observances.name: Sashti
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Samba Dasmi
observances.description_1: Samba Dashami is a popular festival in Odisha. It is dedicated to the worship of Lord Krishna's son, Samba.
observances.description_2:
Samba Dashami is celebrated on the dashami thiti of the Shukla Paksha of in the month of Pausha as per traditional Odia calendar. This festival is unique to the state of Odisha.

According to legend, Samba, son of Lord Krishna, was afflicted by leprosy and was cured by the Sun God Surya after 12 years of penance near Konark. On this day, mothers pray to Surya for the health of their children.

Women wake up before sun rise and prepare a variety of food items like, Khichdi, Udiya Puli, Ghadghadia Tarkari and offer them to Sun God during sun rise. One of the specific characteristics of this ritual is that the food items are offered to the Sun God in the name of each family member, especially children. The legend of Samba Dasami Brata Katha is also read.

deities.title: Surya
deities.description: Surya is the god of the sun, symbolizing light, life, and the dispeller of darkness. As the source of all life, Surya is considered a creator and a vital deity. He is often depicted riding a chariot drawn by seven horses, representing the seven colors of the rainbow or the seven chakras in the body, driven by his charioteer, Aruna. Surya is worshipped daily in many Hindu households, especially during the Surya Namaskar (sun salutation) yoga practice, which enhances vitality and improves health.

observances.name: Vaikunta Ekadasi
observances.description_1: The most important Ekadashi of the year - when the doors of Vaikunta are open.
observances.description_2:
Vaikuntha Ekadashi is a significant day in the Hindu calendar, falling during the Dhanur solar month. In Tamil, it's known as Margazhi month. This day marks one of the two Ekadashis (the 11th lunar day) in the brighter phase (Shukla Paksha) of the month. It may occur in either the Margashirsha or the Pausha month in the Hindu lunar calendar and may have none, one, or two occurrences in a Gregorian year.

Vaikuntha Ekadashi, also called Mukkoti Ekadashi, holds special importance. It's believed that on this day, the gates to the Lord's inner sanctum, Vaikuntha Dwaram, are opened, and devotees observing fast attain salvation by reaching Heaven.

This day is especially significant for the Tirumala Venkateswara Temple in Tirupati and the Sri Ranganathaswamy Temple in Srirangam.

In the Malayalam calendar, it's known as Swarga Vathil Ekadashi in Kerala.

Parana means breaking the fast. Ekadashi Parana is done after sunrise on the next day of Ekadashi fast. It is necessary to do Parana within Dwadashi Tithi unless Dwadashi is over before sunrise.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

deities.title: Sri Panduranga
deities.description: Sri Panduranga is a form of the Vishnu in his Krishna avatar. He worshipped primarily in the Indian states of Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Andhra Pradesh. The Varkari sect, a devotional movement centered around Panduranga, emphasizes the values of humility, devotion, and community service. He embodies a youthful, compassionate aspect of Lord Krishna.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

observances.name: Shri Tailang Swami Jayanti
observances.description_1: Shri Tailang Swami Jayanti is the birth anniversary of Shri Tailang Swami, a saint known for his extraordinary spiritual powers.
observances.description_2:
Shri Tailang Swami Jayanti falls on Ekadashi tithi of Shukla Paksha in the month of Pausha and coincides with Pausha Putrada Ekadashi. Celebrated primarily in Varanasi and by devotees across India, this day honors the life and teachings of this great sage.

Tailang Swami (1607-1887 C.E.) was a great Hindu Yogi. His birth name was Shivarama, and he showed signs of spiritual inclination from a very young age.He renounced worldly life early and spent many years in deep meditation and spiritual practices. He traveled extensively before settling in Varanasi, where he continued his spiritual journey. Numerous miracles are attributed to Tailang Swami, earning him the title "The Walking Shiva of Varanasi."

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Swami Vivekananda Jayanti
observances.description_1: Swami Vivekananda Jayanti marks the birth anniversary of the revered Indian saint and philosopher Swami Vivekananda, celebrated on January 12th.
observances.description_2:
Swami Vivekananda Jayanti, observed on January 12th, celebrates the birth anniversary of Swami Vivekananda, one of India's most influential spiritual leaders. Born as Narendra Nath Datta in Calcutta (now Kolkata) in 1863, Swami Vivekananda was a key figure in the revival of Hinduism in India during the 19th century. He was deeply influenced by his guru, Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa, and became a prominent disciple in the Ramakrishna Mission.

Swami Vivekananda's teachings were characterized by his emphasis on practical spirituality. He advocated for the upliftment of the masses, particularly the poor and marginalized, and stressed the importance of education and self-reliance for national regeneration.

In 1893, Swami Vivekananda represented Hinduism at the Parliament of the World's Religions in Chicago, where he delivered his historic speech that began with the words "Sisters and brothers of America." This address, which emphasized religious tolerance and the universality of spiritual truths, earned him widespread acclaim and introduced Indian philosophy to the Western world.

Throughout his life, Swami Vivekananda traveled extensively, both in India and abroad, spreading the message of Vedanta and inspiring countless individuals with his lectures and writings. He founded the Ramakrishna Math and Ramakrishna Mission, organizations dedicated to serving humanity through educational, cultural, and philanthropic activities.

Swami Vivekananda's legacy continues to inspire people of all backgrounds around the globe. His teachings on self-realization, service to humanity, and the unity of all religions remain relevant in the modern world. Swami Vivekananda Jayanti is celebrated with lectures, seminars, meditation sessions, and cultural programs that highlight his life and teachings, aiming to foster spiritual growth, social harmony, and global peace.

observances.name: Mahakumbh
observances.description_1: The Maha Kumbh Mela is one of the largest and most significant religious gatherings in the world, celebrated every 12 years in rotation at four sacred riverbank sites in India: Prayagraj (Allahabad), Haridwar, Ujjain, and Nashik. It is rooted in Hindu mythology and symbolizes spiritual purification, with millions of devotees gathering to take a holy dip in sacred rivers believed to cleanse sins and lead to liberation (moksha). The event features grand processions of saints, cultural festivities, and religious discourses, drawing ascetics, pilgrims, and tourists from around the globe.
observances.description_2: The Maha Kumbh Mela, celebrated every 12 years, is deeply rooted in Hindu mythology and considered the world's largest religious gathering. Its origins lie in the legend of the Samudra Manthan (churning of the cosmic ocean), where gods (Devas) and demons (Asuras) churned the ocean for the nectar of immortality (Amrita). A fierce battle ensued, and as the divine bird Garuda carried the nectar, four drops fell at Prayagraj, Haridwar, Ujjain, and Nashik, sanctifying these sites. The festival's timing is determined by specific astrological alignments, believed to enhance the spiritual potency of the event. Beyond the holy dip in sacred rivers to cleanse sins and attain liberation (moksha), the Maha Kumbh is a celebration of India’s rich spiritual traditions, featuring grand processions of saints, philosophical discourses, and cultural rituals. It is a unique confluence of devotion, knowledge, and the vibrant diversity of Hindu culture.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

deities.title: Ganga
deities.description: Goddess Ganga, is the personification of the sacred River Ganga. She is believed to have descended from the heavens to Earth, through the efforts of King Bhagiratha, to cleanse the souls of his ancestors and relieve them from a curse. She is seen as a divine purifier, capable of washing away sins and providing salvation to those who bathe in her sacred waters or have their ashes immersed in the river.

observances.name: Shakambhari Purnima
observances.description_1: Shakambhari Purnima is dedicated to Goddess Shakambhari, an incarnation of Devi Bhagwati.
observances.description_2:
Shakambhari Purnima falls on the full moon day (Purnima) in the month of Pausha which is the last day of Shakambhari Navratri.

One popular legend associated with Shakambhari Purnima is that during a time of severe famine, Goddess Bhagwati incarnated as Goddess Shakambhari and provided food and vegetation to the suffering people, thereby saving them from starvation.

The name "Shakambhari" is derived from "Shakam" (vegetables) and "Bhari" (bearing), reflecting her role as the provider of vegetation and nourishment. She is worshiped as the sustainer of life, providing food and nourishment to all living beings. She is often depicted with green surroundings, fruits and vegetables.

observances.name: Lohri
observances.description_1: Lohri, a vibrant Punjabi festival, celebrates the harvest season with bonfires and traditional dances.
observances.description_2:
Predominantly celebrated in the northern Indian states of Punjab and Haryana.

Lohri is mainly a Sikh festival however the day of Lohri is decided based on the Hindu calendar. Lohri is closely linked to the Hindu festival Makara Sankranti and it is celebrated one day before that.

Lohri is dedicated to the worship of the fire god Agni and the Sun god, thanking them for the bountiful harvest.

Celebrations include lighting bonfires, singing traditional songs, dancing, and sharing food with loved ones. People offer prayers for a bountiful harvest and prosperity.

deities.title: Surya
deities.description: Surya is the god of the sun, symbolizing light, life, and the dispeller of darkness. As the source of all life, Surya is considered a creator and a vital deity. He is often depicted riding a chariot drawn by seven horses, representing the seven colors of the rainbow or the seven chakras in the body, driven by his charioteer, Aruna. Surya is worshipped daily in many Hindu households, especially during the Surya Namaskar (sun salutation) yoga practice, which enhances vitality and improves health.

observances.name: Bhogi Pandigai
observances.description_1: Bhogi Pandigai, a Tamil festival, marks the beginning of Pongal celebrations with traditional rituals and community bonfires.
observances.description_2:
In Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, and Tamil Nadu, Makara Sankranti is celebrated over four days, each with unique rituals.

The first day, Bhogi, also called Bhogi Pandigai, marks the beginning of the Sankranti festivities, occurring a day before Makara Sankranti. People rise before dawn to ignite bonfires, known as Bhogi Mantalu, using wood and other fuels. It's a tradition to discard old and unused items, offering them to the fire.

On Bhogi, children in many Telugu families are showered with Regi Pallu, an Indian jujube fruit, believed to bring protection and prosperity. They dress in colourful attire, like Langa-Voni for girls, while a mix of Regi Pallu, flower petals, sugarcane, and coins are showered on them. This ritual, known as Bhogi Pallu, is thought to ward off the evil eye and bless them with abundance and long life.

Another ritual, Ariselu Adugulu, involves placing sweet rice dishes called Ariselu on the floor for small children to walk on, symbolizing their first steps.

To celebrate Bhogi, families participate in Rangoli competitions, creating colourful designs outside their homes. Many also set up Bommala-Koluvu (a tradition of displaying dolls and figurines, the word "Bommala Koluvu" translates to "Court of Toys" in Telugu. Displays are often thematic, telling a story from a Hindu text, and share sweets generously with friends and family.

deities.title: Lakshmi
deities.description: Lakshmi is the goddess of wealth, fortune, and prosperity, both material and spiritual. She is the consort of Vishnu and is typically depicted with four arms, symbolizing the four goals of human life—dharma, artha, kama, and moksha. Lakshmi is celebrated during the festival of Diwali, when she is worshipped to invite wealth and happiness into homes.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

observances.name: Purnima
observances.description_1: Purnima, signifies the full moon day, often marked by religious ceremonies and spiritual observances.
observances.description_2:
Purnima, or the Full Moon day, is a significant occasion in Indian culture, occurring monthly as the moon reaches its maximum brightness.

Purnima fasting is observed either on the Purnima day itself or the day before, known as Chaturdashi, depending on the timing of the Purnima Tithi (lunar day) from the previous day.

Purnima fasting on Chaturdashi occurs only when the Purnima begins during the Madhyahna period on the previous day. If Chaturdashi extends beyond Madhyahna, it's considered impure for Purnima fasting, even if Purnima begins later in the evening.

In North India, the full moon day is called Purnima, while in South India, it's referred to as Pournami or Pournima, and fasting on this day is known as Pournami Vratam, observed from sunrise until the moon is sighted.

observances.name: Makara Sankranti
observances.description_1: Makara Sankranti, celebrates the transition of the sun into Makara Rashi(Capricorn). It's marked by colorful rituals and kite flying.
observances.description_2:
Makar Sankranti is a significant Hindu festival dedicated to Lord Surya. Although there are twelve Sankranti occurrences throughout the year, Makar Sankranti is considered the most important due to its religious significance, often simply referred to as Sankranti.

This day marks the Sun's transition into Makar Rashi. Surya Deva, revered as the nourisher of all life on Earth, is worshipped on this auspicious occasion. While all twelve Sankranti days are deemed important for worshipping Surya Deva, taking holy baths, and performing acts of charity, Makar Sankranti holds a special place as the beginning of the Sun's journey into the northern hemisphere.

There's often confusion between Makar Sankranti and Uttarayana. Makar Sankranti celebrates the Sun's entry into Makar Rashi, while Uttarayana marks the start of the Sun's northward journey.

Contrary to common belief, Makar Sankranti isn't solely a harvest festival, although it often aligns with the harvest season in some parts of India. Its date fluctuates, with Makar Sankranti falling on either January 14 or 15 in the Gregorian calendar. If the Sankranti moment occurs before sunset, it's observed on the same day; otherwise, it's celebrated the following day.

Makar Sankranti is celebrated over two to four days in various regions, each with its names and rituals. In Tamil Nadu, it's called Pongal and lasts for four days, while in Gujarat, it's known as Uttarayana. Andhra Pradesh celebrates it as Pedda Panduga, also for four days. In Assam, it's Magh Bihu or Bhogali Bihu, and in Punjab, it's Lohri.
Rituals include lighting bonfires, worshipping the rising Sun, taking holy dips, preparing special dishes like Pongal in Tamil Nadu, flying kites in Gujarat, and worshipping livestock.

Overall, Makar Sankranti is a celebration of gratitude towards Surya Deva, symbolizing the transition from darkness to light and the onset of longer days, fostering hope and renewal.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

He is often depicted riding a chariot drawn by seven horses, representing the seven colors of the rainbow or the seven chakras in the body, driven by his charioteer, Aruna. Surya is worshipped daily in many Hindu households, especially during the Surya Namaskar (sun salutation) yoga practice, which enhances vitality and improves health.

deities.title: Ganga
deities.description: Goddess Ganga, is the personification of the sacred River Ganga. She is believed to have descended from the heavens to Earth, through the efforts of King Bhagiratha, to cleanse the souls of his ancestors and relieve them from a curse. She is seen as a divine purifier, capable of washing away sins and providing salvation to those who bathe in her sacred waters or have their ashes immersed in the river.

observances.name: Masik Sankranti
observances.description_1: Masik Sankranti marks the transition of the Sun into a new zodiac sign each month, observed with spiritual significance.
observances.description_2:
Sankranti refers to the transmigration of the sun from one rashi (zodiac) to another in Indian astronomy
The observance revolves around sun’s transition into new rashi (zodiac sign), symoblizing the end of one solar month and the beginning of another.

Malik Sankranti’s including the Makara Sankranthi is associated with Surya pravesh (Sun’s entry) into each rashi. There are twelve rashis (12 signs) namely Mekh (Mekha), Virkh, Mithun, Kark, Singh-Simha, Kanya, Tula,Vrischik, Dhan, Makara, Kumbh and Meena.

While significance and rituals may vary for each Masik Sankranti, they are generally considered as times to offer prayers, seek blessings and make positive changes in one’s life.

Sankranti days are considered good for charity activities and all auspicious ceremonies are avoided on the day of Sankranti(s).

observances.name: Kanuma Panduga
observances.description_1: Kanuma Panduga is a festival dedicated to worshipping cattle and agricultural tools.
observances.description_2:
Kanuma Panduga falls on the third day after Makar Sankranti. It is a harvest festival celebrated in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana. It is a heartfelt expression of gratitude towards cattle, particularly cows and bulls. It is a festival based on solar cycles, Kanuma signifies the deep respect farmers have for these vital companions in their agricultural endeavors.

On Kanuma, farmers rise with the sun to bathe and adorn their cattle with vibrant paints, colourful beads, and sometimes even decorated horns. The cattle are then taken to nearby temples for special prayers and offerings. This act of worship, known as "Go Puja" (Cow Worship), expresses gratitude for the cattle's contribution to agriculture.

Some believe Kanuma commemorates Lord Krishna's victory over the demon king Mura. Additionally, another belief links Kanuma to Lord Krishna saving the people of Gokulam from a devastating flood on this very day.

Traditional games like bullock cart races add a dash of excitement, while some regions hold Jallikattu (Tamil Nadu's version of bull taming) competitions. Rural artisans and craftsmen who support farmers throughout the year are also honoured during this festive occasion.

observances.name: Lambodara Sankashti Chaturthi
observances.description_1: Lambodara Sankashti Chaturthi is a fasting day dedicated to worshipping the Lambodara form of Lord Ganesha.
observances.description_2:
Lambodara Sankashti falls on the Chaturthi thiti of the Krishna Paksha in the month of Magha.

Lambodara Sankashti is dedicated to the worship of Lord Ganesha, seeking his blessings for the removal of obstacles, success in endeavors, and overall prosperity. On this day, devotees of Lord Ganesha observe a strict fast from sunrise to moonrise and consume only fruits and roots or tubers.

deities.title: Ganesha
deities.description: Ganesha is the elephant-headed deity known as the remover of obstacles and the lord of beginnings. Son of Shiva and Parvati, he is commonly depicted with a broken tusk and riding a mouse. Ganesha is revered for his wisdom and is often invoked first in Hindu rituals to ensure success and clear obstacles. He also symbolizes the patronage of arts and sciences.

observances.name: Sankasta Chaturthi
observances.description_1: Sankashti Chaturthi is a significant day for Lord Ganesha devotees, observed to seek his blessings and overcome obstacles.
observances.description_2:
In the Hindu calendar, each lunar month includes two Chaturthi Tithi. The one following the full moon, known as Purnimasi, during Krishna Paksha is called Sankashti Chaturthi, while the one following the new moon, known as Amavasya, during Shukla Paksha is called Vinayaka Chaturthi.

If Sankashti Chaturthi falls on a Tuesday, it is revered as Angarki Chaturthi, considered highly auspicious, particularly in Western and Southern India, notably Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu.

During Sankashti Chaturthi, devotees of Lord Ganesha observe a fast from sunrise to moonrise. Sankashti, meaning deliverance during troubled times, signifies the belief that observing this fast can remove obstacles, as Lord Ganesha is revered as the remover of obstacles.

The fast is observed strictly, with consumption limited to fruits, roots, and vegetable products. Typical foods include Sabudana Khichadi, potatoes, and peanuts, with devotees breaking their fast after sighting the moon.

In North India, Sankashti Chaturthi in the month of Magha is known as Sakat Chauth, while Vinayaka Chaturthi in the month of Bhadrapada is celebrated as Ganesha Chaturthi worldwide as Lord Ganesha's birthday.

Among Tamil Hindus, Sankashti Chaturthi is referred to as Ganesh Sankatahara or Sankatahara Chaturthi.

observances.name: Shattila Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Shattila Ekadashi is a fasting day dedicated to Lord Vishnu that falls in the month of Magha (Krishna Paksha).
observances.description_2:
Shattila Ekadashi is observed on the Ekadashi of the Krishna Paksha in the month of Magha. The word "Shattila" is derived from two Sanskrit words: "Shat" meaning six and "Tila" meaning sesame seeds. The use of sesame seeds in six different ways is a unique feature of this Ekadashi.

According to Hindu mythology, there was once a wealthy but miserly woman who, despite her riches, never engaged in charitable acts. Lord Vishnu, disguised as a beggar, approached her for alms. She gave him a lump of clay instead of food.As a result of her lack of charity, she faced severe hardships in her next life. To alleviate her suffering, she was advised to observe Shattila Ekadashi and use sesame seeds in six different ways: bathing with sesame seeds, consuming sesame seeds, donating sesame seeds, performing havan with sesame seeds, making offerings with sesame seeds, and applying sesame paste on her body. By following these rituals, she was absolved of her sins.

Devotees observe a strict fast on Shattila Ekadashi, abstaining from grains, beans, and certain vegetables. Some may follow a complete fast without food and water, while others may consume fruits, milk, and water. The fast begins at sunrise on Ekadashi and ends after sunrise on the following day, Dwadashi.

He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

observances.name: Sattila Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:

On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Mauni Amavasya
observances.description_1: Mauni Amavasya is a day for purification marked by silence and devotion, particularly auspicious for sacred baths and prayers.
observances.description_2:
Mauni Amavasya is celebrated predominantly in North India, particularly in the holy city of Prayagraj during the Magha month of the Hindu calendar. Falling on the new moon day, or Amavasya, devotees observe this day with deep spiritual significance.

During Mauni Amavasya, Lord Vishnu (particularly in his form as Lord Narayana) is worshipped. Devotees engage in various rituals, including taking a vow of silence (mauna) and abstaining from spoken communication to delve into introspection and inner peace.

Devotees believe that Mauni Amavasya is a day when the cosmos aligns to enhance the spiritual energy, and taking a holy dip in the confluence of the Ganges, Yamuna, and Saraswati rivers at Prayagraj is considered highly auspicious.

deities.title: Lakshmi
deities.description: Lakshmi is the goddess of wealth, fortune, and prosperity, both material and spiritual. She is the consort of Vishnu and is typically depicted with four arms, symbolizing the four goals of human life—dharma, artha, kama, and moksha. Lakshmi is celebrated during the festival of Diwali, when she is worshipped to invite wealth and happiness into homes.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

deities.title: Ganga
deities.description: Goddess Ganga, is the personification of the sacred River Ganga. She is believed to have descended from the heavens to Earth, through the efforts of King Bhagiratha, to cleanse the souls of his ancestors and relieve them from a curse. She is seen as a divine purifier, capable of washing away sins and providing salvation to those who bathe in her sacred waters or have their ashes immersed in the river.

observances.name: Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: Ganesh Jayanti
observances.description_1: Ganesh Jayanti celebrates the birth of Lord Ganesha in Maharastra and Goa, the elephant-headed god of wisdom, prosperity, and remover of obstacles.
observances.description_2:
Ganesh Jayanti is celebrated on the Chaturthi thiti of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Magha. It is especially popular in Maharashtra and Goa. In most parts of India, the birth anniversary of Lord Ganesha is observed during Bhadrapada month and known as Ganesha Chaturthi.

Ganesh Jayanti marks the birth of Lord Ganesha, who is revered as the god of beginnings, wisdom, and the remover of obstacles. His blessings are sought before starting any new venture or undertaking.

According to legend, Goddess Parvati created Ganesha from sandalwood paste and breathed life into him to guard her while she bathed. When Lord Shiva tried to enter, Ganesha stopped him, leading to a confrontation where Shiva beheaded him. To appease Parvati, Shiva replaced Ganesha's head with that of an elephant and granted him divine status.

deities.title: Ganesha
deities.description: Ganesha is the elephant-headed deity known as the remover of obstacles and the lord of beginnings. Son of Shiva and Parvati, he is commonly depicted with a broken tusk and riding a mouse. Ganesha is revered for his wisdom and is often invoked first in Hindu rituals to ensure success and clear obstacles. He also symbolizes the patronage of arts and sciences.

observances.name: Vasant Panchami
observances.description_1: Honoring Saraswati the Goddess of knowledge, music, arts, science and technology.
observances.description_2:
Vasant Panchami day is dedicated to Saraswati, the Goddess of knowledge, music, arts, science and technology. Vasant Panchami is also known as Shri Panchami and Saraswati Panchami.

This festival falls on the fifth day (Panchami) of the Shukla paksha of Magha masa, which typically occurs in late January or early February.

People worship Goddess Saraswati on Vasant Panchami to seek enlightenment and dispel ignorance. One of the prominent rituals of this day is Akshar-Abhyasam or Vidya-Arambham, where children begin their educational journey. Schools and colleges often conduct pujas in the morning to seek blessings for their students.

deities.title: Saraswathi
deities.description: Saraswati is the goddess of knowledge, music, art, wisdom, and learning. Saraswati is often depicted as a beautiful deity dressed in pure white, often seated on a white lotus, which symbolizes light, knowledge, and truth. She not only embodies knowledge but also the experience of the highest reality. Her iconography usually includes a veena, representing the arts and sciences, and books, representing knowledge.

observances.name: Sashti
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Ratha Saptami
observances.description_1: Ratha Saptami marks the auspicious festival celebrating Lord Surya.
observances.description_2:
Saptami Tithi honors Lord Surya, the Sun God. The Shukla Paksha Saptami in Magha masa is recognized as Ratha Saptami or Magha Saptami. It marks the beginning of Lord Surya's illumination of the world, akin to his birthday, thus earning the title Surya Jayanti.

Ratha Saptami holds profound significance for charitable deeds. Worshipping Lord Surya and fasting on this day are believed to absolve all kinds of sins, whether committed knowingly or unknowingly, in speech, action, or thought, across present and past lives.

It is customary to bathe during Arunodaya, the period approximately one and a half hours before sunrise. This practice, known as Ratha Saptami Snan, is considered crucial for health and well-being, earning the day the moniker Arogya Saptami. Bathing in natural water bodies like rivers is preferred.

Following the bath, devotees worship Lord Surya at sunrise, offering Arghyadan—a ritual of respectfully pouring water from a small Kalash with folded hands in Namaskar Mudra. Lighting a ghee lamp and offering a Karpoor, Dhup, and red flowers further honors the Sun God, believed to bestow longevity, good health, and prosperity upon the devotee.

Ratha Saptami is also referred to as Achala Saptami.

deities.title: Surya
deities.description: Surya is the god of the sun, symbolizing light, life, and the dispeller of darkness. As the source of all life, Surya is considered a creator and a vital deity. He is often depicted riding a chariot drawn by seven horses, representing the seven colors of the rainbow or the seven chakras in the body, driven by his charioteer, Aruna. Surya is worshipped daily in many Hindu households, especially during the Surya Namaskar (sun salutation) yoga practice, which enhances vitality and improves health.

observances.name: Narmada Jayanti
observances.description_1: Narmada Jayanti celebrates the birth of the Narmada river on Earth,
observances.description_2:
Narmada Jayanti falls on Saptami Tithi of Shukla Paksha in the month of Magha. It is mainly celebrated in Amarkantak in Madhya Pradesh, the origin of river Narmada.

On this day devotees worship river Narmada and take a dip in the river to rid themselves of their sins. Ratha Saptami also falls on the same day making it very auspicious. On the banks of Narmada, a Maha Aarti is performed on the evening of Narmada Jayanti which is witnessed by thousands of devotees.

observances.name: Madhva Navami
observances.description_1: Madhva Navami commemorates Madvacharya, a revered philosopher and theologian in Hinduism.
observances.description_2:
This day marks the day when Madhvacharya, the third great philosopher following Sri Shankaracharya and Shri Ramanujacharya, attained Nirvana. On the 9th day of Magha masa in the year 1317 AD, while teaching the Aitareya Upanishad Bhashya to his disciples at the Sri Anantheshwara Temple, Madhvacharya suddenly vanished into a heap of flowers, believed to signify his entrance into the Badarikasrama. He is revered as the third incarnation of Lord Vayu after Hanuman and Bheema, and he established the philosophy of Dwaita or Dualism. Madhvacharya advocated that salvation is accessible to all, irrespective of birth, and his teachings revitalized the Bhakti traditions in Karnataka.

Madhvacharya's legacy extends to the Udupi region, renowned for its Krishna Temple, where he is said to have installed the idol of Krishna. Legend has it that while composing Dvaadasha-stotra, his twelve-part poem praising Lord Krishna, he rescued sailors in distress at the beach and received a lump of gopi-chandana clay from the ship's captain as a token of gratitude. To everyone's amazement, the lump broke, revealing the Deity of Lord BalaKrishna, which Madhvacharya installed at Malpe beach, and the Krishna deity, which he brought to Udupi and enshrined in his Matha. Despite efforts by his disciples, only Madhvacharya himself could move the Deity, symbolizing divine approval. In ecstatic devotion, he carried the Lord back to Udupi, where he bathed and enshrined Him in the ShriKrishna Matha, inaugurating a temple that remains revered today.

Madhvacharya's philosophy's key tenests tenets include the soul's bondage to the world due to ignorance, its liberation through seeking the grace of Sri Hari, and the necessity of Bhakti as the sole path to Sri Hari, achievable through meditation, study of sacred texts, and guidance from a Guru.

observances.name: Jaya Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Jaya Ekadashi is a fasting day dedicated to Lord Vishnu that falls in the month of Magha (Shukla Paksha).
observances.description_2:
Jaya Ekadashi is is observed on the Ekadashi of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Magha .Jaya Ekadashi is considered highly auspicious and is believed to grant victory over sins, freedom from the cycle of rebirth, and the attainment of moksha.

According to Hindu mythology, the story of Jaya Ekadashi is associated with a Gandharva named Malyavan and his consort Pushpavati. They were cursed by Lord Indra to become demons due to a lapse in their duties and improper conduct. To atone for their sins, they observed a fast and performed rituals on the day of Jaya Ekadashi. Pleased with their devotion, Lord Vishnu granted them liberation from their demonic forms and restored them to their celestial status.

Devotees observe a strict fast on Jaya Ekadashi, abstaining from grains, beans, and certain vegetables. Some may follow a complete fast without food and water, while others may consume fruits, milk, and water. The fast begins at sunrise on Ekadashi and ends after sunrise on the following day, Dwadashi.

observances.name: Jaya Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Jaya Ekadashi is a fasting day dedicated to Lord Vishnu that falls in the month of Magha (Shukla Paksha).
observances.description_2:
Jaya Ekadashi is is observed on the Ekadashi of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Magha .Jaya Ekadashi is considered highly auspicious and is believed to grant victory over sins, freedom from the cycle of rebirth, and the attainment of moksha.

According to Hindu mythology, the story of Jaya Ekadashi is associated with a Gandharva named Malyavan and his consort Pushpavati. They were cursed by Lord Indra to become demons due to a lapse in their duties and improper conduct. To atone for their sins, they observed a fast and performed rituals on the day of Jaya Ekadashi. Pleased with their devotion, Lord Vishnu granted them liberation from their demonic forms and restored them to their celestial status.

Devotees observe a strict fast on Jaya Ekadashi, abstaining from grains, beans, and certain vegetables. Some may follow a complete fast without food and water, while others may consume fruits, milk, and water. The fast begins at sunrise on Ekadashi and ends after sunrise on the following day, Dwadashi.

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Thai Pusam
observances.description_1: Thai Pusam, predominantly celebrated in Tamil Nadu, commemorates the victory of Lord Murugan over evil forces with vibrant processions.
observances.description_2:
Thaipusam is celebrated in south Indian states especially in Tamil Nadu to commemorate the victory of the Lord Murugan over the demon Surapadman using a divine spear granted by Parvati. It falls in Tamil Solar month Thai, which is Solar month Makara in other Hindu calendars.

Devotees tend to wear yellow during Thaipusam because yellow is Lord Murugan's favourite colour, also undertake a pilgrimage to temples dedicated to Lord Murugan, with the most famous being the Palani Murugan Temple and the Batu Caves in Malaysia.

deities.title: Subramanya
deities.description: Subramanya, also known as Kartikeya or Murugan, is revered as god of war and victory. He is the son of Shiva and Parvati and the brother of Ganesha. Subramanya is depicted with six heads, symbolizing his omniscience, and rides a peacock, which represents his defeat of the demon Tarakasura. He is especially popular in South Indian communities around the world, where he is worshipped as a youthful god embodying bravery and leadership.

observances.name: Guru Ravidas Jayanti
observances.description_1: Guru Ravidas Jayanti commemorates the birth anniversary of Guru Ravidas, revered for his teachings of equality, compassion, and social justice.
observances.description_2:
Guru Ravidas (born 1377 C.E.) was a revered saint of the Bhakti Movement, renowned for his devotional songs and verses that left a profound impact on the movement. He is also referred to as Raidas, Rohidas, and Ruhidas.

According to the Hindu calendar, Guru Ravidas was born on Magha Purnima, leading to the celebration of his birth anniversary on this auspicious day as per Hindu lunar calendar.

His birthplace, Now known as Shri Guru Ravidas Janam Asthan, has become a significant pilgrimage site for his followers.

observances.name: Lalita Jayanti
observances.description_1: Lalita Jayanti is dedicated to the worship of Goddess Lalita Tripura Sundari, one of the ten Mahavidya Goddesses.
observances.description_2:
Lalita Jayanti celebrates Goddess Lalita Tripura Sundari, the most beautiful in all three worlds. She also known as Rajarajeshwari, Shodashi, and Kamakshi. Lalita Tripura Sundari is also associated with the Sri Vidya tradition of Tantra.

Mythology describes the battle between Goddess Lalita and the demon, Bhandasura. He performed severe penance and received a boon that made him almost invincible. To restore balance and destroy Bhandasura, the gods invoked the supreme goddess. Goddess Lalita Tripura Sundari emerged in all her splendor and glory, seated on a chariot and armed with powerful weapons.
The goddess engaged in a fierce battle with Bhandasura, displaying her supreme strength and ultimately defeated and destroyed Bhandasura, restoring peace and harmony to the universe.

She is often depicted iconographically as a 16-year-old girl seated on a lotus that rests on the body of Sadashiva, which in turn lies on a throne whose legs are the gods Brahma, Vishnu, Ishana, and Rudra.

observances.name: Masik Sankranti
observances.description_1: Masik Sankranti marks the transition of the Sun into a new zodiac sign each month, observed with spiritual significance.
observances.description_2:
Sankranti refers to the transmigration of the sun from one rashi (zodiac) to another in Indian astronomy
The observance revolves around sun’s transition into new rashi (zodiac sign), symoblizing the end of one solar month and the beginning of another.

Malik Sankranti’s including the Makara Sankranthi is associated with Surya pravesh (Sun’s entry) into each rashi. There are twelve rashis (12 signs) namely Mekh (Mekha), Virkh, Mithun, Kark, Singh-Simha, Kanya, Tula,Vrischik, Dhan, Makara, Kumbh and Meena.

While significance and rituals may vary for each Masik Sankranti, they are generally considered as times to offer prayers, seek blessings and make positive changes in one’s life.

Sankranti days are considered good for charity activities and all auspicious ceremonies are avoided on the day of Sankranti(s).

observances.name: Purnima
observances.description_1: Purnima, signifies the full moon day, often marked by religious ceremonies and spiritual observances.
observances.description_2:
Purnima, or the Full Moon day, is a significant occasion in Indian culture, occurring monthly as the moon reaches its maximum brightness.

Purnima fasting is observed either on the Purnima day itself or the day before, known as Chaturdashi, depending on the timing of the Purnima Tithi (lunar day) from the previous day.

Purnima fasting on Chaturdashi occurs only when the Purnima begins during the Madhyahna period on the previous day. If Chaturdashi extends beyond Madhyahna, it's considered impure for Purnima fasting, even if Purnima begins later in the evening.

In North India, the full moon day is called Purnima, while in South India, it's referred to as Pournami or Pournima, and fasting on this day is known as Pournami Vratam, observed from sunrise until the moon is sighted.

observances.name: Sankasta Chaturthi
observances.description_1: Sankashti Chaturthi is a significant day for Lord Ganesha devotees, observed to seek his blessings and overcome obstacles.
observances.description_2:
In the Hindu calendar, each lunar month includes two Chaturthi Tithi. The one following the full moon, known as Purnimasi, during Krishna Paksha is called Sankashti Chaturthi, while the one following the new moon, known as Amavasya, during Shukla Paksha is called Vinayaka Chaturthi.

If Sankashti Chaturthi falls on a Tuesday, it is revered as Angarki Chaturthi, considered highly auspicious, particularly in Western and Southern India, notably Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu.

During Sankashti Chaturthi, devotees of Lord Ganesha observe a fast from sunrise to moonrise. Sankashti, meaning deliverance during troubled times, signifies the belief that observing this fast can remove obstacles, as Lord Ganesha is revered as the remover of obstacles.

The fast is observed strictly, with consumption limited to fruits, roots, and vegetable products. Typical foods include Sabudana Khichadi, potatoes, and peanuts, with devotees breaking their fast after sighting the moon.

In North India, Sankashti Chaturthi in the month of Magha is known as Sakat Chauth, while Vinayaka Chaturthi in the month of Bhadrapada is celebrated as Ganesha Chaturthi worldwide as Lord Ganesha's birthday.

Among Tamil Hindus, Sankashti Chaturthi is referred to as Ganesh Sankatahara or Sankatahara Chaturthi.

observances.name: Yashoda Jayanti
observances.description_1: Yashoda Jayanti celebrates the birth anniversary of Ma Yashodha who raised Lord Krishna
observances.description_2:
Yashoda Jayanti is observed on the Shashthi thiti of the Krishna Paksha in the month of Phalguna in the Hindu calendar.

The festival honors Yashoda's role in the upbringing of Lord Krishna, highlighting her unconditional love and care. It is a day to remember and celebrate the virtues of motherhood, devotion, and selfless love.

observances.name: Shabari Jayanti
observances.description_1: Shabari Jayanti is dedicated to Shabari, a devotee of Lord Rama, celebrated for her pure devotion and humble service.
observances.description_2:
Shabari Jayanti is observed on the Saptami of the Krishna Paksha in the Hindu month of Phalguna. Shabari Jayanti celebrates the devotion and faith of Shabari, who waited her entire life to meet Lord Rama.

Shabari despite her humble background, was determined to seek a higher spiritual path. She left her home and wandered into the forest, where she met the sage Matanga. Impressed by her devotion, Matanga accepted her as his disciple and instructed her in the ways of spiritual practice. Before his death, Sage Matanga told Shabari that one day Lord Rama would visit her ashram. With this prophecy, Shabari continued to live in the forest, dedicating her life to the service of her guru and Lord Rama. Every day, she cleaned the ashram, collected fruits, and kept the path clear, hoping that Lord Rama would arrive. Years passed, and Shabari's devotion never wavered. Finally, one day, Lord Rama and his brother Lakshmana arrived at her ashram while searching for Sita, who had been abducted by Ravana. Overwhelmed with joy, Shabari welcomed them with great reverence. She offered them fruits, first tasting them to ensure they were sweet and fit for her beloved Lord. Despite her humble offerings, Lord Rama accepted them with gratitude, recognizing the purity and devotion behind her actions. Lord Rama blessed Shabari, praising her devotion and teaching the world that true devotion transcends all social and caste boundaries. He emphasized that pure love and dedication are the most important qualities in a devotee.

On this day, Mata Shabri and Lord Rama are worshipped and it is believed that by doing this we get the blessings of Lord Rama. Devotees also chant mantras and recite passages from the Ramayana, particularly the episodes involving Shabari and her interaction with Lord Rama.

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Vijaya Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Mahashivaratri
observances.description_1: Maha Shivratri celebrates Lord Shiva with fasting, prayers, and devotion.
observances.description_2:
Mahashivaratri is celebrated annually on the Chaturdashi of the Krishna Paksha of Phalguna masa (as per Purnimanta) or Magha masa(as per Amanta).

Mahashivaratri is dedicated to Lord Shiva, the destroyer and transformer among the Hindu Trinity. It symbolizes the convergence of Shiva and Shakti, representing the divine union.

Devotees fast, meditate, and offer prayers throughout the night, known as "Jaagran," in reverence to Lord Shiva. They visit Shiva temples, perform abhisheka (ritual bathing of the Shiva Linga), and chant "Om Namah Shivaya" to attain spiritual purification and enlightenment. It's a night of deep introspection, devotion, and seeking the grace of Lord Shiva.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: RamaKrishna Paramahamsa Jayanti
observances.description_1: Ramakrishna Paramahamsa Jayanti commemorates the birth anniversary of the esteemed Indian saint Ramakrishna Paramahamsa.
observances.description_2:
Ramakrishna, born on February 18, 1836, in Kamarpukur, West Bengal, India, was a revered saint of 19th-century India. Raised in a devout Brahmin family, he later served as a priest at the Dakshineswar Kali Temple, devoted to the goddess Kali. Known affectionately as Ramakrishna Paramahansa, his given name was Gadadhar Chattopadhyay. He shared a spiritual bond with his wife, Sarada Devi.

Among his notable disciples was Swami Vivekananda, who founded the Ramakrishna Math in honor of his guru. This institution is dedicated to humanitarian work and the global propagation of the Ramakrishna Movement. The headquarters of the Ramakrishna Math and Mission is situated at Belur Math.

Ramakrishna's birth anniversary is commemorated annually according to the Hindu lunar calendar, specifically on Dwitiya, Phalguna, Shukla Paksha, Vikram Samvat 1892. This occasion is observed across all Ramakrishna Maths worldwide, celebrating his profound spiritual legacy and teachings.

observances.name: Phulera Dooj
observances.description_1: Celebrating love and togetherness marks the start of the Holi festive season with flowers.
observances.description_2:
Phulera Dooj, also known as Phoolera Duj, is a lively festival celebrated in the Braj region of India, especially in Mathura and Vrindavan.

It falls on the second day (Dooj) of the Shukla Paksha of the Phalguna masa, which comes between Vasant Panchami and Holi.

Legend has it that on this day, Lord Krishna played Holi of flowers (Phulera) with Radha and the other gopis. The famous temples in the Vrindavan region are adorned with vibrant floral decorations.

Hindu households are adorned with flowers and colourful rangolis on this day. Special delicacies are prepared for Lord Krishna and offered as Bhog in front of the deity idols. Poha is a common preparation served as Prasad during this festival.

According to astrologically, Phulera Dooj is a day that is free from all defects or Dosha. Hence all auspicious work especially marriage ceremonies does not need any Muhurat on the day of Phulera Dooj. However, this point of view is debatable and not all astrologers agree with it.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

observances.name: Sashti
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Melukote Vairamudi Utsava
observances.description_1: Melukote Vairamudi Utsava is a grand festival celebrated in Melukote, Karnataka, where the deity is adorned with the Vairamudi crown, symbolizing sovereignty and divinity.
observances.description_2: Melukote Vairamudi Utsava is a significant festival celebrated in Melukote, a pilgrimage town in Karnataka, India. The highlight of the festival is the procession of the deity adorned with the Vairamudi crown. The crown symbolizes sovereignty and divinity and is adorned by the deity once a year during this festival. The entire town of Melukote comes alive with vibrant decorations, colourful processions, and traditional rituals, creating a festive atmosphere filled with joy and devotion.

observances.name: Rangabhari Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Amalaki Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
