When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Surya Grahana
observances.description_1: Solar Eclipse occurs when the Moon passes between the Earth and the Sun, temporarily blocking sunlight.
observances.description_2:
If a Solar Eclipse spans across two different dates, the Eclipse Day should be when the maximum eclipse occurs.

In Hinduism, Solar Eclipses hold significance only if visible to the naked eye. Penumbral Solar Eclipses, invisible to the naked eye, have no associated rituals. Rituals are only observed if the Solar Eclipse is visible during the Umbral Phase.

If a Solar Eclipse is not visible in your city but is visible nearby, it should not be observed. Precautions advised during Sutak should only be taken if the Solar Eclipse is visible in your city, regardless of visibility due to weather conditions.

Sutak, an inauspicious time before Solar and Lunar Eclipses, is believed to contaminate the Earth's atmosphere. It lasts for 4 Prahars (12 hours) before a Solar Eclipse and 3 Prahars (9 hours) before a Lunar Eclipse, during which food consumption is prohibited.

During Sutak, all food, solid or liquid, is prohibited, except for children, the sick, and the elderly, for whom restrictions are limited to a single Prahar (3 hours). Pregnant women are advised to avoid venturing out during the Eclipse to prevent potential harm to the unborn child.

Various activities such as oil massage, drinking water, and engaging in sexual activities are prohibited during an Eclipse. After the Eclipse, cooked food should be discarded, and only freshly prepared food should be consumed. Items like grains and pickles that cannot be discarded should be protected with Kusha grass or Tulasi leaves. It is also recommended to bathe and make offerings to Brahmins after the Eclipse for spiritual benefit.

eclipse_info.description: It is advised to not consume any food or liquids during this time.

observances.name: Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: Ugadi
observances.description_1: Celebrating the New Year with Festivities and Traditions across India's regions.
observances.description_2:
Ugadi is observed differently across India. In North India, it kicks off the nine-day Chaitra Navratri leading up to Rama Navami. In Karnataka, it's Yugadi, marking the Kannada New Year. In Maharashtra, it's Gudi Padwa, and in Rajasthan, it's Thapna. In Andhra Pradesh and Telangana, it's Ugadi, marking a new year.

Ugadi marks the onset of a new "Samvat" or cycle, associated with the position of Jupiter in a 60-year cycle. It's celebrated with the recitation of Panchangam, offering yearly forecasts. This day is considered auspicious for various activities, especially shopping.

Celebrated on the Shukla Paksha Pratipada of the Chaitra month, Ugadi traditions include rituals like the Abhyang Snan (oil bath), hosting flags at homes, and consuming tender Neem leaves. It also signifies the beginning of Chaitra Navratri.

Ugadi is celebrated with special dishes like Ugadi Pachadi, a traditional concoction made of jaggery, raw mango, neem flowers, and tamarind.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

deities.title: Rama
deities.description: Lord Rama is the seventh avatar of Vishnu, incarnated to defeat the demon king Ravana and restore dharma. He is one of the most revered deities in Hinduism. He embodies the ideals of virtue, duty, and kingly conduct, often referred to as Maryada Purushottama. His life and actions serve as a guide for ideal behavior in various roles - as a son, husband, brother, and king.

observances.name: Matsya Jayanti
observances.description_1: Matsya Jayanti celebrates the birth of Lord Vishnu's first avatar, Matsya (the fish), who is believed to have saved humanity and the sacred Vedas from a great deluge.
observances.description_2:
Matsya Jayanti is a significant Hindu festival that commemorates the appearance of Lord Vishnu's first avatar, Matsya, in the form of a fish. According to Hindu mythology, Lord Vishnu took the Matsya avatar to save the ancient scriptures, the Vedas, and the sage Manu from a catastrophic flood. This avatar marks the beginning of the ten principal avatars (Dashavatara) of Vishnu.

On this day, special prayers, rituals, and pujas are performed in Vishnu temples across India. Devotees chant Vishnu Sahasranama (the thousand names of Vishnu) and other hymns dedicated to Matsya.

observances.name: Gangaur
observances.description_1: Gangaur, a joyous Rajasthani festival, celebrates the union of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati.
observances.description_2:
Gangaur is celebrated primarily in the Indian state of Rajasthan, but it is also observed in some parts of Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh.

The Gangaur festivities starts on the first day of the month of Chaitra masa which is on the day following Holi, and is consummated on the third day of Shukla Paksha of the same month.

The story of Gangaur revolves around Parvati being escorted by Lord Shiva from her parental home, following a grand farewell. As per ancient texts, Parvati had performed severe penance for days to persuade Lord Shiva to have her as his wife. Her perseverance and devotion did indeed move him.

Married women observe a fast restricting themselves to only one meal a day for the well-being and longevity of their husbands. Clay idols of Shiva-Gauri perfected by the local craftsmen are decorated and worshipped during the full course of the festival, the idols are immersed in water on the final day.

deities.title: Parvathi
deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife, and is the mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Kushmanda Puja
observances.description_1: Kushmanda Puja is the worship of Goddess Kushmanda on the fourth day of Chaitra Navratri.
observances.description_2:
Kushmanda Puja is performed on the fourth day of Chaitra Navratri, a Hindu festival dedicated to the worship of the goddess Durga and her nine forms, known as Navadurga. Kushmanda, the fourth form of Navadurga, is believed to be the creator of the universe.

According to legend, Goddess Parvati started living inside the center of the Sun so that He can liberate energy to the universe and came to be known as Goddess Kushmanda. The glow and radiance of her body is as luminous as that of the Sun.

She is depicted with eight hands. She has Kamandal, Dhanush, Bada and Kamal in the right hands and Amrit Kalash, Jap Mala, Gada and Chakra in the left hands. She rides a lion, symbolizing strength and courage.

observances.name: Skandamata Puja
observances.description_1: Skandamata Puja is the worship of Goddess Skandamata on the fifth day of Chaitra Navratri.
observances.description_2:
Skandamata Puja is performed on the fifth day of Chaitra Navratri, the nine-day Hindu festival dedicated to the worship of the goddess Durga and her nine forms, known as Navadurga. Skandamata, the fifth form of Navadurga, is worshipped as the mother of Lord Skanda (also known as Kartikeya), the god of war. Her name, "Skandamata," means "mother of Skanda."

According to Hindu mythology, Skanda (Kartikeya) was born to defeat the demon Tarakasura, who had become invincible. Skandamata nurtured and trained him, making him a powerful warrior who eventually killed Tarakasura and restored peace.

Goddess Skandamata is depicted seated on a lion, holding her son Skanda in her lap. She has four arms, with two hands holding lotuses, one hand holding Skanda, and the other hand in a blessing gesture.

observances.name: Lakshmi Panchami
observances.description_1: Lakshmi Panchami is dedicated to Goddess Lakshmi, the deity of wealth, prosperity, and good fortune.
observances.description_2:
Lakshmi Panchami is celebrated on the Panchami thiti of the Shukla Paksha month of Chaitra.Chaitra Shukla Panchami is also Kalpadi Tithi. As per Vedic division of time, this day relates to beginning of a Kalpa.

Lakshmi Panchami honors Goddess Lakshmi, who is revered as the goddess of wealth, prosperity, and abundance. She is also the consort of Lord Vishnu and plays a vital role in maintaining the balance of the universe.

Lakshmi Panchami falls during the first week of Hindu New Year. Worshipping Goddess Lakshmi at the beginning of the year is considered very auspicious. Devotees observe a day long fast and worship Goddess Lakshmi in homes and offices.

deities.title: Lakshmi
deities.description: Lakshmi is the goddess of wealth, fortune, and prosperity, both material and spiritual. She is the consort of Vishnu and is typically depicted with four arms, symbolizing the four goals of human life—dharma, artha, kama, and moksha. Lakshmi is celebrated during the festival of Diwali, when she is worshipped to invite wealth and happiness into homes.

observances.name: Yamuna Jayanti
observances.description_1: Yamuna Chhath marks the day when Goddess Yamuna descended on Earth.
observances.description_2:
Yamuna Chhath falls on the Shukla Paksha Shashthi in Chaitra masa during Chaitra Navratri. It is the birth anniversary of Goddess Yamuna. Yamuna Chhath is celebrated on the 6th day of Chaitra Navratri a 9 days festival.

Devi Yamuna is the consort of Bhagwan Krishna. Therefore, Yamuna Chhath is celebrated with great enthusiasm in Vrindavan and Mathura. Yamuna River is considered a holy river along with Ganga, Godavari, Brahmaputra and Saraswati. It is believed that taking a dip in the Yamuna river can purify the soul and get rid of sins committed.

observances.name: Sashti
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Kalaratri Puja
observances.description_1: Kalaratri Puja is the worship of Goddess Kalaratri on the seventh day of Chaitra Navratri.
observances.description_2:
Kalaratri Puja is performed on the seventh day of Chaitra Navratri, the nine-day Hindu festival dedicated to the worship of the goddess Durga and her nine forms, known as Navadurga. Kalaratri, the seventh form of Navadurga, is worshipped as the goddess of time and death. When the Goddess Parvati removed outer golden skin to kill demons named Shumbha and Nishumbha, She was known as Goddess Kalaratri. She is considered one of the fiercest forms of Durga, symbolizing the destructive aspect that removes darkness and evil.

Goddess Maha Gauri is depicted with a fair complexion, radiant like the moon. She has four arms, holding a trident and a damaru (small drum) in two hands, while her other two hands are in the Abhaya (fear-dispelling) and Varada (blessing) mudras. She rides a donkey, symbolizing humility.

Although the Goddess Kalaratri is the most ferocious form of Goddess Parvati, She blesses her devotees with Abhaya and Varada mudras. Because of her auspicious power within her fierce form Goddess Kalaratri is also known as Goddess Shubhankari

observances.name: Maha Gauri Puja
observances.description_1: Maha Gauri Puja is the worship of Goddess Maha Gauri on the eighth day of Navratri.
observances.description_2:
Maha Gauri Puja is performed on the eighth day of Navratri, the nine-day Hindu festival dedicated to the worship of the goddess Durga and her nine forms, known as Navadurga. Maha Gauri, the eighth form of Navadurga, is worshipped as the goddess of purity, serenity, and compassion. Her name, "Maha Gauri," means "extremely fair," symbolizing her radiant and pure form.

Goddess Maha Gauri is depicted with a fair complexion, radiant like the moon. She has four arms, holding a trident and a damaru (small drum) in two hands, while her other two hands are in the Abhaya (fear-dispelling) and Varada (blessing) mudras. She rides a white bull, symbolizing purity and righteousness.

Due to her fair complexion Goddess Mahagauri is compared with the conch, the moon and the white flower of Kunda. She adorns white clothes only and due to that She is also known as Shwetambardhara.

observances.name: Ashok Ashtami
observances.description_1: Ashok Ashtami is dedicated to Lord Shiva and Goddess Shakti. It commemorates the victory of Ram over Ravan.
observances.description_2:
Ashok Ashtami falls on the Astami, Shukla Paksha in Chaitra masa during the Chaitra Navratri festival.

When Ram was unable to defeat Ravana after many days of battle, he prayed to Goddess Shakti and Lord Shiva to seek their blessings. Blessed by them, he was able to defeat Ravana the very next day. Ram took out a procession on a chariot in honor of Shiv-Shakti to show his gratitude. Ashok Ashtami to mark the victory of Lord Ram over Ravana which signifies victory or goodness over evil.

Ashok Ashtami is celebrated with great fervour in Bhubaneswar, Odisha. A Rath Yatra is organized at the Lingaraj Temple.On this day, the Utsava Vigraha of Lingaraja, is taken out in a Ratha from the Lingaraj temple to Rameswara temple. The Ratha festival lasts for five-seven days. The Ratha is drawn by the devotees from the Lingaraj to Rameswara and starts its return journey on 5th day.

deities.title: Durga
deities.description: Goddess Durga is a major deity in Hinduism, worshipped as a principal aspect of the mother goddess Mahadevi. She was created by the combined energies of the gods Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, who infused their divine powers into her to combat the demon, Mahishasura. She is celebrated for her strength and  her role as a fierce warrior against evil and injustice. Durga is often depicted as a beautiful woman with ten arms, each holding a weapon or symbol. She rides a lion or tiger.

observances.name: Ram Navami
observances.description_1: Celebrating the birth of Lord Rama with devotion and reverence.
observances.description_2:
Lord Rama's birth on Navami Tithi of the Chaitra masa is celebrated annually as his birthday. Born during the auspicious Madhyahna period, which lasts for approximately 2 hours and 24 minutes, it is the ideal time for Rama Navami Puja rituals. Temples commemorate this moment as Rama's birth, with celebrations peaking between 11 a.m. and 1 p.m.

Despite the common misconception of 12 p.m. as the Madhyahna moment due to the Western clock, the actual timing falls between 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. across most Indian cities. Ayodhya, Rama's birthplace, hosts remarkable celebrations drawing devotees from far and wide, who take a holy dip in the Sarayu River before visiting the Rama temple. Fasting from sunrise to sunrise is recommended during Rama Navami.

deities.title: Rama
deities.description: Lord Rama is the seventh avatar of Vishnu, incarnated to defeat the demon king Ravana and restore dharma. He is one of the most revered deities in Hinduism. He embodies the ideals of virtue, duty, and kingly conduct, often referred to as Maryada Purushottama. His life and actions serve as a guide for ideal behavior in various roles - as a son, husband, brother, and king.

observances.name: Tara Jayanti
observances.description_1: Tara Jayanti celebrates the birth or appearance of Goddess Tara, one of the ten Mahavidya Goddesses.
observances.description_2:
Tara Jayanti celebrates Goddess Tara, a revered goddess of protection, compassion, and guidance. She represents the fierce yet protective aspect of the divine feminine.

One of the legends associated with Goddess Tara’s origin relates to the churning of the ocean of milk (Samudra Manthan). When the deadly poison (Halahala) emerged and threatened the universe, Lord Shiva drank it. To cool the poison and prevent it from harming Shiva, Goddess Tara appeared. She took Shiva on her lap and suckled him, neutralizing the poison with her nurturing and soothing presence.

Tara is often depicted as a dark-skinned, formidable goddess with a serene expression, symbolizing her dual nature of fierce protection and compassionate guidance. She is shown with a blue complexion, standing on a corpse, symbolizing her mastery over death and the material world.

observances.name: Swaminarayan Jayanti
observances.description_1: Swaminarayan Jayanti celebrates the birth anniversary of Swaminarayan.
observances.description_2:
Swaminarayan Jayanti coincides with Rama Navami. Swaminarayan also known as Sahajanand Swami, was a yogi and ascetic believed by followers to be a manifestation of Krishna, around whom the Swaminarayan Sampradaya developed.

On this day, devotees of the Swaminarayan Sampraday observe a nirjala fast. They gather at local mandirs, perform aarti at 10:10 pm, Bhagwan Swaminarayan’s birth hour, and sing bhajans celebrating the birth and arrival of Bhagwan’s child form.

observances.name: Kamada Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Kamada Ekadashi is a sacred Hindu fasting day in Chaitra, believed to fulfill desires and remove sins.
observances.description_2:
A sacred occasion that falls in the Shukla Paksha of Chaitra masa, Kamada Ekadashi is a powerful opportunity for spiritual growth and fulfilment.

The name "Kamada Ekadashi" suggests that observing this Ekadashi has the potential to fulfil even the deepest desires (Kamana). The fast is believed to have the power to remove obstacles, bring peace, and bestow the devotee with the divine grace of Lord Vishnu.

One can get rid of all types of sins by observing Kamada Ekadashi fasting.

Parana means breaking the fast. Ekadashi Parana is done after sunrise on the next day of Ekadashi fast. It is necessary to do Parana within Dwadashi Tithi unless Dwadashi is over before sunrise.

Sometimes, Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. Smartha (householders) with family are advised to fast on the first day only, while the alternate Ekadashi fasting is suggested for Sanyasis (renunciates), widows, and those seeking Moksha.

Fasting on both days is recommended for devoted seekers of Lord Vishnu's love and affection.

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Kamada Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Kamada Ekadashi is a sacred Hindu fasting day in Chaitra, believed to fulfill desires and remove sins.
observances.description_2:
A sacred occasion that falls in the Shukla Paksha of Chaitra masa, Kamada Ekadashi is a powerful opportunity for spiritual growth and fulfilment.

The name "Kamada Ekadashi" suggests that observing this Ekadashi has the potential to fulfil even the deepest desires (Kamana). The fast is believed to have the power to remove obstacles, bring peace, and bestow the devotee with the divine grace of Lord Vishnu.

One can get rid of all types of sins by observing Kamada Ekadashi fasting.

Parana means breaking the fast. Ekadashi Parana is done after sunrise on the next day of Ekadashi fast. It is necessary to do Parana within Dwadashi Tithi unless Dwadashi is over before sunrise.

Sometimes, Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. Smartha (householders) with family are advised to fast on the first day only, while the alternate Ekadashi fasting is suggested for Sanyasis (renunciates), widows, and those seeking Moksha.

Fasting on both days is recommended for devoted seekers of Lord Vishnu's love and affection.

observances.name: Mahavira Jayanti
observances.description_1: Mahavir Jayanti is observed by Jains as birth anniversary of sage Mahavir.
observances.description_2:
According to Jain scriptures, Lord Mahavira was born on Trayodashi of the Shukla paksha in Chaitra masa in Kundalagrama, now known as Kundalpur, Bihar, near Patna. This occurred during a time when Vaishali was the capital of the state. The year of Mahavira's birth is disputed, with the Swetambar Jains citing 599 BC and the Digambar Jains citing 615 BC. Mahavira, born to King Siddhartha and Queen Trisala, was initially named Vardhaman.

According to the Swetambar community's beliefs, Mahavira's mother had 14 auspicious dreams interpreted by astrologers, predicting his future as either an emperor or a sage (Tirthankara). At the age of 30, Mahavira renounced his throne and family in search of truth, spending 12 years as an ascetic preaching non-violence and treating all with reverence. He earned the name "Mahavira" for his exceptional control over his senses and attained enlightenment (Nirvana) at the age of 72.

During Mahavir Jayanti, the Jain community celebrates through various festivities, strengthening bonds with family and friends while honoring and worshipping Lord Mahavira. Central to the festival is the ceremonial washing of Mahavir's idol with fragrant oil, symbolizing purity.

The festival promotes peace, harmony, and the teachings of Lord Mahavira, exemplified through rituals like the "rath yatra" procession with his idol atop, temple decorations.

Mahavir Jayanti is a Jain festival celebrated predominantly in Jain temples, providing an opportunity for devotees to immerse themselves in the essence of Jainism and the teachings of Lord Mahavira.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Hanuman Jayanti
observances.description_1: Hanuman Jayanti commemorates the birth of Lord Hanuman, known for his strength, devotion, and loyalty.
observances.description_2:
Hanuman Jayanti is a festival dedicated to the birth of Lord Hanuman, Celebrated on Purnima of the Chaitra masa, the festival holds significant religious importance for devotees across India.

Lord Hanuman is revered for his unwavering loyalty to Lord Rama and his extraordinary strength, symbolizing courage, selfless service, and devotion.
Join the recitation of the Hanuman Chalisa, and be inspired by the timeless story of devotion and service.

deities.title: Hanuman
deities.description: Hanuman is revered as the epitome of devotion and selfless service. Known as the son of the wind god Vayu, Hanuman is a symbol of strength, valor, and celibate devotion. He is celebrated for his unwavering dedication to Lord Rama and played a crucial role in the battle against the demon king Ravana. Hanuman is also worshipped as a protector and is believed to grant courage and fortitude to his devotees.

observances.name: Purnima
observances.description_1: Purnima, signifies the full moon day, often marked by religious ceremonies and spiritual observances.
observances.description_2:
Purnima, or the Full Moon day, is a significant occasion in Indian culture, occurring monthly as the moon reaches its maximum brightness.

Purnima fasting is observed either on the Purnima day itself or the day before, known as Chaturdashi, depending on the timing of the Purnima Tithi (lunar day) from the previous day.

Purnima fasting on Chaturdashi occurs only when the Purnima begins during the Madhyahna period on the previous day. If Chaturdashi extends beyond Madhyahna, it's considered impure for Purnima fasting, even if Purnima begins later in the evening.

In North India, the full moon day is called Purnima, while in South India, it's referred to as Pournami or Pournima, and fasting on this day is known as Pournami Vratam, observed from sunrise until the moon is sighted.

observances.name: Puthandu
observances.description_1: Tamil New Year with cultural festivities, traditional rituals, and festive gatherings.
observances.description_2:
This day is celebrated as the first day of the Tamil month, Chitterai as the Tamil new year. According to the Tamil calendar, the Sankranti occurs after sunrise and before sunset, the day is celebrated as the New Year's Day but if Sankranti occurs after sunset, the next day is celebrated as Puthundu.

People clean their homes, wear new clothes, and prepare a special dish called "Maanga Pachadi," made from raw mangoes, neem flowers, jaggery, and other ingredients, symbolizing the mixture of emotions in life.

Puthandu is a time for new beginnings and is celebrated with great joy and enthusiasm. It is a time for families and friends to come together and celebrate the new year.

deities.title: Lakshmi
deities.description: Lakshmi is the goddess of wealth, fortune, and prosperity, both material and spiritual. She is the consort of Vishnu and is typically depicted with four arms, symbolizing the four goals of human life—dharma, artha, kama, and moksha. Lakshmi is celebrated during the festival of Diwali, when she is worshipped to invite wealth and happiness into homes.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

observances.name: Vishu
observances.description_1: Radiant dawn of Malayalam New Year.
observances.description_2:
Vishu is a festival that celebrates the Malayali New Year in Kerala, Tulu Nadu, and Mahe of India. It is celebrated on the first day of the Malayalam month of Medam, which is usually in April. The date of Vishu varies each year depending on the position of the sun.

Vishu celebrates the vernal equinox when day and night are roughly equal in length. It marks the beginning of the new agricultural season and is a celebration of harvest as well as togetherness

The day of Vishu begins with the Vishukkani, which is a ritual of seeing auspicious items first thing in the morning. The Vishukkani is typically arranged in a vessel called an urali and it includes items such as rice, gold, money, a mirror, flowers, and fruits.

After the Vishukkani, people visit temples to offer prayers. They also visit their elders and relatives to seek their blessings.

In the afternoon, people enjoy a special feast called the Vishu Sadhya. The Vishu Sadhya is a vegetarian feast that consists of several dishes, including rice, sambar, rasam, aviyal, and payasam.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

deities.title: Surya
deities.description: Surya is the god of the sun, symbolizing light, life, and the dispeller of darkness. As the source of all life, Surya is considered a creator and a vital deity. He is often depicted riding a chariot drawn by seven horses, representing the seven colors of the rainbow or the seven chakras in the body, driven by his charioteer, Aruna. Surya is worshipped daily in many Hindu households, especially during the Surya Namaskar (sun salutation) yoga practice, which enhances vitality and improves health.

observances.name: Pana Sankranti
observances.description_1: Celebrating the arrival of Odia's new year with traditional festivities.
observances.description_2:
Pana Sankranti, also known as Maha Bishuba Sankranti, is a traditional festival celebrated by the Odia people. It is the New Year celebration for the Odia people and is celebrated on the first day of the traditional solar month of Mesa.

Pana Sankranti holds cultural and agricultural significance. It coincides with the end of the harvest season. The festival represents a time of gratitude for the bountiful crops and a hopeful start to a new agricultural cycle.

A central ritual involves the preparation and distribution of "Pana," a sweet concoction made with raw mango, jaggery, coconut, and water. The sharing of Pana symbolizes the sweetness of life and fosters a sense of community. Many individuals embark on the Jhamu Yatra, a procession where devotees carry water pots and visit various shrines, singing devotional songs.

observances.name: Baisakhi
observances.description_1: Marking the Sikh New Year and the spring harvest season, and commemorating the formation of the Khalsa Panth by Guru Gobind Singh in 1699
observances.description_2:
Baisakhi, also known as Vaisakhi or Basoa, is a spring festival. It marks the beginning of the month of Vaisakh and is the Sikh solar new year.

For the Sikh community, Baisakhi carries profound religious significance. It commemorates the day in 1699 when Guru Gobind Singh, the tenth Sikh Guru, established the Khalsa Panth, a community of initiated Sikhs.

Baisakhi festivities commence with religious processions, Nagar Kirtans, and visits to gurdwaras. The Golden Temple in Amritsar, Punjab, witnesses an influx of devotees. Sikhs offer prayers, listen to hymns, and partake in community meals called Langar. The vibrant Baisakhi fairs feature cultural performances, folk music, and traditional food, creating an atmosphere of jubilation.

deities.title: Surya
deities.description: Surya is the god of the sun, symbolizing light, life, and the dispeller of darkness. As the source of all life, Surya is considered a creator and a vital deity. He is often depicted riding a chariot drawn by seven horses, representing the seven colors of the rainbow or the seven chakras in the body, driven by his charioteer, Aruna. Surya is worshipped daily in many Hindu households, especially during the Surya Namaskar (sun salutation) yoga practice, which enhances vitality and improves health.

deities.title: Ganga
deities.description: Goddess Ganga, is the personification of the sacred River Ganga. She is believed to have descended from the heavens to Earth, through the efforts of King Bhagiratha, to cleanse the souls of his ancestors and relieve them from a curse. She is seen as a divine purifier, capable of washing away sins and providing salvation to those who bathe in her sacred waters or have their ashes immersed in the river.

observances.name: Masik Sankranti
observances.description_1: Masik Sankranti marks the transition of the Sun into a new zodiac sign each month, observed with spiritual significance.
observances.description_2:
Sankranti refers to the transmigration of the sun from one rashi (zodiac) to another in Indian astronomy
The observance revolves around sun’s transition into new rashi (zodiac sign), symoblizing the end of one solar month and the beginning of another.

Malik Sankranti’s including the Makara Sankranthi is associated with Surya pravesh (Sun’s entry) into each rashi. There are twelve rashis (12 signs) namely Mekh (Mekha), Virkh, Mithun, Kark, Singh-Simha, Kanya, Tula,Vrischik, Dhan, Makara, Kumbh and Meena.

While significance and rituals may vary for each Masik Sankranti, they are generally considered as times to offer prayers, seek blessings and make positive changes in one’s life.

Sankranti days are considered good for charity activities and all auspicious ceremonies are avoided on the day of Sankranti(s).

observances.name: Pohela Boishakh
observances.description_1: A colourful commencement of the Bengali New Year.
observances.description_2:
Pohela Boishakh, also known as Bengali New Year, is a festival observed in the Bengali community, particularly in West Bengal, Bangladesh, and among the Bengali diaspora around the world.

This joyful occasion usually takes place in mid-April, marking the first day of the Bengali calendar. King Shoshangko of ancient Bengal is credited with starting the Bengali era. The starting point of the Bengali era is estimated to be in 594 in the Gregorian calendar. Hence Bengali year is 594 less than the Gregorian calendar if it is before Pohela Boishakh or 593 less if it is after Pohela Boishakh.

It's a day of joy, feasting, and cultural performances, with the highlight being the "Poila Boishakh" traditional breakfast, featuring dishes like "panta bhat" (fermented rice), "ilish maach" (hilsa fish), and sweets like "roshogolla" and "sandesh." The exchange of "Haal Khata" (new financial ledgers) among businesses signifies the start of a prosperous year.

deities.title: Lakshmi
deities.description: Lakshmi is the goddess of wealth, fortune, and prosperity, both material and spiritual. She is the consort of Vishnu and is typically depicted with four arms, symbolizing the four goals of human life—dharma, artha, kama, and moksha. Lakshmi is celebrated during the festival of Diwali, when she is worshipped to invite wealth and happiness into homes.

deities.title: Ganesha
deities.description: Ganesha is the elephant-headed deity known as the remover of obstacles and the lord of beginnings. Son of Shiva and Parvati, he is commonly depicted with a broken tusk and riding a mouse. Ganesha is revered for his wisdom and is often invoked first in Hindu rituals to ensure success and clear obstacles. He also symbolizes the patronage of arts and sciences.

observances.name: Sankasta Chaturthi
observances.description_1: Sankashti Chaturthi is a significant day for Lord Ganesha devotees, observed to seek his blessings and overcome obstacles.
observances.description_2:
In the Hindu calendar, each lunar month includes two Chaturthi Tithi. The one following the full moon, known as Purnimasi, during Krishna Paksha is called Sankashti Chaturthi, while the one following the new moon, known as Amavasya, during Shukla Paksha is called Vinayaka Chaturthi.

If Sankashti Chaturthi falls on a Tuesday, it is revered as Angarki Chaturthi, considered highly auspicious, particularly in Western and Southern India, notably Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu.

During Sankashti Chaturthi, devotees of Lord Ganesha observe a fast from sunrise to moonrise. Sankashti, meaning deliverance during troubled times, signifies the belief that observing this fast can remove obstacles, as Lord Ganesha is revered as the remover of obstacles.

The fast is observed strictly, with consumption limited to fruits, roots, and vegetable products. Typical foods include Sabudana Khichadi, potatoes, and peanuts, with devotees breaking their fast after sighting the moon.

In North India, Sankashti Chaturthi in the month of Magha is known as Sakat Chauth, while Vinayaka Chaturthi in the month of Bhadrapada is celebrated as Ganesha Chaturthi worldwide as Lord Ganesha's birthday.

Among Tamil Hindus, Sankashti Chaturthi is referred to as Ganesh Sankatahara or Sankatahara Chaturthi.

observances.name: Vallabha Acharya Jayanti
observances.description_1: Vallabha Acharya Jayanti is the birth anniversary of Shri Vallabha Acharya, a saint and philosopher.
observances.description_2:
Vallabha Acharya Jayanti falls on the ekadashi of Krishna Paksha in the month of Vaishakha and coincides with Varuthini Ekadashi.

Shri Vallabhacharya (1479-1531 C.E.) was a prominent philosopher and saint. He was the founder of the Pushti Marg sect. This day is celebrated with great devotion by his followers, particularly within the Vaishnavism tradition.

Vallabha Acharya is best known for establishing the Pushti Marg (Path of Grace), which emphasizes the worship of Lord Krishna and devotion through love and grace rather than rituals. He is renowned for his philosophical work, particularly the concept of Shuddhadvaita (Pure Non-Dualism), which articulates a unique understanding of the relationship between the individual soul and the divine.

observances.name: Varuthini Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Varuthini Ekadashi is a fasting day dedicated to Lord Vishnu, observed for spiritual purification and the removal of sins.
observances.description_2:
Varuthini Ekadashi is a fasting day dedicated to Lord Vishnu, celebrated on the Ekadashi of the Krishna Paksha in Vaishakha masa. The term "Varuthini" signifies "protected" or "armored," reflecting the belief that observing this Ekadashi with devotion provides divine protection and blessings.

On Varuthini Ekadashi, devotees observe a strict fast, abstaining from food from sunrise to the next day's sunrise. The fast is often broken the next day after offering prayers to Lord Vishnu. Some devotees may follow a partial fast, consuming only fruits and milk.

In various Hindu texts, the significance of Varuthini Ekadashi is highlighted through stories and legends. One popular legend is about King Mandata, who was freed from a curse and attained salvation by observing Varuthini Ekadashi.

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Varuthini Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Varuthini Ekadashi is a fasting day dedicated to Lord Vishnu, observed for spiritual purification and the removal of sins.
observances.description_2:
Varuthini Ekadashi is a fasting day dedicated to Lord Vishnu, celebrated on the Ekadashi of the Krishna Paksha in Vaishakha masa. The term "Varuthini" signifies "protected" or "armored," reflecting the belief that observing this Ekadashi with devotion provides divine protection and blessings.

On Varuthini Ekadashi, devotees observe a strict fast, abstaining from food from sunrise to the next day's sunrise. The fast is often broken the next day after offering prayers to Lord Vishnu. Some devotees may follow a partial fast, consuming only fruits and milk.

In various Hindu texts, the significance of Varuthini Ekadashi is highlighted through stories and legends. One popular legend is about King Mandata, who was freed from a curse and attained salvation by observing Varuthini Ekadashi.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: Parashurama Jayanti
observances.description_1: Parashurama Jayanti is celebrated as birth anniversary of sixth incarnation of Lord Vishnu.
observances.description_2:
Parashurama Jayanti marks the birth anniversary of the sixth incarnation of Lord Vishnu, celebrated Tritiya Shukla Paksha of the Vaishakha masa. Tradition holds that Parashurama was born during Pradosh Kala, hence his Jayanti is observed when Tritiya coincides with this period. Parashurama's purpose as an avatar was to alleviate the Earth's burden by eliminating corrupt and neglectful rulers.

Unlike other avatars of Lord Vishnu, Parashurama is believed to still reside on Earth and is not worshipped like Rama or Krishna. However, in South India, particularly near Udupi in Pajaka, a significant temple commemorates him. Numerous temples along the western coast of India are also dedicated to Lord Parashurama.

According to the Kalki Purana, Parashurama will serve as the martial teacher of Shri Kalki, the tenth and final avatar of Lord Vishnu. This meeting between the sixth and tenth avatars is not unprecedented; according to the Ramayana, Parashurama attended the betrothal ceremony of Sita and Lord Rama, encountering the seventh avatar of Lord Vishnu.

observances.name: Akshaya Tritiya
observances.description_1: Festival of everlasting prosperity and gold-buying tradition in Hindu and Jain communities.
observances.description_2:
Akshaya Tritiya, also known as Akha Teej or Akti, is a significant festival celebrated by Hindus and Jains across India. It falls on the Tritiya of the Shukla Paksha in Vaishakha masa.

The word Akshaya means never diminishing. Hence the benefits of doing any Japa, Yajna, Pitra-Tarpan, Dan-Punya on this day never diminish and remain with the person forever.

Akshaya Tritiya is believed to bring good luck and success. Most people purchase Gold on this day as it is believed that buying Gold on Akshaya Tritiya brings prosperity and more wealth in the coming future. Being Akshaya day it is believed that Gold, bought on this day, will never diminish and will continue to grow or appreciate.

Akshaya Tritiya day is ruled by God Vishnu who is the preserver God in the Hindu Trinity. According to Hindu mythology, Treta Yuga began on Akshaya Tritiya day. Usually, Akshaya Tritiya and Parashurama Jayanti, the birthday anniversary of the 6th incarnation of Lord Vishnu, fall on the same day but depending on the starting time of Tritiya Tithi Parashurama Jayanti might fall one day before Akshaya Tritiya day.

observances.name: Matangi Jayanti
observances.description_1: Matangi Jayanti is dedicated to the worship of Goddess Matangi, one of the ten Mahavidya Goddesses.
observances.description_2:
Matangi Jayanti celebrates Goddess Matangi , a revered goddess of speech, music, knowledge and the arts also known as Tantric Saraswati.

According to mythology, Matangi emerged from the leftover food (Ucchishta) of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati. This food was considered impure, and Matangi is associated with pollution and impurity.

Goddess Matangi is often depicted as a beautiful goddess with an emerald green complexion, adorned with jewelry and clothes that symbolize her connection to nature and the arts. She is depicted with four arms in which She holds a noose, sword, goad and a club. She is usually shown playing a veena, highlighting her association with music and learning. She is sometimes depicted with a parrot, which symbolizes the power of speech and communication.

observances.name: Basava Jayanti
observances.description_1: Basava Jayanti celebrates the birth anniversary of Basavanna, a revered philosopher and social reformer in Karnataka, India.
observances.description_2:
Basava Jayanti is a Hindu festival that commemorates the birth anniversary of Basavanna, a revered 12th-century philosopher, poet, and social reformer. Basavanna emphasized social equality, human rights, and the abolition of the caste system. Celebrated primarily in Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh, Basava Jayanti features rituals such as reading Basavanna's vachanas (poems), processions, and special prayers, highlighting his profound teachings on social justice and equality.

Basava Jayanti is celebrated with enthusiasm, with devotees visiting Lord Basaveshwar temples to offer prayers, particularly farmers who hold special reverence for the occasion. Lingayat committees organize various events across Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Andhra Pradesh, including cultural and spiritual gatherings. Kudalasangama emerges as a popular destination during Basava Jayanti, hosting a range of festivities over a week-long period.

observances.name: Adi Shankara Jayanti
observances.description_1: Adi Shankara Jayanti commemorates the birth anniversary of Adi Shankaracharya, a revered philosopher and theologian in Hinduism.
observances.description_2:
Adi Shankaracharya Jayanti commemorates the birth anniversary of the revered Indian Guru and philosopher, Adi Shankara. Born in 788 C.E. in Kalady, Kerala, he departed at the young age of 32 in 820 C.E.

This observance falls on Panchami Tithi during the Shukla Paksha of the Vaishakha masa. Adi Shankaracharya is renowned for revitalizing Hindu culture during a period of decline, particularly through his consolidation of the doctrine of Advaita Vedanta.

Alongside Madhava and Ramanuja, Adi Shankara played a pivotal role in the resurgence of Hinduism. These three luminaries crafted doctrines that continue to guide their respective sects today, making them integral figures in the recent history of Hindu philosophy.

observances.name: Surdas Jayanti
observances.description_1: Surdas Jayanti commemorates the birth anniversary of the great poet and saint Surdas.
observances.description_2:
Surdas Jayanti is observed on Panchami thiti of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Vaishakha. Surdas was born on this day as per the Hindu calendar.

Surdas (1478-1581 C.E.) was born blind, but he started to compose and sing about the life and deeds of Lord Krishna at an young age. He is said to have written a hundred thousand songs in Sur Sagar, out of which only about 8,000 have survived. As he became more famous, the Mughal emperor Akbar became his patron. He spent the last years of his life in Braj.

Surdas Jayanti is celebrated with great devotion, particularly in North India, where Surdas's contributions to the Bhakti movement and Indian devotional music and literature are highly esteemed.

observances.name: Ramanujacharya Jayanti
observances.description_1: Ramanujacharya Jayanti celebrates the birth anniversary of the revered Hindu Scholar and philosopher Ramanujacharya, revered for his contributions to Vaishnavism and philosophy.
observances.description_2:
Ramanujacharya Jayanti honors the birth anniversary of Ramanuja, a revered philosopher and thinker known for his devotion to Vaishnavism. He served as a priest at the Vardharaja Perumal Temple, dedicated to Lord Vishnu, and advocated the path of Bhakti for spiritual liberation.

It falls on Panchami Tithi of Shukla Paksha in Vaishakha masam under Thiruvathirai Nakshatra, holding special significance among South Indian communities.

Ramanuja, born as Lakshamana in Sriperumbudur, Tamil Nadu in 1017 CE, departed from mortal existence in 1137 CE at Srirangamin. He devoted his life to Lord Vishnu, following the Vaishnavism tradition, and championed Bhakti as a means to spiritual enlightenment. Becoming a monk, he established temples and spread the worship of Lord Vishnu and Mahalakshmi.

Studying Advaita Vedanta in Kanchipuram, Ramanuja developed distinct teachings diverging from his Guru Yadava Prakasa. He served as a priest at the Vardharaja Perumal Temple, disseminating Bhakti teachings and guiding followers on the path to salvation through devotion to God.

Ramanuja staunchly opposed caste discrimination and supported Vaishnavism and the Bhakti movement, advocating for social equality. He authored significant works including the Vedartha Sangraha, Sri Bhashya, and Bhagwat Gita Bhashya, which expounded his philosophical insights and spiritual teachings.

observances.name: Sashti
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Sita Jayanti
observances.description_1: Sita Jayanti celebrates the birth of Goddess Sita, an incarnation of Goddess Lakshmi.
observances.description_2:
Sita Jayanti is celebrated on Navami Tithi during Shukla Paksha of Vaishakha month. Goddess Sita was married to Lord Rama who was also born on Navami Tithi during Shukla Paksha of Chaitra month. On Hindu calendar Sita Jayanti falls one month after Rama Navami.

According to the Ramayana, Sita was found in a furrow in a plowed field by King Janaka of Mithila, who adopted her as his daughter. She is believed to be an incarnation of Goddess Lakshmi, born to accompany Lord Rama, an incarnation of Lord Vishnu, in his earthly journey.

Devotees perform special pujas (rituals) dedicated to Goddess Sita. Passages from the Ramayana, especially those that narrate the life and virtues of Sita, are read and recited.

deities.title: Shri Sita
deities.description: Goddess Sita is an incarnation of Goddess Lakshmi, the consort of Lord Vishnu, and is worshipped as a deity embodying purity, devotion, and strength. Her life, as depicted in the epic Ramayana, exemplifies ideal womanhood, virtue, and unwavering faith, making her a symbol of fidelity and resilience. Worshipped alongside Lord Rama, Sita is often depicted seated beside him, showcasing her integral role in the divine couple's balance of dharma (righteousness) and karma (duty).

observances.name: Baglamukhi Jayanti
observances.description_1: Baglamukhi Jayanti is dedicated to the worship of Goddess Baglamukhi, one of the ten Mahavidya Goddesses.
observances.description_2:
Baglamukhi Jayanti celebrates Goddess Baglamukhi , a fierce deity who paralyzes and immobilizes the enemies of her devotees. The word 'Bagala' is derived from the Sanskrit word 'Valga' which means bridle.

In the Satya Yuga , a great storm threatened to destroy creation. The Gods prayed to appease the Goddess Parvati on shore of Haridra Sarovar. Pleased, the Goddess manifested in the form of Bagalamukhi from the lake. She calmed the storm, restoring order in the universe.

Bagalamukhi is strongly associated with yellow . She dresses in yellow clothes and ornaments. She has a golden complexion and sits on a golden throne in the midst of an ocean of nectar full of yellow lotuses with a crescent moon on her head. She has two arms. She holds a club in her right hand and pulls the tongue of a demon with her left hand. This is interpreted as Stambhana, the power to paralyze an enemy into silence.

observances.name: Thrissur Pooram
observances.description_1: Thrissur Pooram, a grand festival in Kerala, is renowned for its spectacular procession of beautifully decorated elephants.
observances.description_2:
Thrissur Pooram, known as the mother of all poorams, is a vibrant festival celebrated in the Vadakunnathan temple in Thrissur, Kerala during April-May. Started by Shakthan Thampuran, the ruler of the Kingdom of Cochin. It attracts devotees from all over the world who witness the night-long fireworks, colourful Kudamottam, and famous elephant procession

It takes place on the Pooram day, which is when the moon rises with the Pooram star in the Malayalam calendar month of Medam.

The festival is a gathering of suburban deities before the presiding deity at the Vadakkumnathan temple.

The main attraction of the festival is the Kudamattam ritual, which features caparisoned elephants and their handlers performing. The ceremonial procession of the elephants decorated with golden nettipattam (headgear), peacock feathers, and white tufts carrying the deity is the soul of pooram.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Mohini Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Mohini Ekadashi honours the divine role of Lord Vishnu as Mohini.
observances.description_2:
Celebrated by Hindus across India. In the form of Mohini, Lord Vishnu disguised himself to take the Amrit from Asuras and give it to the Devas. The day when Lord Vishnu took the form of Mohini is known as Mohini Ekadashi.

It falls on the 11th day of the Shukla Paksha in Vaisakha masa.
Devotees believe that observing a fast on Mohini Ekadashi helps purify the mind, body, and soul.

Parana means breaking the fast. Ekadashi Parana is done after sunrise on the next day of Ekadashi fast. It is necessary to do Parana within Dwadashi Tithi unless Dwadashi is over before sunrise.

Sometimes, Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. Smartha (householders) with family are advised to fast on the first day only, while the alternate Ekadashi fasting is suggested for Sanyasis (renunciates), widows, and those seeking Moksha.

Fasting on both days is recommended for devoted seekers of Lord Vishnu's love and affection.

observances.name: Mohini Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Mohini Ekadashi honours the divine role of Lord Vishnu as Mohini.
observances.description_2:
Celebrated by Hindus across India. In the form of Mohini, Lord Vishnu disguised himself to take the Amrit from Asuras and give it to the Devas. The day when Lord Vishnu took the form of Mohini is known as Mohini Ekadashi.

It falls on the 11th day of the Shukla Paksha in Vaisakha masa.
Devotees believe that observing a fast on Mohini Ekadashi helps purify the mind, body, and soul.

Parana means breaking the fast. Ekadashi Parana is done after sunrise on the next day of Ekadashi fast. It is necessary to do Parana within Dwadashi Tithi unless Dwadashi is over before sunrise.

Sometimes, Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. Smartha (householders) with family are advised to fast on the first day only, while the alternate Ekadashi fasting is suggested for Sanyasis (renunciates), widows, and those seeking Moksha.

Fasting on both days is recommended for devoted seekers of Lord Vishnu's love and affection.

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Rabindranath Tagore Jayanti
observances.description_1: Rabindra Jayanti celebrates the birth anniversary of the great poet, Rabindranath Tagore.
observances.description_2:
Rabindranath Tagore Jayanti falls on May 7 as per Gregorian calendar, but It is celebrated on the 25th day of the Bengali month of Boishakh as Tagore was born on this day.

Rabindranath Tagore was a Bengali poet, writer, playwright, composer, philosopher, social reformer, and painter. He was the first non-European to win the Nobel Prize in Literature.

Rabindranath Tagore Jayanti is an annual cultural festival honoring him on his birth anniversary. Every year, numerous cultural events are organized which feature songs , poetries, and dramas, written and composed by Tagore, , by various schools, colleges and universities in Bengal, and is also celebrated by different groups abroad, as a tribute to Tagore and his works.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Narasimha jayanti
observances.description_1: Narasimha Jayanti marks the appearance of Lord Vishnu in the form of Narasimha, a half lion and half man, to kill the demon Hiranyakashipu.
observances.description_2:
Narasimha Jayanti is celebrated on the Chaturdasi thiti of the Shukla paksha in the month of Vaishakha. Lord Vishnu took the Narashima avatar to save his devotee Prahalada from his own father, the demon king, Hiranyakashipu.

The combination of Vaishakha Shukla Chaturdashi with Swati Nakshatra and weekday Saturday is considered highly auspicious to observe Narasimha Jayanti Vratam.

The rules and guidelines to observe Narasimha Jayanti fasting are similar to those of Ekadashi fasting. Devotees eat only single meal one day before Narasimha Jayanti. All type of grains and cereals are prohibited during Narasimha Jayanti fasting. Parana, which means breaking the fast, is done next day at an appropriate time.

deities.title: Narasimha
deities.description: Lord Narasimha is a fierce avatar of Vishnu, embodying a half-lion, half-man form, who is revered for his protection of devotees and the destruction of evil, most famously demonstrated in his slaying of the demon king Hiranyakashipu.

observances.name: Chinnamasta Jayanti
observances.description_1: Chinnamasta Jayanti is dedicated to the worship of Goddess Chinnamasta , one of the ten Mahavidya Goddesses.
observances.description_2:
Chinnamasta Jayanti celebrates Goddess Chinnamasta, a self-decapitated Goddess known as Prachanda Chandika. She represents the fierce and self-sacrificing aspect of the divine feminine.
Chinnamasta emerged from the goddess Parvati. One day, Parvati went to bathe in the Mandakini River with her attendants, Dakini and Varnini After bathing, the attendants felt extreme hunger and asked Parvati for food. Despite Parvati’s assurances that they would be fed soon, the hunger grew unbearable.In a moment of intense compassion and self-sacrifice, Parvati transformed into Chinnamasta. She severed her own head and held it in her left hand. Three streams of blood gushed from her neck. The two attendants drank the blood from the streams on either side, while Chinnamasta’s own mouth consumed the central stream.

Goddess Chinnamasta is depicted as a headless Goddess holding her own severed head in one hand a scimitar in the other hand. Three jets of blood spurt out of her bleeding neck and are drunk by her severed head and two female attendants. She is depicted standing on a copulating couple. Her complexion is red and she is depicted nude and with disheveled hair.

observances.name: Buddha Purnima
observances.description_1: Commemorating the birth and enlightenment of lord Buddha with devotional observances.
observances.description_2:
Buddha Purnima commemorates the birth anniversary of Gautam Buddha. This festival is celebrated by Buddhists both in India and worldwide, also known as "Buddha Jayanti'. It is celebrated on Purnima of the Vaisakha masa in the Buddhist calendar.

Gautama Buddha, whose birth name was Siddhartha Gautama, showed a path away from suffering to the whole mankind. The time of Gautama Buddha's birth and death is uncertain. However, most historians date his lifetime between 563-483 B.C.

Bodh Gaya holds unparalleled significance as the site where Gautama Buddha attained enlightenment. Alongside Bodh Gaya, the three other key pilgrimage locations in Buddha's life include Kushinagar, Lumbini, and Sarnath. Lumbini, located in Nepal, is revered as Buddha's birthplace. Buddha passed away at the age of 80 in Kushinagar, Uttar Pradesh, India. It is at Bodh Gaya that Buddha is believed to have achieved enlightenment, and Sarnath is where he first imparted his teachings, known as the Dharma.

It is believed that Gautama Buddha obtained Enlightenment on this day. Buddha Purnima is also known as Buddha Jayanti, Vesak, Vaishaka and Buddha's Birthday.

observances.name: Kurma Jayanti
observances.description_1: Kurma Jayanti is the birth anniversary of Lord Vishnu as Kurma, the second incarnation of Lord Vishnu.
observances.description_2:
Kurma Jayanti is observed on the Purnima (full moon day) in the Shukla Paksha in the month of Vaishakha.Lord Kurma, the tortoise incarnation of Vishnu, is one of the ten principal avatars (Dashavatara) of Vishnu. This avatar is particularly significant for its role in the churning of the ocean (Samudra Manthan), a pivotal event in Hindu mythology.

According to the legend, the devas (gods) and asuras (demons) collaborated to churn the ocean of milk to obtain Amrita, the nectar of immortality. Lord Vishnu, in the form of a giant tortoise (Kurma), supported Mount Mandara on his back to serve as the churning rod, while the serpent Vasuki acted as the churning rope. This event led to the emergence of various divine treasures and beings, including the goddess Lakshmi.

On this day, temples dedicated to Lord Vishnu, especially those associated with the Kurma avatar, organize special events and poojas.

observances.name: Purnima
observances.description_1: Purnima, signifies the full moon day, often marked by religious ceremonies and spiritual observances.
observances.description_2:
Purnima, or the Full Moon day, is a significant occasion in Indian culture, occurring monthly as the moon reaches its maximum brightness.

Purnima fasting is observed either on the Purnima day itself or the day before, known as Chaturdashi, depending on the timing of the Purnima Tithi (lunar day) from the previous day.

Purnima fasting on Chaturdashi occurs only when the Purnima begins during the Madhyahna period on the previous day. If Chaturdashi extends beyond Madhyahna, it's considered impure for Purnima fasting, even if Purnima begins later in the evening.

In North India, the full moon day is called Purnima, while in South India, it's referred to as Pournami or Pournima, and fasting on this day is known as Pournami Vratam, observed from sunrise until the moon is sighted.

observances.name: Narada Jayanti
observances.description_1: Narada Jayanti celebrates the birth anniversary of Narada Muni, a revered sage and celestial musician known for his devotion to Lord Vishnu and his role as a messenger between the gods and humans.
observances.description_2:
Narada Jayanti is a festival commemorating Narada Muni, a revered sage and celestial musician in Hindu mythology. Narada Muni is known for his devotion to Lord Vishnu and his role as a messenger between the gods and humans. He is often depicted carrying a veena (stringed musical instrument) and singing the glories of the divine.

According to Hindu scriptures, Narada Muni is considered one of the greatest devotees of Lord Vishnu and plays a pivotal role in disseminating spiritual knowledge and wisdom. His teachings, known as Narada Bhakti Sutra, emphasize the path of devotion (bhakti) as the supreme means of attaining liberation.

The festival is marked by recitations of stories and teachings associated with Narada Muni, highlighting his role as a divine messenger and spiritual guide.

observances.name: Masik Sankranti
observances.description_1: Masik Sankranti marks the transition of the Sun into a new zodiac sign each month, observed with spiritual significance.
observances.description_2:
Sankranti refers to the transmigration of the sun from one rashi (zodiac) to another in Indian astronomy
The observance revolves around sun’s transition into new rashi (zodiac sign), symoblizing the end of one solar month and the beginning of another.

Malik Sankranti’s including the Makara Sankranthi is associated with Surya pravesh (Sun’s entry) into each rashi. There are twelve rashis (12 signs) namely Mekh (Mekha), Virkh, Mithun, Kark, Singh-Simha, Kanya, Tula,Vrischik, Dhan, Makara, Kumbh and Meena.

While significance and rituals may vary for each Masik Sankranti, they are generally considered as times to offer prayers, seek blessings and make positive changes in one’s life.

Sankranti days are considered good for charity activities and all auspicious ceremonies are avoided on the day of Sankranti(s).

observances.name: Sankasta Chaturthi
observances.description_1: Sankashti Chaturthi is a significant day for Lord Ganesha devotees, observed to seek his blessings and overcome obstacles.
observances.description_2:
In the Hindu calendar, each lunar month includes two Chaturthi Tithi. The one following the full moon, known as Purnimasi, during Krishna Paksha is called Sankashti Chaturthi, while the one following the new moon, known as Amavasya, during Shukla Paksha is called Vinayaka Chaturthi.

If Sankashti Chaturthi falls on a Tuesday, it is revered as Angarki Chaturthi, considered highly auspicious, particularly in Western and Southern India, notably Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu.

During Sankashti Chaturthi, devotees of Lord Ganesha observe a fast from sunrise to moonrise. Sankashti, meaning deliverance during troubled times, signifies the belief that observing this fast can remove obstacles, as Lord Ganesha is revered as the remover of obstacles.

The fast is observed strictly, with consumption limited to fruits, roots, and vegetable products. Typical foods include Sabudana Khichadi, potatoes, and peanuts, with devotees breaking their fast after sighting the moon.

In North India, Sankashti Chaturthi in the month of Magha is known as Sakat Chauth, while Vinayaka Chaturthi in the month of Bhadrapada is celebrated as Ganesha Chaturthi worldwide as Lord Ganesha's birthday.

Among Tamil Hindus, Sankashti Chaturthi is referred to as Ganesh Sankatahara or Sankatahara Chaturthi.

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Apara Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Vat Savitri
observances.description_1: Festival honouring the bond between husbands and wives.
observances.description_2:
Vat Savitri, is a Hindu celebration observed by married women in Nepal and North Indian states

It falls on the Krishna Paksha Amavasya in the Hindu month of Jyeshtha masa.

On Vat Savitri, married women observe a fast and offer prayers to the banyan tree, Vat Vriksha, to honour the Goddess Savitri. The fast is a commemoration of Savitri's act of rescuing her husband, Satyavan, from the god of death.

Married women circle the banyan tree seven times with a yellow-red thread while praying for their husband's long life and to get the same husband for seven lives.

observances.name: Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
