observances.name: Maharana Pratap Jayanti
observances.description_1: Maharana Pratap Jayanti is the birth anniversary of Maharana Pratap, the valiant Rajput king of Mewar in Rajasthan
observances.description_2:
Maharana Pratap Jayanti is celebrated on the tritiya thiti of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Jyeshtha. Maharana Pratap was born on this day according to the Hindu calendar.

Maharana Pratap is remembered for his courage and his refusal to submit to Mughal domination. His life is a symbol of Rajput valor and honor.
The Battle of Haldighati (1576) is one of the most famous battles associated with him. He is revered and worshipped by many royal families in Rajasthan for his bravery and courage.

observances.name: Satala Shasti
observances.description_1: Shitalasasthi is celebrated as the wedding of Shiva and Parvati.
observances.description_2:
Shitalasasthi is celebrated on the sasthi thiti during the Shukla Paksha in the month of Jyestha .

Sitala Sasthi commemorates the marriage of Shiva and Parvati, the divine couple and is celebrated since ancient times. According to the legend, Parvati performed rigorous penance to get Lord Shiva as her husband. On the day of Jyestha Shukla Paksha Sasthi, Shiva was pleased and the divine marriage of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati took place.

Sitalasasthi is also observed as the Monsoon Wedding of Lord Shiva and Parvati as it marks the beginning of the monsoon season. Farmers celebrate the beginning of monsoon on Sitalasasthi.

Shitalasasthi is celebrated with immense grandeur in the Sambalpur district of Orissa. The Sambalpur Utsav on Shitalasasthi is a popular event that attracts thousands of tourists from all over India and abroad.

deities.title: Parvathi
deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife, and is the mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Sashti
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Dhumavati Jayanti
observances.description_1: Dhumavati Jayanti is dedicated to the worship of Goddess Dhumavati, one of the ten Mahavidya Goddesses.
observances.description_2:
Dhumavati Jayanti is dedicated to the worship of Goddess Dhumavati. She represents the dark and inauspicious aspects of the divine feminine.

It is believed that Dhumavati is the widow form of Goddess Parvati. It is said that during a disagreement, Parvati consumed Lord Shiva. Afterward, she assumed the form of Dhumavati, representing the state of a widow without her consort.

Goddess Dhumavati symbolizes the void and the state of dissolution before creation and manifests herself at the time of Pralaya (cosmic dissolution).
She is often depicted as an elderly, widowed woman, often riding a chariot without horses with a winnowing basket, usually in a cremation ground.

observances.name: Mahesh Navami
observances.description_1: Mahesh Navami is dedicated to the worship of Lord Shiva, also known as Mahesh, celebrated by the Maheshwari community of Rajasthan.
observances.description_2:
Mahesh Navami is celebrated on the navami of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Jyeshtha. It is the biggest festival of the Maheshwari community.

The festival commemorates the divine appearance of Lord Shiva to the ancestors of the Maheshwari community of Rajasthan. According to legend, on the day of Jyeshtha Shukla Navami, Lord Mahesha and Mata Parvati freed the 72 Kshatriyas who had been turned into stone due to the curse of the sages which led to the emergence of the Maheshwari community.

Mahesh Navami is celebrated as Maheshwari Vanshotpatti Day on a grand scale. Many religious and cultural programs are organized and processions are taken out. Devotees sing Mahesha Vandana and
Maha Aarti of Lord Mahesha is also performed in Shiva temples.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Ganga Dussehra
observances.description_1: Ganga Dussehra celebrates the descent of the sacred Ganga River to Earth.
observances.description_2:
Ganga Dussehra falls during Dashami Tithi of Jyeshtha Shukla Paksha and currently falls in May or June. Ganga Dussehra is also known as Gangavataran which means the descent of the Ganga.

Usually, Ganga Dussehra is celebrated one day before Nirjala Ekadashi but in some years Ganga Dussehra and Nirjala Ekadashi might fall on the same day.

Ganga Dussehra is dedicated to Goddess Ganga and this day is commemorated as the day when Goddess Ganga descended to the Earth to accomplish her mission to purge the cursed souls of Bhagiratha's ancestors. Before coming to the Earth, the Goddess Ganga was residing in Kamandal of Lord Brahma and along with her the Goddess Ganga brought the purity of heaven to the Earth.

On Ganga Dussehra, devotees worship Goddess Ganga and take a bath in the Ganges. Taking a bath in the Ganges and offering charity or Dan-Punya on Ganga Dussehra day is considered highly auspicious. It is believed that the holy dip in the Ganges on Ganga Dussehra day can purge all types of sins.

Devotees flock to Prayagraj/Allahabad, Garhmukteshwar, Haridwar, Rishikesh and Varanasi to take a holy dip. Ganga Dussehra celebrations are legendary in Varanasi. On Ganga Dussehra day thousands of devotees do Ganga Snan and participate in Ganga Aarti at Dasaswamedh Ghat.

deities.title: Ganga
deities.description: Goddess Ganga, is the personification of the sacred River Ganga. She is believed to have descended from the heavens to Earth, through the efforts of King Bhagiratha, to cleanse the souls of his ancestors and relieve them from a curse. She is seen as a divine purifier, capable of washing away sins and providing salvation to those who bathe in her sacred waters or have their ashes immersed in the river.

observances.name: Gayatri Jayanti
observances.description_1: Gayatri Jayanti celebrates the birth anniversary of Goddess Gayatri, the Goddess of Veda.
observances.description_2:
Gayatri Jayanti is observed on Shukla Paksha Ekadashi during Jyeshtha lunar month and it is usually observed on the next day of Ganga Dussehra.

Being the Goddess of all Veda, Goddess Gayatri is also known as Veda Mata.

It is believed that Goddess Gayatri is manifestation of all phenomenal attributes of Brahman. She is also worshipped as the Goddess of Hindu Trimurti. She is considered as the mother of all Gods and embodiment of Goddess Saraswati, Goddess Parvati and Goddess Lakshmi.

deities.title: Goddess Gayatri
deities.description: Goddess Gayatri is often considered the personified form of the Gayatri Mantra, a popular hymn from Vedic texts. She is worshiped as the essence of the Vedas and the embodiment of wisdom, righteousness, and spiritual enlightenment. She is considered the mother of all Vedas (Veda Mata) and is sometimes depicted as the consort of Lord Brahma, the creator god, symbolizing her role in nurturing and sustaining creation through the transformative power of wisdom. She is the manifestation of Saraswati and is often associated with Savitṛ, a solar deity in the Vedas

observances.name: Nirjala Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Nirjala Ekadashi: A rigorous fasting day with no food or water, offering the benefits of 24 Ekadashis.
observances.description_2:
Nirjala Ekadashi stands out as the toughest and most significant of all twenty-four Ekadashis observed yearly. 'Nirjala' translates to 'without water,' symbolizing the strict fasting observed on this day, refraining from both food and water.

Nirjala Ekadashi occurs during the Shukla Paksha of the Jyeshtha month, usually in May or June. It often follows Ganga Dussehra, although occasionally, both events coincide.

For devotees unable to observe all twenty-four Ekadashis, observing Nirjala Ekadashi offers the same benefits. It's regarded as equivalent to fasting on all Ekadashis throughout the year.

Also known as Pandava Ekadashi or Bhimseni Ekadashi, it's linked to Bhima, the Pandava prince. Bhima, known for his hearty appetite, struggled with traditional Ekadashi fasting. Upon sage Vyasa's counsel, he observed Nirjala Ekadashi to make amends, earning it these alternative names.

Parana means breaking the fast. Ekadashi Parana is done after sunrise on the next day of Ekadashi fast. It is necessary to do Parana within Dwadashi Tithi unless Dwadashi is over before sunrise.

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Jamai Sasti
observances.description_1: A Bengali festival celebrates the bond between sons-in-law and mothers-in-law with feasting and blessings.
observances.description_2:
Jamai Sasthi is a Bengali festival that celebrates the bond between sons-in-law and their mothers-in-law. The word "Jamai" means son-in-law and "Sasthi" means sixth.

The festival has both religious and cultural significance. It is believed that observing Jamai Sasthi will bring good fortune and prosperity to the family. The festival also serves as an opportunity to strengthen the bond between mothers-in-law and sons-in-law, who are traditionally seen as important members of the family.

During Jamai Sasthi, the sons-in-law are typically presented with new clothes, jewellery, and other gifts. They are also served with a special feast, which usually includes traditional Bengali dishes such as fish curry, and rice, and sweets such as rasgulla and sandesh. In some households, the sons-in-law are also given a ceremonial bath, after which they are offered new clothes and gifts.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Ravivara Shukla Pradosa
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Vat Purnima
observances.description_1: Festival honouring the bond between husbands and wives.
observances.description_2:
A Celebration of Spousal Bonds celebrated mainly in Maharashtra, Gujarat and southern Indian states.

It falls on the Krishna Paksha Purnima (new moon day) in Jyeshtha masa.

On Vat Purnima, married women observe a fast and offer prayers to the banyan tree, Vat Vriksha, to honour the Goddess Savitri. The fast is a commemoration of Savitri's act of rescuing her husband, Satyavan, from the god of death.

Married women in Maharashtra, Gujarat and southern Indian states observe Vat Savitri Vrat 15 days later than that of North Indian women. However, the legend behind observing the fast is the same in both calendars.

Married women circle the banyan tree(vat) seven times with a yellow-red thread while praying for their husband's long life and to get the same husband for seven lives.

observances.name: Purnima
observances.description_1: Purnima, signifies the full moon day, often marked by religious ceremonies and spiritual observances.
observances.description_2:
Purnima, or the Full Moon day, is a significant occasion in Indian culture, occurring monthly as the moon reaches its maximum brightness.

Purnima fasting is observed either on the Purnima day itself or the day before, known as Chaturdashi, depending on the timing of the Purnima Tithi (lunar day) from the previous day.

Purnima fasting on Chaturdashi occurs only when the Purnima begins during the Madhyahna period on the previous day. If Chaturdashi extends beyond Madhyahna, it's considered impure for Purnima fasting, even if Purnima begins later in the evening.

In North India, the full moon day is called Purnima, while in South India, it's referred to as Pournami or Pournima, and fasting on this day is known as Pournami Vratam, observed from sunrise until the moon is sighted.

observances.name: Purnima
observances.description_1: Purnima, signifies the full moon day, often marked by religious ceremonies and spiritual observances.
observances.description_2:

observances.name: Sankasta Chaturthi
observances.description_1: Sankashti Chaturthi is a significant day for Lord Ganesha devotees, observed to seek his blessings and overcome obstacles.
observances.description_2:
In the Hindu calendar, each lunar month includes two Chaturthi Tithi. The one following the full moon, known as Purnimasi, during Krishna Paksha is called Sankashti Chaturthi, while the one following the new moon, known as Amavasya, during Shukla Paksha is called Vinayaka Chaturthi.

If Sankashti Chaturthi falls on a Tuesday, it is revered as Angarki Chaturthi, considered highly auspicious, particularly in Western and Southern India, notably Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu.

During Sankashti Chaturthi, devotees of Lord Ganesha observe a fast from sunrise to moonrise. Sankashti, meaning deliverance during troubled times, signifies the belief that observing this fast can remove obstacles, as Lord Ganesha is revered as the remover of obstacles.

The fast is observed strictly, with consumption limited to fruits, roots, and vegetable products. Typical foods include Sabudana Khichadi, potatoes, and peanuts, with devotees breaking their fast after sighting the moon.

In North India, Sankashti Chaturthi in the month of Magha is known as Sakat Chauth, while Vinayaka Chaturthi in the month of Bhadrapada is celebrated as Ganesha Chaturthi worldwide as Lord Ganesha's birthday.

Among Tamil Hindus, Sankashti Chaturthi is referred to as Ganesh Sankatahara or Sankatahara Chaturthi.

observances.name: Raja Sankranti
observances.description_1: Raja Sankranti, celebrated in Odisha, marks the onset of the monsoon season with swing festivities.
observances.description_2:
The festival is a celebration of the onset of the monsoon season. Raja Sankranti is the second day of the Pahili Raja festival, which is a three-day festival that can sometimes go on for four days in the state.

The Raja Sankranti Day is also called the 'Swing Festival' because of the many varieties of swings that are hung from tree branches. Girls play on the swings while singing folk songs.

While Pahili Raja is the first day of the festival, Raja Sankranti is the second day, and the third day is called Basi Raja (past Raja). Raja Sankranti is also called Mithuna Sankranti with the meaning of the name being ''the proper king''.

During the festival, people do not walk barefoot on the earth as it is believed that the earth should be given rest before the monsoon rains fall on it. Women take a break from household chores and farmers take a break from agricultural work.

Everyone indulges in games with the women spending time playing indoor games and playing on the specially constructed swings. These swings are called by different names such as 'dandi doli', 'pata doli', ''charki doli'', and ''Ram doli''. Young women who are single wear their traditional clothes and paint their feet red with a special red dye called 'alata'.

Vasumati Snana is the final day of the festival, which is sometimes on the fourth day. Here, a grinding stone symbolising the Hindu Goddess of earth, Bhumi, is given a ritualistic bath by women with turmeric paste. It is adorned with flowers afterwards. Seasonal fruits are offered to the Earth Mother Goddess after this. In order to prepare for this, the day before the festival is put aside to clean the grinding stones in the houses and prepare the spices. This day is called 'Sajabaja' meaning the preparatory day.

This is a time when people get together to welcome the rains and worship the earth as their mother and goddess who bestows her blessings on them.

observances.name: Masik Sankranti
observances.description_1: Masik Sankranti marks the transition of the Sun into a new zodiac sign each month, observed with spiritual significance.
observances.description_2:
Sankranti refers to the transmigration of the sun from one rashi (zodiac) to another in Indian astronomy
The observance revolves around sun’s transition into new rashi (zodiac sign), symoblizing the end of one solar month and the beginning of another.

Malik Sankranti’s including the Makara Sankranthi is associated with Surya pravesh (Sun’s entry) into each rashi. There are twelve rashis (12 signs) namely Mekh (Mekha), Virkh, Mithun, Kark, Singh-Simha, Kanya, Tula,Vrischik, Dhan, Makara, Kumbh and Meena.

While significance and rituals may vary for each Masik Sankranti, they are generally considered as times to offer prayers, seek blessings and make positive changes in one’s life.

Sankranti days are considered good for charity activities and all auspicious ceremonies are avoided on the day of Sankranti(s).

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Shani Jayanti Amavasya
observances.description_1: Shani Jayanti marks the birth anniversary of Lord Shani.
observances.description_2:
Shani Jayanti is observed on Amavasya Tithi during Jyeshtha month (Purnimant) or during Vaishakha month (Amavasyant ).

Lord Shani is son of Lord Suryadev and rules planet Saturn and weekday Saturday. He is the Lord of Karma and justice. It is believed that people who do not have blessing of Lord Shani bear no fruits for their hard work.

On Shani Jayanti, devotees observe fast and visit Shani temples to seek blessings of Lord Shani.

Shani Tailabhishekam and Shani Shanti Puja are the most important ceremonies performed during Shani Jayanti. These ceremonies are believed to lessen Shani Dosha, which is popularly known as Sade Sati.

deities.title: Shani Mahatma
deities.description: Lord Shani is the personification of the planet Saturn. He is one of the Navagrahas, the nine celestial deities in Vedic astrology. He considered the deity of karma, justice, and retribution, rewarding the virtuous and punishing the evil. He is known for his influence on individuals' lives, bringing both challenges and justice. He is depicted riding a vulture or on an iron chariot drawn by eight horses.

observances.name: Jyeshtha Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.

observances.name: Jagannatha Rath Yatra
observances.description_1: A grand chariot festival, Celebrated primarily in the coastal town of Puri, Odisha.
observances.description_2:
A Grand Chariot Festival. Celebrated primarily in the coastal town of Puri, located in Odisha.

The festival is held every year on the second day of the Shukla Paksha (waxing phase of the moon) in the Hindu month of Ashadha (June-July).

The festival is associated with Lord Jagannath, Lord Balabhadra, and Goddess Subhadra, who are believed to embark on a journey in grand chariots from the Jagannath Temple in Puri to the Gundicha Temple.

Puri Rath Yatra is significant as it symbolizes the Lord's annual journey to visit his aunt's temple. Huge chariots carrying the deities are pulled by devotees through the streets of Puri. This grand procession attracts millions of pilgrims each year.

observances.name: Sashti
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Kumara Sasthi
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Kharchi puja
observances.description_1: Kharchi Puja is dedicated to the worship of the fourteen gods and deities that form the dynasty deity of the Tripuri people.
observances.description_2:
Kharchi Puja is a significant festival celebrated in the northeastern Indian state of Tripura. It is primarily dedicated to the worship of the fourteen gods and deities that form an essential part of the traditional tribal culture and religion of the state.

The festival is held at the temple of the Fourteen Gods, also known as Chaturdasha Devata Mandir, located in Old Agartala. The word "Kharchi" is derived from "Khya," which means "earth" in the local tribal language, and the festival is essentially a worship of Mother Earth.

The main ritual of Kharchi Puja involves the purification of the deities and the temple premises. The idols are bathed in the holy water and are brought back to the temple. They are again placed in the temple by performing Puja, offering of Flowers and Vermillion. Devotees offer prayers, flowers, fruits, and animal sacrifices to the fourteen gods. The sacrifices, usually goats or pigeons, are made to appease the gods and seek their blessings.

The festival is marked by vibrant folk dances and music performances by local artists. These cultural activities add to the festive spirit and are a significant part of the celebration. It attracts tourists from across the country and abroad.

observances.name: Devshayani Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Commemorating the beginning of Lord Vishnu's cosmic sleep.
observances.description_2:
Ashadha Shukla Paksha Ekadashi is known as Devshayani Ekadashi. Lord Vishnu goes to sleep on this day and wakes up after four months on Prabodhini Ekadashi.

Devshayani Ekadashi comes just after the famous Jagannath Rathyatra and currently falls in the month of June or July on the Gregorian calendar. Chaturmas, a holy period of four months in the Hindu calendar, starts from this day.

Devshayani Ekadashi is also known as Padma Ekadashi, Ashadi Ekadashi and Hari Shayani Ekadashi.

Parana means breaking the fast. Ekadashi Parana is done after sunrise on the next day of Ekadashi fast. It is necessary to do Parana within Dwadashi Tithi unless Dwadashi is over before sunrise.

Sometimes, Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. Smartha (householders) with family are advised to fast on the first day only, while the alternate Ekadashi fasting is suggested for Sanyasis (renunciates), widows, and those seeking Moksha.

Fasting on both days is recommended for devoted seekers of Lord Vishnu's love and affection.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

deities.title: Sri Panduranga
deities.description: Sri Panduranga is a form of the Vishnu in his Krishna avatar. He worshipped primarily in the Indian states of Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Andhra Pradesh. The Varkari sect, a devotional movement centered around Panduranga, emphasizes the values of humility, devotion, and community service. He embodies a youthful, compassionate aspect of Lord Krishna.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

observances.name: Guru Purnima
observances.description_1: Celebrating the invaluable role of gurus, marked with reverence and gratitude.
observances.description_2:
Guru Purnima, a sacred festival celebrated by Hindus, Buddhists, and Jains, holds profound significance as a day to express reverence and gratitude towards spiritual teachers, mentors, and gurus.

Guru Purnima is the Purnima that occurs in Ashadha masa.

Guru Purnima is also known as Vyasa Purnima and this day is commemorated as the birth anniversary of Veda Vyasa. Veda Vyasa was the author as well as a character in the Hindu epic Mahabharata.

Adi Shankara, Sri Ramanuja Acharya and Sri Madhvacharya are some of the noteworthy Gurus in Hinduism. They are also commemorated on this day.

Guru Purnima is also celebrated by Buddhists in honour of Gautama Buddha to commemorate the day when Buddha gave his first sermon at Sarnath, Uttar Pradesh, India.

Devotees offer prayers to their guru. They also offer flowers, fruits, and diyas to their guru.

deities.title: Guru
deities.description: The Guru is revered as a pivotal spiritual guide whose profound wisdom and divine connection elevate him to a status worthy of deep respect and veneration. By imparting essential knowledge and guiding disciples through their spiritual journey, the Guru helps dissolve ignorance, facilitating a deeper understanding of the self and the universe, making him truly worthy of reverence.

observances.name: Kokila Vrat
observances.description_1: Kokila Vrat is a period of fasting observed by women dedicated to Goddess Sati and Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Kokila Vrat is observed on the Purnima in the month of Ashadha.In North Indian states, it is observed for a month from Ashadha Purnima to Shravan Purnima. It is believed that it should be observed in those years when there is an intercalary Ashadha month. It is observed during normal Masa and not during Adhik Masa. However, in the Southern and Western parts of India, Kokila Vrat is observed annually on Ashadha Purnima.

Kokila Vrat is dedicated to Goddess Sati and Lord Shiva. The name Kokila refers to the Indian bird cuckoo and is associated with Goddess Sati. According to legend, Goddess Sati immolated herself when Her father, Daksha, insulted Lord Shiva. It is believed that she was reborn as a cuckoo and merged with Lord Shiva after a thousand celestial years.

Women fast during the Kokila Vrat and wake up early to take bath in nearby river or water body. They also make an idol of cuckoo with clay and worship it. It is believed that women who observe Kokila Vrat will be Akhand Saubhagyavati.

deities.title: Parvathi
deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife, and is the mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Purnima
observances.description_1: Purnima, signifies the full moon day, often marked by religious ceremonies and spiritual observances.
observances.description_2:
Purnima, or the Full Moon day, is a significant occasion in Indian culture, occurring monthly as the moon reaches its maximum brightness.

Purnima fasting is observed either on the Purnima day itself or the day before, known as Chaturdashi, depending on the timing of the Purnima Tithi (lunar day) from the previous day.

Purnima fasting on Chaturdashi occurs only when the Purnima begins during the Madhyahna period on the previous day. If Chaturdashi extends beyond Madhyahna, it's considered impure for Purnima fasting, even if Purnima begins later in the evening.

In North India, the full moon day is called Purnima, while in South India, it's referred to as Pournami or Pournima, and fasting on this day is known as Pournami Vratam, observed from sunrise until the moon is sighted.

observances.name: Shravana Somavara - Prathama
observances.description_1: The first Monday in the highly auspicious month of Shravana. It is a special observance in the Hindu calendar dedicated to Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Shravana is the fifth month in the Hindu calendar and is dedicated to Lord Shiva. All Mondays or Somavar(s) which fall during Shravana month are considered highly auspicious for fasting and known as Shravan Somavara.

One of the prominent legends associated with the significance of Shravana Somavara is that of the churning of the ocean (Samudra Manthan) which happened during the month of Shravana. During the Samudra Manthan, Lord Shiva consumed the poison (halahala) that came out of the ocean to save the world , thus earning the title Neelkanth (the blue-throated one).

Shravana is considered the holiest month in the Hindu calendar for the worship of Lord Shiva. It is believed that during this time, the celestial alignment is such that the energy and grace of Lord Shiva are most accessible.
Devotees observe a strict fast on Mondays during the Shravana month. Some may follow a partial fast (eating fruits, milk, and light food), while others may observe a complete fast without any food or water.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Sankasta Chaturthi
observances.description_1: Sankashti Chaturthi is a significant day for Lord Ganesha devotees, observed to seek his blessings and overcome obstacles.
observances.description_2:
In the Hindu calendar, each lunar month includes two Chaturthi Tithi. The one following the full moon, known as Purnimasi, during Krishna Paksha is called Sankashti Chaturthi, while the one following the new moon, known as Amavasya, during Shukla Paksha is called Vinayaka Chaturthi.

If Sankashti Chaturthi falls on a Tuesday, it is revered as Angarki Chaturthi, considered highly auspicious, particularly in Western and Southern India, notably Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu.

During Sankashti Chaturthi, devotees of Lord Ganesha observe a fast from sunrise to moonrise. Sankashti, meaning deliverance during troubled times, signifies the belief that observing this fast can remove obstacles, as Lord Ganesha is revered as the remover of obstacles.

The fast is observed strictly, with consumption limited to fruits, roots, and vegetable products. Typical foods include Sabudana Khichadi, potatoes, and peanuts, with devotees breaking their fast after sighting the moon.

In North India, Sankashti Chaturthi in the month of Magha is known as Sakat Chauth, while Vinayaka Chaturthi in the month of Bhadrapada is celebrated as Ganesha Chaturthi worldwide as Lord Ganesha's birthday.

Among Tamil Hindus, Sankashti Chaturthi is referred to as Ganesh Sankatahara or Sankatahara Chaturthi.

observances.name: Mangala Gauri Vratha - Prathama
observances.description_1: First Mangalavara of Mangala Gauri Vratha. Mangala Gauri Vratha is a traditional fasting ritual observed by married women, dedicated to Goddess Gauri (an incarnation of Parvati), for marital bliss, happiness, and the well-being of their families.
observances.description_2:
Mangala Gauri Vratha is a sacred fasting ritual observed primarily by married women in various parts of India, particularly in Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, and Maharashtra. The vratha is dedicated to Goddess Gauri, also known as Mangala Gauri, who is considered an incarnation of Goddess Parvati and a symbol of marital harmony, fertility, and prosperity.

The observance of Mangala Gauri Vratha happens four or five times a year, taking place on tuesdays during the Shravana masa. On this day, married women wake up early, take a purifying bath, and adorn themselves in traditional attire and jewelry. They then create a sacred space in their homes where they place an image or idol of Goddess Gauri and decorate it with flowers, turmeric, and vermilion.

Devotees observe a strict fast throughout the day, abstaining from consuming food and water until the completion of the vratha. They offer prayers and perform special rituals to Goddess Gauri, seeking her blessings for the well-being and longevity of their husbands and families.

In the evening, after the completion of the vratha, married women break their fast by partaking in a meal prepared with great devotion and offered to the deity as prasad (blessed food).

deities.title: Parvathi
deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife, and is the mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

observances.name: Masik Sankranti
observances.description_1: Masik Sankranti marks the transition of the Sun into a new zodiac sign each month, observed with spiritual significance.
observances.description_2:
Sankranti refers to the transmigration of the sun from one rashi (zodiac) to another in Indian astronomy
The observance revolves around sun’s transition into new rashi (zodiac sign), symoblizing the end of one solar month and the beginning of another.

Malik Sankranti’s including the Makara Sankranthi is associated with Surya pravesh (Sun’s entry) into each rashi. There are twelve rashis (12 signs) namely Mekh (Mekha), Virkh, Mithun, Kark, Singh-Simha, Kanya, Tula,Vrischik, Dhan, Makara, Kumbh and Meena.

While significance and rituals may vary for each Masik Sankranti, they are generally considered as times to offer prayers, seek blessings and make positive changes in one’s life.

Sankranti days are considered good for charity activities and all auspicious ceremonies are avoided on the day of Sankranti(s).

observances.name: Bonalu
observances.description_1: A vibrant celebration of goddess Mahakali filled with devotion, rituals, and colourful offerings.
observances.description_2:
Bonalu, a traditional Hindu festival predominantly celebrated in the Telangana region of India, is a vibrant and colourful ode to Goddess Mahakali.

This annual festival is observed during the Ashada masa.

The festival of Bonalu is deeply rooted in the worship of the Mother Goddess Mahakali. The name "Bonalu" is derived from the Telugu word "Bhojanalu," meaning food offerings, as devotees present a variety of food items to the goddess as a symbol of gratitude.

Celebrations kick off with the Golconda Bonalu, where a colourful procession carries the Utsava Murthi (processional idol) of the goddess from the Mahakali Temple in Golconda Fort. Devotees, dress in traditional attire, carry decorated pots (Bonalu) containing offerings like rice, jaggery, curd, and water to be presented to the goddess.

observances.name: Shravana Somavara - Dwitiya
observances.description_1: The second Monday in the highly auspicious month of Shravana. It is a special observance in the Hindu calendar dedicated to Lord Shiva.

Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. observances.name: Kamika Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Sawan Shivratri
observances.description_1: Sawan Shivaratri, a revered occasion, celebrates devotion to Lord Shiva in the auspicious Shravana month.
observances.description_2:
Chaturdashi Tithi during Krishna Paksha is observed as Masik Shivaratri, where ardent devotees of Lord Shiva fast and worship the Shiva Linga. Throughout the year, there are typically twelve Shivaratri days.

Shivaratri falling in the Shravana masa is known as Sawan Shivaratri. As the entire Shravana month is dedicated to Shiva Puja, Masik Shivaratri during Sawan holds special significance.

Famous Shiva temples in North India, such as Kashi Vishwanath and Badrinath Dham, arrange special Pujas and Shiva Darshan during the Sawan month. Thousands of Shiva devotees visit these temples during Sawan and perform Gangajal Abhishekam.

Sawan Shivaratri is more popular in North Indian states like Uttarakhand, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, and others, where the Purnimant Lunar Calendar is followed. In states like Andhra Pradesh, Goa, Maharashtra, Karnataka, Gujarat, and Tamil Nadu, where the Amanta Lunar Calendar is followed, Sawan Shivaratri corresponds to Ashadha Shivaratri.

The Sawan Shivaratri Vrat Vidhi involves eating only one meal on Trayodashi before the fast and taking a Sankalp for a full-day fast on Shivaratri. The evening before Shivaratri, devotees take a second bath before Shiva Puja or temple visits. The fast is broken the next day between sunrise and the end of Chaturdashi Tithi.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Hariyali Amavasya
observances.description_1: Embracing greenery and renewal, a spiritual observance on the Shravan Amavasya.
observances.description_2:
The term "Hariyali" translates to "greenery", signifying the lushness and vitality of the environment during the monsoon season. Hariyali Amavasya is especially celebrated in North India, where the monsoon rains bring life to the parched land.

Hariyali Amavasya falls during Shravana masa which corresponds to Ashadha Amavasya in Andhra Pradesh, Goa, Maharashtra, Karnataka, Gujarat and Tamil Nadu where the Amanta Lunar Calendar is followed.

Various temples in North India, especially in Mathura and Vrindavan, organize a special Darshan on Hariyali Amavasya day. Thousands of Krishna devotees visit Dwarkadhish temple in Mathura and Banke Bihari temple in Vrindavan to see the special Darshan of Lord Krishna.

Phool Bangla at Banke Bihari temple in Vrindavan is famous among Krishna devotees. Apart from Krishna temples various Shiva temples also arrange special Shiva Darshan on Hariyali Amavasya day.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Bheemana Amavasya
observances.description_1: Bheemana Amavasya is a significant observance, marked by reverence for ancestors, particularly in Karnataka, India.
observances.description_2:
Bheemana Amavasya is a significant Hindu observance widely practiced by women in Karnataka. It falls in the Ashadha masa.

Jyoti Bheemeshwara Amavasi (Bheemana Amavasi Vrata) venerates Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati. Its origin stems from the tale of a young bride who, after marrying a deceased prince, performed the Bheemana Amavasya puja with mud lamps. Her unwavering devotion led Shiva and Parvati to resurrect the prince and bless her.

During Bheemana Amavasya, married and unmarried women observe fasts, praying for the longevity of their husbands, brothers, and male relatives—a custom also known as Deepastambha Pooja.

The ritual, documented in the Skanda Purana, involves crafting a pair of mud lamps, symbolizing Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, and conducting special pujas to honor the divine couple. Another prominent tradition is the preparation of Kadubu, dough balls containing hidden coins, which are broken by brothers or young boys at the conclusion of the Bheemana Puja.

Women fasting on Bheema Amavasya abstain from fried foods and break their fasts with fruits and dairy products, offered first to Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati.

deities.title: Parvathi
deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife, and is the mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

observances.name: Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: Hariyali Teej
observances.description_1: Teej, celebrated mainly by women in North India, marks the divine union of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati.
observances.description_2:
In North Indian states like Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Bihar, and Jharkhand, Teej is a vibrant celebration observed mainly by women.

Hariyali Teej falls on the third day of Shukla Paksha of the Shravana masa, usually preceding Nag Panchami by two days. It holds significance as it marks the 108th birth of Parvati, symbolizing her acceptance of Shiva as her consort, revered as Teej Maata.

Hariyali Teej symbolizes the reunion of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati. Married women observe fasts and offer prayers to Goddess Parvati for conjugal bliss and marital happiness. During Hariyali Teej married women visit their parents' home, wear new clothes preferably green Sari and enjoy swings while singing Teej songs.

Parents show their affection by sending Sindhara, a gift bucket containing homemade sweets, Ghewar, Henna, and bangles, to their married daughters' in-laws. This tradition has led to Hariyali Teej being referred to as Sindhara Teej.

The festival is also known as Chhoti Teej and Shravana Teej. It is followed by Kajari Teej, also known as Badi Teej, occurring fifteen days later.

deities.title: Parvathi
deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

observances.name: Aadi Pooram
observances.description_1: Aadi Pooram is celebrated in honor of Goddess Andal, marking her birth and devotion to Lord Vishnu. It is observed in the Tamil month of Aadi and includes vibrant processions, devotional singing, and rituals in temples, particularly in Tamil Nadu.
observances.description_2:
Aadi Pooram, also known as Andal Jayanti, is a celebration dedicated to Goddess Andal, one of the twelve Alvars (saint-poets) and a devoted follower of Lord Vishnu. Celebrated in the Tamil month of Aadi, this festival marks the birth of Goddess Andal and her admiration for Lord Vishnu.

Goddess Andal is seen as an incarnation of Goddess Lakshmi and is loved for her beautiful hymns and devotion. During Aadi Pooram, temples, especially in Tamil Nadu, are decorated, and colorful processions are held with the idol of Goddess Andal. Devotees take part in special rituals, including poojas, abhishekams (ritual bathing of the deity), and singing her hymns, especially the Tiruppavai and Nachiyar Tirumozhi.

deities.title: Parvathi
deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife, and is the mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

deities.title: Goda Devi
deities.description: Goda Devi, also known as Andal or Kothai, is a beloved saint and poetess in the Vaishnava tradition of Hinduism, especially revered in South India. She is celebrated as one of the twelve Alvars (saint-poets devoted to Vishnu) and is considered an incarnation of Bhudevi, the Earth Goddess. Andal is known for her devotion to Lord Vishnu, specifically to the deity Ranganatha of the Sri Ranganathaswamy Temple.

observances.name: Naga Panchami
observances.description_1: Nag Panchami honors Naga devata during the Shravana masa month.
observances.description_2:
Nag Panchami, celebrated during the Shukla Paksha of the Shravana masa on its fifth day Panchami), holds a special place in Hindu tradition.

Typically following two days after Hariyali Teej, which marks the advent of the monsoon season, Nag Panchami falls between July and August in the Gregorian calendar. This auspicious occasion is dedicated to the worship of Naga Devta, the serpent deity, and is observed with reverence across India.

During Naga Panchami, women perform rituals to honor Naga Devta by offering milk to snakes, symbolizing respect and seeking blessings for the well-being of their families.

In Hindu belief, serpent deities hold immense significance, and Naga Panchami is regarded as one of the most propitious days to worship them.

Devotees chant sacred mantras invoking the blessings of Naga devata, seeking protection and prosperity for themselves and their loved ones. The Naga Panchami Puja Mantra, recited with devotion, is believed to confer divine grace and safeguard against malevolent forces.

In some regions, Naga Panchami is preceded by Naga Chaturthi, a day of fasting observed to purify the mind and body before the main festival. Additionally, in Gujarat, Naga Panchami is celebrated as Nag Pancham, aligning with the Krishna Paksha Panchami of Shravana month, heralding the festivities leading up to Krishna Janmashtami.

observances.name: Mangala Gauri Vratha - Trithiya
observances.description_1: Third Mangalavara of Mangala Gauri Vratha. Mangala Gauri Vratha is a traditional fasting ritual observed by married women, dedicated to Goddess Gauri (an incarnation of Parvati), for marital bliss, happiness, and the well-being of their families.
observances.description_2:
Mangala Gauri Vratha is a sacred fasting ritual observed primarily by married women in various parts of India, particularly in Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, and Maharashtra. The vratha is dedicated to Goddess Gauri, also known as Mangala Gauri, who is considered an incarnation of Goddess Parvati and a symbol of marital harmony, fertility, and prosperity.

The observance of Mangala Gauri Vratha happens four or five times a year, taking place on tuesdays during the Shravana masa. On this day, married women wake up early, take a purifying bath, and adorn themselves in traditional attire and jewelry. They then create a sacred space in their homes where they place an image or idol of Goddess Gauri and decorate it with flowers, turmeric, and vermilion.

Devotees observe a strict fast throughout the day, abstaining from consuming food and water until the completion of the vratha. They offer prayers and perform special rituals to Goddess Gauri, seeking her blessings for the well-being and longevity of their husbands and families.

In the evening, after the completion of the vratha, married women break their fast by partaking in a meal prepared with great devotion and offered to the deity as prasad (blessed food).

deities.title: Parvathi
deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife, and is the mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

observances.name: Sashti
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Tulsidas Jayanti
observances.description_1: Tulsidas Jayanti commemorates the birth anniversary of the great poet-saint Goswami Tulsidas.
observances.description_2:
According to Hindu calendar, Tulsidas was born in the Saptami tithi of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Shravana and this day is observed as Tulsidas Jayanti.

Tulsidas was a 16th-century Hindu poet-saint, philosopher, and devotee of Lord Rama. His works, especially the "Ramcharitmanas," are considered some of the greatest in Hindu literature.Tulsidas's writings emphasize devotion to Lord Rama and the principles of dharma. His compositions have had an impact on Hindu culture and religious practices.

Tulsidas also wrote several other important texts, including "Hanuman Chalisa," "Vinaya Patrika," and "Dohavali,". He spent most of his life in the city of Varanasi. Tulsi Ghat on the Ganges River in Varanasi is named after him. The famous Sankatmochan Temple in Varanasi dedicated to God Hanuman is believed to be founded by him.

observances.name: Aadi Perukku
observances.description_1: Celebrating the power of water, fertility, and nature's abundance.
observances.description_2:
Aadi Perukku is a traditional South Indian festival celebrated predominantly in the state of Tamil Nadu and is dedicated to the worship of water, nature, and the divine forces associated with fertility and prosperity.

The word "Aadi" is the name of the Tamil month in which the festival falls, and "Perukku" means "to rise". The festival is also sometimes referred to as "Padinettam Perukku", which means "eighteenth Perukku". Celebrated on the 18th day of the Tamil month of Aadi.

It's a festival of prosperity and good fortune that's associated with the holy rivers Cauvery, Ganga, Yamuna, Godavari, and Vaigai.

During the festival, prayers are offered to rivers and water sources in the hope of a sustainable water resource and a better yield in the ensuing season.

deities.title: Parvathi
deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife, and is the mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

observances.description_1: Celebrating the power of water, fertility, and nature's abundance.
observances.description_2:
Aadi Perukku is a traditional South Indian festival celebrated predominantly in the state of Tamil Nadu and is dedicated to the worship of water, nature, and the divine forces associated with fertility and prosperity.

The word "Aadi" is the name of the Tamil month in which the festival falls, and "Perukku" means "to rise". The festival is also sometimes referred to as "Padinettam Perukku", which means "eighteenth Perukku". Celebrated on the 18th day of the Tamil month of Aadi.

It's a festival of prosperity and good fortune that's associated with the holy rivers Cauvery, Ganga, Yamuna, Godavari, and Vaigai.

During the festival, prayers are offered to rivers and water sources in the hope of a sustainable water resource and a better yield in the ensuing season.
