deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife, and is the mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

observances.name: Shravana Somavara - Chaturtha
observances.description_1: The fourth Monday in the highly auspicious month of Shravana. It is a special observance in the Hindu calendar dedicated to Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Shravana is the fifth month in the Hindu calendar and is dedicated to Lord Shiva. All Mondays or Somavar(s) which fall during Shravana month are considered highly auspicious for fasting and known as Shravan Somavara.

One of the prominent legends associated with the significance of Shravana Somavara is that of the churning of the ocean (Samudra Manthan) which happened during the month of Shravana. During the Samudra Manthan, Lord Shiva consumed the poison (halahala) that came out of the ocean to save the world , thus earning the title Neelkanth (the blue-throated one).

Shravana is considered the holiest month in the Hindu calendar for the worship of Lord Shiva. It is believed that during this time, the celestial alignment is such that the energy and grace of Lord Shiva are most accessible.
Devotees observe a strict fast on Mondays during the Shravan month. Some may follow a partial fast (eating fruits, milk, and light food), while others may observe a complete fast without any food or water.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Shravana Putrada Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Shravana Putrada Ekadashi, a revered occasion to seek blessings for fertility and childbirth.
observances.description_2:
Putrada Ekadashi is observed twice a year, during the Pausha and Shravana Shukla Paksha, falling respectively in December/January and July/August as per the Gregorian calender. In North India, the Pausha month Ekadashi is more popular, while in other regions, the Shravana month Ekadashi holds greater significance.

According to Hindu tradition, rituals performed at birth and death are highly significant. Sons are entrusted with the responsibility of conducting funeral rites, essential for the soul's liberation. Consequently, not having a male child can cause distress, particularly for those who believe in Hinduism's afterlife concept. Thus, couples aspiring for a son often observe Putrada Ekadashi fasting.

Shravan Shukla Paksha Ekadashi is also referred to as Pavitropana Ekadashi or Pavitra Ekadashi, particularly within the Vaishnava community.

Parana means breaking the fast. Ekadashi Parana is done after sunrise on the next day of Ekadashi fast. It is necessary to do Parana within Dwadashi Tithi unless Dwadashi is over before sunrise.

Sometimes, Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. Smartha (householders) with family are advised to fast on the first day only, while the alternate Ekadashi fasting is suggested for Sanyasis (renunciates), widows, and those seeking Moksha.

Fasting on both days is recommended for devoted seekers of Lord Vishnu's love and affection.

observances.name: Mangala Gauri Vratha - Chaturtha
observances.description_1: Fourth Mangalavara of Mangala Gauri Vratha. Mangala Gauri Vratha is a traditional fasting ritual observed by married women, dedicated to Goddess Gauri (an incarnation of Parvati), for marital bliss, happiness, and the well-being of their families.
observances.description_2:
Mangala Gauri Vratha is a sacred fasting ritual observed primarily by married women in various parts of India, particularly in Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, and Maharashtra. The vratha is dedicated to Goddess Gauri, also known as Mangala Gauri, who is considered an incarnation of Goddess Parvati and a symbol of marital harmony, fertility, and prosperity.

The observance of Mangala Gauri Vratha happens four or five times a year, taking place on tuesdays during the Shravana masa. On this day, married women wake up early, take a purifying bath, and adorn themselves in traditional attire and jewelry. They then create a sacred space in their homes where they place an image or idol of Goddess Gauri and decorate it with flowers, turmeric, and vermilion.

Devotees observe a strict fast throughout the day, abstaining from consuming food and water until the completion of the vratha. They offer prayers and perform special rituals to Goddess Gauri, seeking her blessings for the well-being and longevity of their husbands and families.

In the evening, after the completion of the vratha, married women break their fast by partaking in a meal prepared with great devotion and offered to the deity as prasad (blessed food).

deities.title: Parvathi
deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife, and is the mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

observances.name: Pavitropana Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Varalakshmi Vratam
observances.description_1: Varalakshmi Puja honors the goddess of wealth and prosperity, observed mainly by married women seeking blessings for their families.
observances.description_2:
Varalakshmi Puja, a significant occasion, honors the goddess of wealth and prosperity, Varalakshmi, an avatar of Goddess Mahalakshmi and the consort of Lord Vishnu. Legend has it that she emerged from the milky ocean, also known as Kshira Sagara, with a complexion and attire resembling the milky ocean itself.

The Varalakshmi form of the goddess is revered for granting boons and fulfilling devotees' desires, hence the name Vara Lakshmi, symbolizing the bestower of boons.

Varalakshmi Vrat, observed on the last Friday of Shravana Shukla Paksha, precedes Rakhi and Shravana Purnima. While it is recommended for both men and women, in regions like Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, and Maharashtra, it is primarily observed by married women seeking worldly pleasures for their families.

In states like Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, and Maharashtra, Varalakshmi Puja is widespread among married women, believed to be as auspicious as worshiping the eight Goddesses of Wealth. However, its popularity is relatively lower in North Indian states. Nonetheless, Varalakshmi Vratam remains a cherished occasion to seek blessings from Goddess Lakshmi, especially in South Indian regions.

observances.name: Raksha Bandhan
observances.description_1: Raksha Bandhan celebrates the cherished bond between siblings, symbolized by sisters tying Rakhi threads on their brothers' wrists.
observances.description_2:
Raksha Bandhan is a festival that celebrates the bond of love and affection between brothers and sisters. The term "Raksha Bandhan" translates to "bond of protection"

Raksha Bandhan is celebrated in Shravana masa on Purnima.

The central ritual of Raksha Bandhan involves the sister tying a sacred thread, known as a "rakhi," around her brother's wrist. The rakhi symbolizes the sister's love, prayers for her brother's well-being, and the promise of protection. In return, the brother offers gifts and a pledge to protect and support his sister throughout her life.

The best time to tie Rakhi on Raksha Bandhan is during Aparahna(Afternoon) which is late afternoon according to Hindu division of the day. If Aparahna time is not available then Pradosh time is also suitable to perform rituals related to Raksha Bandhan.

observances.name: Nariyeli Purnima
observances.description_1: Embracing coastal traditions, celebrating bounty with coconuts, and seeking divine blessings on the radiant full moon night.
observances.description_2:
"Nariyeli Purnima," Meaning "Coconut Full Moon Day," is a festival celebrated in Maharashtra, especially in coastal Maharashtra and the Konkani region.

This auspicious day falls on the Purnima in the Hindu month of Shravana (July-August).

Nariyeli Purnima is a unique coastal celebration that combines religious rituals with the coastal community's dependence on the sea.

On Nariyal Purnima, people worship God Varuna and especially offer Nariyal to the God of the sea. It is believed that the Puja offered to sea on the auspicious day of Shravana Purnima appease God and it protects fishermen from all sorts of untoward incidents.

Maharashtrian Brahmins, who perform ritualistic Shravani Upakarma on this day, observe Phalahar fasting on the day and eat only Nariyal i.e. the coconut during the fast. Hence, in Konkan and coastal Maharashtra, the day of Shravana Purnima is popularly known as Nariyal Purnima.

People also plant trees on the day of Nariyal Purnima to show their respect and gratitude towards nature. Nariyal Purnima is also pronounced as Narali Purnima and spelled as Nariyali Purnima.

observances.name: Yajur Upakarma
observances.description_1: Yajur Upakarma is an auspicious Hindu rituals marking the renewal of sacred threads among Brahmins.
observances.description_2:
Upakarma, which translates to "commencement," marks the ritualistic initiation of Vedic learning. In addition to studying Vedas on Upakarma day, Brahmins undergo rituals to change their Upanayana thread as part of Shrauta rituals.

Adherents of the Yajur Upakarma on the Purnima of Shravan masa.

In Tamil Nadu, Upakarma is referred to as Avani Avittam, and for first-timers, it is termed Thalai Avani Avittam. Meanwhile, in Andhra Pradesh, Upakarma coinciding with Shravana Purnima is known as Jandhyala Purnima.

Brahmins select Shravana Purnima for commencing Vedic studies because it aligns with Hayagriva Jayanti, the birth anniversary of Lord Hayagriva, considered an incarnation of Lord Vishnu. Legend has it that Lord Hayagriva restored all Vedas to Brahma.

observances.name: Rig Upakarma
observances.description_1: Rig Upakarma is an auspicious Hindu rituals marking the renewal of sacred threads among Brahmins.
observances.description_2:
Upakarma, which translates to "commencement," marks the ritualistic initiation of Vedic learning. In addition to studying Vedas on Upakarma day, Brahmins undergo rituals to change their Upanayana thread as part of Shrauta rituals.

Adherents of the Rigveda celebrate Upakarma on the day of Shravana Nakshatra in the month of Shravana.

In Tamil Nadu, Upakarma is referred to as Avani Avittam, and for first-timers, it is termed Thalai Avani Avittam. Meanwhile, in Andhra Pradesh, Upakarma coinciding with Shravana Purnima is known as Jandhyala Purnima.

Brahmins select Shravana Purnima for commencing Vedic studies because it aligns with Hayagriva Jayanti, the birth anniversary of Lord Hayagriva, considered an incarnation of Lord Vishnu. Legend has it that Lord Hayagriva restored all Vedas to Brahma.

observances.name: Purnima
observances.description_1: Purnima, signifies the full moon day, often marked by religious ceremonies and spiritual observances.
observances.description_2:
Purnima, or the Full Moon day, is a significant occasion in Indian culture, occurring monthly as the moon reaches its maximum brightness.

Purnima fasting is observed either on the Purnima day itself or the day before, known as Chaturdashi, depending on the timing of the Purnima Tithi (lunar day) from the previous day.

Purnima fasting on Chaturdashi occurs only when the Purnima begins during the Madhyahna period on the previous day. If Chaturdashi extends beyond Madhyahna, it's considered impure for Purnima fasting, even if Purnima begins later in the evening.

In North India, the full moon day is called Purnima, while in South India, it's referred to as Pournami or Pournima, and fasting on this day is known as Pournami Vratam, observed from sunrise until the moon is sighted.

observances.name: Kajari Teej
observances.description_1: Kajari Teej is dedicated to the worship of Goddess Parvati and Lord Shiva and is part of the monsoon festivities.
observances.description_2:
Badi Teej is celebrated on the Tritiya tithi of the Krishna Paksha in the month of Bhadrapada. It is celebrated primarily in North India, particularly in the states of Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, and Madhya Pradesh. It is one of the three Teej festivals observed by women, the others being Hariyali Teej and Hartalika Teej.

Teej honors the love and dedication of Goddess Parvati, who performed severe penance to win the love of Lord Shiva. Married women and unmarried girls observe a strict fast from sunrise to moonrise. The fast is broken after sighting the moon and performing the necessary rituals. Women observe this fast for the well-being, health, and prosperity of their husbands.

.

deities.title: Parvathi
deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife, and is the mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Heramba Sankashti
observances.description_1: Heramba Sankashti Chaturthi is a fasting day dedicated to worshipping the Heramba form of Lord Ganesha.
observances.description_2:
Heramba Sankashti falls on the Chaturthi thiti of the Krishna Paksha in the month of Shravana.

Heramba Sankashti is dedicated to the worship of Lord Ganesha, seeking his blessings for the removal of obstacles, success in endeavors, and overall prosperity. On this day, devotees of Lord Ganesha observe a strict fast from sunrise to moonrise and consume only fruits and roots or tubers.

deities.title: Ganesha
deities.description: Ganesha is the elephant-headed deity known as the remover of obstacles and the lord of beginnings. Son of Shiva and Parvati, he is commonly depicted with a broken tusk and riding a mouse. Ganesha is revered for his wisdom and is often invoked first in Hindu rituals to ensure success and clear obstacles. He also symbolizes the patronage of arts and sciences.

observances.name: Sankasta Chaturthi
observances.description_1: Sankashti Chaturthi is a significant day for Lord Ganesha devotees, observed to seek his blessings and overcome obstacles.
observances.description_2:
In the Hindu calendar, each lunar month includes two Chaturthi Tithi. The one following the full moon, known as Purnimasi, during Krishna Paksha is called Sankashti Chaturthi, while the one following the new moon, known as Amavasya, during Shukla Paksha is called Vinayaka Chaturthi.

If Sankashti Chaturthi falls on a Tuesday, it is revered as Angarki Chaturthi, considered highly auspicious, particularly in Western and Southern India, notably Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu.

During Sankashti Chaturthi, devotees of Lord Ganesha observe a fast from sunrise to moonrise. Sankashti, meaning deliverance during troubled times, signifies the belief that observing this fast can remove obstacles, as Lord Ganesha is revered as the remover of obstacles.

The fast is observed strictly, with consumption limited to fruits, roots, and vegetable products. Typical foods include Sabudana Khichadi, potatoes, and peanuts, with devotees breaking their fast after sighting the moon.

In North India, Sankashti Chaturthi in the month of Magha is known as Sakat Chauth, while Vinayaka Chaturthi in the month of Bhadrapada is celebrated as Ganesha Chaturthi worldwide as Lord Ganesha's birthday.

Among Tamil Hindus, Sankashti Chaturthi is referred to as Ganesh Sankatahara or Sankatahara Chaturthi.

observances.name: Balaram Jayanti
observances.description_1: Balaram Jayanti celebrates the birth anniversary of Lord Balarama, Lord Krishna's elder brother.
observances.description_2:
Lord Balarama, elder brother of Lord Krishna and is an incarnation of the snake Lord Vishnu would sleep on, Aadi Sesha.

Lord Balarama embodies strength and power. It is believed that devotees who worship Lord Balaram and observe Balaram Jayanti Vrat are bestowed with healthy life with physical strength.

On the eve of Balaram Jayanti, the devotees wake up early morning, take a bath and start preparing for the Puja. The idols of Lord Krishna and Lord Balaram are placed and decorated with new clothes. The celebration takes place at all those temples where Lord Balarama and Lord Krishna are worshipped.

observances.name: Randhan Chhath
observances.description_1: Randhan Chhath, a Gujarati festival, involves cooking and preparing food ahead of Chhath Puja celebration.
observances.description_2:
Randhan Chhath is a unique festival celebrated by the Gujarati community.

It is marked one day before Shitala Satam in the calendar. Shitala Satam is observed on Saptami of Krishna Paksha (waning phase of the moon) during Shravana month.

Randhan Chhath is not an independent festival but part of Shitala Satam, a religious festival dedicated to Goddess Shitala Devi. It is a preparatory day for Shitala Satam Puja. As all sorts of cooking are prohibited on the day of Shitala Satam, most Gujarati families make food arrangements for the next day on Randhan Chhath. Due to the important day for cooking, the day has got its name Randhan Chhath i.e. cooking on the sixth day.

deities.title: Shitala Devi
deities.description: Shitala Devi is the goddess of smallpox, disease, and healing. Known for her powers to cure epidemics and illnesses, she is revered as the protector against infectious diseases, particularly those related to pox. Devotees invoke her for protection from sickness, health, and healing, and to gain relief from pestilences and outbreaks.

observances.name: Krishna Janmashtami
observances.description_1: A festival celebrating Lord Krishna's birth.
observances.description_2:
Krishna Janmashtami, celebrates the birth of Lord Krishna, the eighth avatar of Vishnu, observed all over India. Falling on the eighth day (Astami) of the Krishna Paksha in Bhadrapada masa, devotees honour this occasion with fasting rituals and grand feasts at midnight, believed to mark Krishna's birth time. The festivities, comprising dances, devotional songs, and cultural performances, extend into the early hours of the morning.

Devotees preparing for the fast should have only one meal the day before and vow to observe a day-long fast, breaking it the next day after both Rohini Nakshatra and Ashtami Tithi conclude. Traditional Krishna Puja rituals, encompassing all sixteen steps of the Shodashopachara Puja Vidhi, are performed at midnight.

Fasting guidelines advise abstaining from grains until the fast is broken after sunrise the following day. Parana, or breaking the fast, should occur when both Ashtami Tithi and Rohini Nakshatra conclude. If this extends beyond the sunset, fasting devotees may break their fast during the day once either ends. In some cases, fasting may extend for two complete days, with the fast-breaking ceremony held at sunrise on the second day, as suggested by Hindu religious texts.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

observances.name: Shitala Satam
observances.description_1: Shitala Satam, celebrates the goddess Shitala Mata, known for protection against diseases and smallpox.
observances.description_2:
Shitala Satam is celebrated predominantly in the state of Gujarat, India. This festival is dedicated to Goddess Shitala, the deity believed to have the power to protect individuals from diseases, especially those associated with the heat of summer.

Shitala Satam is observed on the seventh day(Satam) of Krishna Paksha during Shravana masa.

The most significant ritual, which is followed on the day of Shitala Satam, is that no fresh food is cooked in the family. The food which is consumed on the day of Shitala Satam should be cold and stale. Hence most Gujarati families prepare special food on the previous day which is popularly known as Randhan Chhath.

deities.title: Shitala Devi
deities.description: Shitala Devi is the goddess of smallpox, disease, and healing. Known for her powers to cure epidemics and illnesses, she is revered as the protector against infectious diseases, particularly those related to pox. Devotees invoke her for protection from sickness, health, and healing, and to gain relief from pestilences and outbreaks.

observances.name: Mahakali Jayanti
observances.description_1: Mahakali Jayanti is dedicated to the worship of Goddess Mahakali, an incarnation of Goddess Durga and one of the ten Mahavidya Goddesses.
observances.description_2:
Mahakali Jayanti is a celebration of the powerful and protective aspects of Goddess Mahakali. She represents the fierce and powerful aspect of the divine feminine.

The most well-known origin story of Mahakali is found in the Devi Mahatmya, a hindu philisophical text. Goddess Durga had to take the form of Mahakali to combat the demon Raktabeeja. Raktabeeja had a boon that every drop of his blood that fell on the ground would spawn a new demon. To defeat him, Mahakali caught his blood with her tongue before it could reach the ground, preventing any new demons from arising. She ultimately drained him of his blood and killed him, symbolizing the destruction of evil and the protection of righteousness.

Mahakali is depicted with a garland of skulls, and multiple arms wielding weapons, is a powerful representation of her role as the destroyer of evil. This imagery is often depicted in temple art, sculptures, and paintings.

observances.name: Krishna Janmashtami
observances.description_1: A festival celebrating Lord Krishna's birth.
observances.description_2:
Krishna Janmashtami, celebrates the birth of Lord Krishna, the eighth avatar of Vishnu, observed all over India. Falling on the eighth day (Astami) of the Krishna Paksha in Bhadrapada masa, devotees honour this occasion with fasting rituals and grand feasts at midnight, believed to mark Krishna's birth time. The festivities, comprising dances, devotional songs, and cultural performances, extend into the early hours of the morning.

Devotees preparing for the fast should have only one meal the day before and vow to observe a day-long fast, breaking it the next day after both Rohini Nakshatra and Ashtami Tithi conclude. Traditional Krishna Puja rituals, encompassing all sixteen steps of the Shodashopachara Puja Vidhi, are performed at midnight.

Fasting guidelines advise abstaining from grains until the fast is broken after sunrise the following day. Parana, or breaking the fast, should occur when both Ashtami Tithi and Rohini Nakshatra conclude. If this extends beyond the sunset, fasting devotees may break their fast during the day once either ends. In some cases, fasting may extend for two complete days, with the fast-breaking ceremony held at sunrise on the second day, as suggested by Hindu religious texts.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

observances.name: Dahikala Handi
observances.description_1: "Dahi Handi" is a post-Janmashtami celebration where participants form human pyramids to reach curd-filled earthen pots.
observances.description_2:
Dahi Handi, a celebrated event in Maharashtra and Goa, takes place on the day following Krishna Janmashtami, also known as Gokulashtami. In this tradition, "Dahi" refers to curd, and "Handi" signifies the earthen pots used to store dairy products, also known as Gopalakala in Maharashtra.

The festivity commemorates the playful nature of Lord Krishna, who, in his youth, was notorious for his love of curd and butter. As the young Krishna and his friends sought to satisfy their cravings for milk products, the local women devised a clever defence, suspending the Handis from the ceiling to keep them out of reach.

To outsmart the women, Krishna introduced the idea of forming human pyramids to reach the Handis. This creative solution became an enduring part of Indian folklore, reenacted each Janmashtami by groups of boys. The Handis are often placed at considerable heights, adding to the challenge, and women may attempt to disrupt the human pyramids with water or slippery substances.

In Mumbai, Dahi Handi has evolved into a competitive sport, drawing hundreds of teams annually, with famous personalities endorsing the event. The event is often accompanied by the spirited chant, "Govinda Aala Re!"

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

observances.name: Goga Navami
observances.description_1: Goga Navami is dedicated to the worship of Gogaji, a folk deity.
observances.description_2:
Goga Navami is celebrated on Navami thiti of the Krishna Paksha in the month of Bhadrapada.Gogaji, also called as Jahar Veer Gogga is a popular folk deity who is worshipped in the northern states of India, especially Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan and Punjab.

Gogaji is venerated as a warrior saint and a protector, especially against snake bites. According to legend, Gogaji was born to Queen Bachhal and King Jewar Singh. His birth was believed to be a blessing from Guru Gorakhnath, and he exhibited divine powers from a young age. Gogaji is known for his miraculous powers, especially his ability to control and charm snakes. His bravery and heroism in protecting people from snake bites and other dangers are celebrated through various stories and folklore.

On Goga Navami, processions are organized where devotees carry images or idols of Gogaji, accompanied by singing, dancing, and music. Traditional folk performances, including songs and dances that narrate the life and miracles of Gogaji, are an integral part of the celebrations.

observances.name: Masik Sankranti
observances.description_1: Masik Sankranti marks the transition of the Sun into a new zodiac sign each month, observed with spiritual significance.
observances.description_2:
Sankranti refers to the transmigration of the sun from one rashi (zodiac) to another in Indian astronomy
The observance revolves around sun’s transition into new rashi (zodiac sign), symoblizing the end of one solar month and the beginning of another.

Malik Sankranti’s including the Makara Sankranthi is associated with Surya pravesh (Sun’s entry) into each rashi. There are twelve rashis (12 signs) namely Mekh (Mekha), Virkh, Mithun, Kark, Singh-Simha, Kanya, Tula,Vrischik, Dhan, Makara, Kumbh and Meena.

While significance and rituals may vary for each Masik Sankranti, they are generally considered as times to offer prayers, seek blessings and make positive changes in one’s life.

Sankranti days are considered good for charity activities and all auspicious ceremonies are avoided on the day of Sankranti(s).

observances.name: Aja Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: Shravana Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:

observances.name: Varaha Jayanti
observances.description_1: Varaha Jayanti celebrates the incarnation of Lord Vishnu as Varaha, his third avatar on earth.
observances.description_2:
Varaha Jayanti is celebrated on Tritiya Tithi of Shukla Paksha in the month of Bhadrapada. It celebrates the birth of Vishnu as Varaha (boar) to save the world from Hiranyaksha.

Varaha lifted the earth out of the cosmic ocean when the asura Hiranyaksha stole the earth and hid her in the primordial waters. Varaha killed Hiranyaksha, and retrieved the earth from the ocean, lifting it on his tusks. Varaha is depicted as a boar with a boar's head and a human body.

Special poojas are organized in Lord Vishnu temples across India on the occasion of Varaha Jayanti. It is believed that worshipping Lord Varaha bestows devotees with immense riches and good health.

deities.title: Varaha
deities.description: Varaha is the third avatar of the Hindu god Vishnu, in the form of an Indian boar. Varaha is celebrated for his heroic rescue of the Earth (personified as the goddess Bhudevi) from the cosmic ocean. According to Hindu mythology, the demon Hiranyaksha had submerged the Earth into the depths of the primordial waters. In response, Vishnu took the form of a colossal boar, descended into the ocean, and after a fierce battle, defeated Hiranyaksha. Varaha then lifted the Earth on his tusks and restored her to her rightful place in the universe.

observances.name: Swarna Gowri Vratha
observances.description_1: A golden day of devotion and auspicious celebrations, honoring the divine goddess Gowri.
observances.description_2:
Swarna Gowri Vratha is a significant Hindu festival observed primarily in the southern states of India, especially Karnataka and parts of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu. This auspicious occasion is dedicated to Goddess Gowri, an incarnation of Goddess Parvati and the mother of Lord Ganesha.

Swarna Gowri Vratha is observed on the third day of the Shukla Paksha of Bhadrapada masa (usually August or September), a day before the popular Ganesh Chaturthi festival.

The name "Swarna Gowri" translates to "Golden Gowri," symbolizing the goddess's radiance and purity. She is worshipped as the giver of marital bliss, fertility, and overall well-being.

One significant aspect of the festival is the preparation of a clay idol of Goddess Gowri. Married women observe fasts on this day and participate in the rituals.

The festival culminates with the immersion of the Gowri idol in water, symbolizing the departure of the goddess to her maternal home, and it is believed that she returns with her son, Lord Ganesha, during Ganesh Chaturthi.
The same festival is known as Hartalika Teej in Maharashtra and other North Indian states.

deities.title: Parvathi
deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife, and is the mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

observances.name: Ganesha Chaturthi
observances.description_1: 10-day celebration honoring Lord Ganesha with rituals, pujas, and community events, celebrated in various Indian states.
observances.description_2:
Ganesh Chaturthi is a 10-day Hindu festival that celebrates the birth of Lord Ganesha. The festival begins on the fourth day of the Shukla Paksha in Bhadrapada masa, which falls in August or September.

Ganesha Chaturthi is celebrated with great enthusiasm throughout India, with particularly grand celebrations in the states of Maharashtra, Gujarat, Karnataka, and Andhra Pradesh. Maharashtra, in particular, is known for hosting elaborate processions and community events during the festival.

Ganesha Chaturthi begins with the installation of clay idols of Lord Ganesha in homes and community pandals. Devotees perform elaborate pujas (ritual worship), recite sacred hymns, and offer a variety of sweets, fruits, and flowers to the deity.

Ganesh Puja is preferred during Madhyahna as it is believed that Lord Ganesh was born during Madhyahna Kala. Madhyahna Kala is equivalent to midday according to the Hindu division of the day.

As per Hindu time-keeping, the time duration between sunrise to sunset is divided into five equal parts. These five parts are known as Pratahkala, Sangava, Madhyahna, Aparahna and Sayankal. Ganapati Sthapana and Ganapati Puja on Ganesha Chaturthi are done during the Madhyahna part of the day .

On the tenth day, grand processions carry the Ganesha idols through the streets, accompanied by music and dance, leading to the immersion of the idols in water bodies. This symbolizes the return of Lord Ganesha to his celestial abode.

deities.title: Ganesha
deities.description: Ganesha is the elephant-headed deity known as the remover of obstacles and the lord of beginnings. Son of Shiva and Parvati, he is commonly depicted with a broken tusk and riding a mouse. Ganesha is revered for his wisdom and is often invoked first in Hindu rituals to ensure success and clear obstacles. He also symbolizes the patronage of arts and sciences.

observances.name: Rishi Panchami
observances.description_1: Rishi Panchami is dedicated to honoring the Sapta Rishis (seven sages) .
observances.description_2:
Rishi Panchami falls on the fifth day of the waxing moon in the Hindu calendar month of Bhadrapada. It is usually two days after Hartalika Teej and one day after Ganesh Chaturthi.
It is observed as a day of fasting by women to pay homage to the Sapta Rishis (seven sages) - Kashyapa, Atri, Bharadvaja, Vishvamitra, Gautama Maharishi, Jamadagni, and Vasishtha.

In Hindu tradition, menstruating women are forbidden to undertake religious activities or involve themselves in domestic work. If this is violated, it leads to Rajaswala Dosha. It is believed that fasting on this day will lead to purification of Rajaswala Dosha.

Rishi Panchami is famous among the Nepali Hindus.

observances.name: Sashti
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Sasthi
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Radhashtami
observances.description_1: Radhashtami commemorates the birth anniversary of the Goddess Radha, the chief consort of Lord Krishna.
observances.description_2:
Radhashtami is the birth anniversary of Radha, who is the reincarnation of Goddess Lakshmi. It falls on Ashtami, Shukla Paksha of Bhadrapada masa.

The celebrations are grand in Vrindavan, Mathura and in Barsana, which is the birthplace of Radha. As Lord Krishna was very fond of Radha ji, his worship is incomplete without worshipping Goddess Radha.

On this day, devotees observe fast and Goddess Radha is worshipped during Madhyahna Kala which is noon time. Chanting ‘Radha Gayatri Mantra’ or the ‘Radha Ashtami Mantra’ on this day helps devotees to overcome all thier obstacles.

observances.name: Durva Ashtami Puja
observances.description_1: Durva Ashtami is dedicated to the worship of Durva Grass, an essential in nearly all Hindu rituals.
observances.description_2:
Durva Ashtami Puja is observed on Ashtami thiti of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Bhadrapada. Durva Ashtami festival is mainly celebrated in West Bengal.


Durva grass is considered sacred and is especially significant in the worship of Lord Ganesha. Durva grass is believed to possess purifying qualities and is used in various rituals for protection and blessings. It is also associated with health, prosperity, and longevity.A specific number of Durva grass blades, usually 21, are tied together and offered to Lord Ganesha while reciting mantras and prayers. The grass is placed on the idol or image of Ganesha.

On Durva Ashtami Puja, women observe a fast and Durva grass is worshipped which is believed to bring health, prosperity, and longevity.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

deities.title: Ganesha
deities.description: Ganesha is the elephant-headed deity known as the remover of obstacles and the lord of beginnings. Son of Shiva and Parvati, he is commonly depicted with a broken tusk and riding a mouse. Ganesha is revered for his wisdom and is often invoked first in Hindu rituals to ensure success and clear obstacles. He also symbolizes the patronage of arts and sciences.

observances.name: Parsva Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Parsva Ekadashi is a fasting day dedicated to Lord Vishnu that falls in the month of Bhadrapada (Shukla Paksha).
observances.description_2:
Parsva Ekadashi is observed on the Ekadashi of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Bhadrapada.

According to Hindu mythology, during the Chaturmas period (the four months when Lord Vishnu is believed to be in yogic sleep), Lord Vishnu turns from his left side to his right side on the day of Parsva Ekadashi.

Devotees observe a strict fast on Parsva Ekadashi, abstaining from grains, beans, and certain vegetables. Some may follow a complete fast without food and water, while others may consume fruits, milk, and water. The fast begins at sunrise on Ekadashi and ends after sunrise on the following day, Dwadashi.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

deities.title: Sri Panduranga
deities.description: Sri Panduranga is a form of the Vishnu in his Krishna avatar. He worshipped primarily in the Indian states of Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Andhra Pradesh. The Varkari sect, a devotional movement centered around Panduranga, emphasizes the values of humility, devotion, and community service. He embodies a youthful, compassionate aspect of Lord Krishna.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.
