observances.name: Vamana Jayanti
observances.description_1: Vamana Jayanti celebrates the incarnation of Lord Vishnu as Lord Vamana, his fifth avatar.
observances.description_2:
Vamana Jayanti is observed on the Dwadashi tithi of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Bhadrapada.
Lord Vamana is the fifth incarnation of Lord Vishnu and is depicted as a dwarf Brahmin.

King Mahabali was a powerful and benevolent ruler who had conquered the three worlds. The gods, feeling threatened by his power, approached Lord Vishnu for help. Lord Vishnu incarnated as Vamana, a dwarf Brahmin, and approached Mahabali during a yagna. He requested three paces of land as alms. Mahabali, known for his generosity, agreed.
Vamana then assumed a gigantic form, covering the earth with one step, the heavens with the second, and with nowhere to place the third step, Mahabali offered his own head. Vamana placed his foot on Mahabali's head. However, impressed by Mahabali's devotion, Vishnu granted him the boon to visit his people once a year, which is celebrated as Onam in Kerala.

On Vamana Jayanti, Panchopachara or Shodashopachara Puja of golden or clay idol of Vamana is performed. Vamana Jayanti Vrat Katha is also narrated. The significance of Vamana Jayanti increases multifold if it coincides with Shravana Nakshatra.

observances.name: Bhuvaneshwari Jayanti
observances.description_1: Bhuvaneshwari Jayanti is dedicated to the worship of Goddess Bhuvaneshwari, one of the ten Mahavidya Goddesses.
observances.description_2:
Bhuvaneshwari Jayanti celebrates Goddess Bhuvaneshwari who is considered the goddess of the universe. She represents the creation and sustenance aspect of the divine feminine.

Bhuvaneshwari is identified as Adi Parashakti in the Devi Bhagavata Purana. Bhuvaneshwari is closely associated with other forms of the divine feminine, including Durga, Parvati, and Lakshmi. She is considered a compassionate and nurturing goddess who provides for the needs of her devotees.

Bhuvaneshwari is often depicted as a beautiful goddess with a serene expression, seated on a lotus or throne, symbolizing her supreme power and authority over the universe. She has four arms, holding a noose (pasha), a goad (ankusha), and making gestures of granting boons (varada mudra) and dispelling fear (abhaya mudra).

observances.name: Onam Thiruvonam
observances.description_1: A grand harvest festival in Kerala, commemorating the annual return of the legendary King Mahabali
observances.description_2:
Onam Thiruvonam is the most significant and widely celebrated festival in the southern Indian state of Kerala. This ten-day harvest festival holds cultural and religious importance, marked by vibrant festivities, traditional rituals, and a spirit of unity and festivity.

Onam falls in the month of Chingam, which is the first month according to the Malayalam Calendar. The Celebrations mark the Malayalam New Year.

While Onam is a harvest festival with agricultural roots, it is also associated with the mythical King Mahabali. The festival commemorates the reign of King Mahabali, a benevolent and just ruler who is believed to have visited Kerala during Onam to ensure the well-being of his people.

Onam Thiruvonam is marked by several rituals and customs. Homes are adorned with intricate flower carpets known as "Pookalam." Traditional Onam Sadya, a grand feast, is prepared with a variety of vegetarian dishes served on a banana leaf. The Snake Boat Race (Vallam Kali), Kaikottikali dance, and Pulikali (tiger dance) are some of the cultural events that add to the festive spirit.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Anant Chaturdashi
observances.description_1: Embracing Lord Vishnu's eternal blessings on the auspicious fourteenth day.
observances.description_2:
Anant Chaturdashi holds immense significance in the Hindu religion. The occasion is also popularly known as Anant Chaudas. The sacred day is dedicated to Lord Vishnu who is called as the Lord of several avatars and the preserver of the universe. Lord Anant is one of the incarnations (avatar) of Lord Vishnu.

The festivity of Ananta Chaturdashi is celebrated on the Chaturdashi in the Bhadrapada masa during the Shukla Paksha.

Lord Vishnu is also popular with its other name Anant which signifies eternal and the word Chaturdashi means fourteen. On the eve of Anant Chaturdashi, usually, men keep an Anant Chaturdashi fast to get relieved from all their past sins and for the wellbeing of their children and family. The fast is observed for a continuous period of 14 years in a row to get bestowed with the divine blessings of Lord Vishnu and to achieve their lost prosperity and wealth.

deities.title: Ganesha
deities.description: Ganesha is the elephant-headed deity known as the remover of obstacles and the lord of beginnings. Son of Shiva and Parvati, he is commonly depicted with a broken tusk and riding a mouse. Ganesha is revered for his wisdom and is often invoked first in Hindu rituals to ensure success and clear obstacles. He also symbolizes the patronage of arts and sciences.

observances.name: Ganesh Visarjan
observances.description_1: A bittersweet farewell to lord Ganesha, marking the grand culmination of joyful festivities.
observances.description_2:
Ganesh Visarjan, also known as Ganpati Visarjan or immersion, is the concluding and emotionally charged ritual of the Ganesh Chaturthi festival, which celebrates the birth of Lord Ganesha, the remover of obstacles.

Ganesh Visarjan occurs on the last day of the Ganesh Chaturthi festival, typically on Anant Chaturdashi, the fourteenth day of Shukla Paksha in Bhadrapada masa, usually falling in August or September.

The Ganesh Visarjan rituals involve the immersion of Ganesha idols in water bodies, such as rivers, lakes, or the sea. The immersion processions are characterized by lively music, dance, and devotees chanting hymns in praise of Lord Ganesha.

Devotees carry the Ganesha idols, often elaborately crafted and decorated, in a procession leading to the immersion site. The farewell is an emotional and festive affair, with fervent prayers and expressions of love for Lord Ganesha

observances.name: Indrajaatra
observances.description_1: Indrajaatra honours Lord Indra, the celestial king and rain god.
observances.description_2:
Indrajaatra lasts for eight days and is an intergral part of Telugu Hindu culture.

Legend has it that Lord Indra, disguised as a human, visited the Kathmandu Valley seeking a special flower. The locals, unaware of his true identity, captured him. After his mother intervened, he was released, and Indrajaatra was established to appease him and ensure bountiful rains and harvests.

Hindus believe that Indrajaatra is a time to appease not only Indra, but also other celestial beings responsible for the well-being of the world. Devotees offer prayers for good health, prosperity, and a bountiful harvest. The festival also commemorates the victory of good over evil, highlighting the triumph of righteousness.

While widely known as Indrajaatra, the festival has different names in other regions. In Nepal, it's called 'Yenya' meaning 'celebration.' In Sikkim, it's known as 'Indra Jatra' and is celebrated by the Nepalese Hindu community.

observances.name: Narayana Guru Jayanti
observances.description_1: Narayana Guru Jayanti celebrates the birth anniversary of Narayana Guru, a revered spiritual leader and social reformer.
observances.description_2:
The birthday of Sree Narayana Guru is a public holiday in the Indian state of Kerala. However, due to the great popularity of Sree Narayana, his birth anniversary is also celebrated all over the world.

Sree Narayana is considered to the one of the greatest of all saints and social reformers who ever lived in all India. He is most famous for opposing the caste system in India, although he adhered to traditional Hinduism in most other ways.

On Sree Narayana Jayanti, there are “harmony parades”, floral tributes, public prayers, special Narayana conferences, and feasts to which the poor are invited, in the state of Kerala.

observances.name: Purnima
observances.description_1: Purnima, signifies the full moon day, often marked by religious ceremonies and spiritual observances.
observances.description_2:
Purnima, or the Full Moon day, is a significant occasion in Indian culture, occurring monthly as the moon reaches its maximum brightness.

Purnima fasting is observed either on the Purnima day itself or the day before, known as Chaturdashi, depending on the timing of the Purnima Tithi (lunar day) from the previous day.

Purnima fasting on Chaturdashi occurs only when the Purnima begins during the Madhyahna period on the previous day. If Chaturdashi extends beyond Madhyahna, it's considered impure for Purnima fasting, even if Purnima begins later in the evening.

In North India, the full moon day is called Purnima, while in South India, it's referred to as Pournami or Pournima, and fasting on this day is known as Pournami Vratam, observed from sunrise until the moon is sighted.

observances.name: Chandra Grahana
observances.description_1: Lunar Eclipse is a celestial event when the Earth comes between the Sun and the Moon, casting a shadow on the Moon.
observances.description_2:
If a Lunar Eclipse spans across two different dates, the Eclipse Day should be when the maximum eclipse occurs.

In Hinduism, Lunar Eclipses hold significance only if visible to the naked eye. Penumbral Lunar Eclipses, invisible to the naked eye, have no associated rituals. Rituals are only observed if the Lunar Eclipse is visible during the Umbral Phase. Most Hindu calendars do not list Penumbral Eclipses.

If a Lunar Eclipse is not visible in your city but is visible nearby, it should not be observed. Precautions advised during Sutak should only be taken if the Lunar Eclipse is visible in your city, regardless of visibility due to weather conditions.

Sutak, an inauspicious time before Solar and Lunar Eclipses, is believed to contaminate the Earth's atmosphere. It lasts for 4 Prahars (12 hours) before a Solar Eclipse and 3 Prahars (9 hours) before a Lunar Eclipse, during which food consumption is prohibited.

During Sutak, all food, solid or liquid, is prohibited, except for children, the sick, and the elderly, for whom restrictions are limited to a single Prahar (3 hours). Pregnant women are advised to avoid venturing out during the Eclipse to prevent potential harm to the unborn child.

Various activities such as oil massage, drinking water, and engaging in sexual activities are prohibited during an Eclipse. After the Eclipse, cooked food should be discarded, and only freshly prepared food consumed. Items like grains and pickles that cannot be discarded should be protected with Kusha grass or Tulasi leaves. It is also recommended to bathe and make offerings to Brahmins after the Eclipse for spiritual benefit.

eclipse_info.description: It is advised to not consume any food or liquids during this time.

observances.name: Sankasta Chaturthi
observances.description_1: Sankashti Chaturthi is a significant day for Lord Ganesha devotees, observed to seek his blessings and overcome obstacles.
observances.description_2:
In the Hindu calendar, each lunar month includes two Chaturthi Tithi. The one following the full moon, known as Purnimasi, during Krishna Paksha is called Sankashti Chaturthi, while the one following the new moon, known as Amavasya, during Shukla Paksha is called Vinayaka Chaturthi.

If Sankashti Chaturthi falls on a Tuesday, it is revered as Angarki Chaturthi, considered highly auspicious, particularly in Western and Southern India, notably Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu.

During Sankashti Chaturthi, devotees of Lord Ganesha observe a fast from sunrise to moonrise. Sankashti, meaning deliverance during troubled times, signifies the belief that observing this fast can remove obstacles, as Lord Ganesha is revered as the remover of obstacles.

The fast is observed strictly, with consumption limited to fruits, roots, and vegetable products. Typical foods include Sabudana Khichadi, potatoes, and peanuts, with devotees breaking their fast after sighting the moon.

In North India, Sankashti Chaturthi in the month of Magha is known as Sakat Chauth, while Vinayaka Chaturthi in the month of Bhadrapada is celebrated as Ganesha Chaturthi worldwide as Lord Ganesha's birthday.

Among Tamil Hindus, Sankashti Chaturthi is referred to as Ganesh Sankatahara or Sankatahara Chaturthi.

observances.name: Maha Bharani
observances.description_1: Maha Bharani, known as Aadi Pathinettam Perukku in Tamil Nadu is dedicated to the Goddess Kali. "Aadi" refers to the Tamil month, "Pathinettam" means the 18th day, and "Perukku" means a grand festival.
observances.description_2:
Maha Bharani, known as Aadi Pathinettam Perukku in Tamil Nadu, is a special day dedicated to the goddess Kali. It is celebrated when the Bharani Nakshatra aligns with certain lunar phases, particularly during the Tamil month of Aadi.

On this day, devotees honor Kali's fierce and protective aspects through various rituals. Devotees perform special prayers and pujas, often creating an idol or image of Kali. They offer flowers, fruits, and traditional sweets, chanting mantras that highlight Kali's power and benevolence.

Maha Bharani highlights Kali's role as a powerful protector and destroyer of evil. The festival reinforces themes of strength, protection, and spiritual growth, encouraging devotees to seek Kali's blessings for overcoming obstacles and achieving personal and spiritual well-being.

deities.title: Parvathi
deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife, and is the mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

deities.title: Durga
deities.description: Goddess Durga is a major deity in Hinduism, worshipped as a principal aspect of the mother goddess Mahadevi. She was created by the combined energies of the gods Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, who infused their divine powers into her to combat the demon, Mahishasura. She is celebrated for her strength and  her role as a fierce warrior against evil and injustice. Durga is often depicted as a beautiful woman with ten arms, each holding a weapon or symbol. She rides a lion or tiger.

observances.name: Jivitputrika Vrat
observances.description_1: Jivitputrika Vrat is a fasting day observed by mothers for the well-being and long life of their children.
observances.description_2:
Jivitputrika Vrat falls on the Ashtami thiti of the Krishna Paksha month of Ashwin. This festival is particularly celebrated in the Indian states of Bihar, Jharkhand, Uttar Pradesh, and parts of Nepal.

The primary significance of Jivitputrika Vrat is for mothers to pray for the health, prosperity, and long life of their children. The festival begins with a ritual called Nahay Khay on the Saptami, where they purify themselves by taking a holy bath and then consuming a single meal. This marks the preparation for the fast. The fast observed on Jivitputrika Vrat is rigorous. They abstain from food and water (Nirjala Vrat) throughout the day and night. On the morning of Navami, after performing the concluding rituals, they break their fast with a special meal, often shared with family members.

observances.name: Indira Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Indira Ekadashi is a fasting day dedicated to Lord Vishnu that falls in the month of Ashwin (Krishna Paksha).
observances.description_2:
Indira Ekadashi is observed on the Ekadashi of the Krishna Paksha in the month of Ashwini. It is particularly significant for those who wish to offer liberation to the souls of their ancestors.

According to Hindu mythology, the legend of Indira Ekadashi is associated with King Indrasena, who ruled the kingdom of Mahishmati. One day, the sage Narada visited the king and informed him that his deceased father was suffering in the afterlife due to his past sins.To offer relief to his father's soul, the sage advised King Indrasena to observe a fast on Indira Ekadashi and perform the necessary rituals. The king followed the sage's advice with utmost devotion. As a result, Lord Vishnu was pleased with the king's devotion and granted liberation to the soul of his father, relieving him from the suffering in the afterlife.

Devotees observe a strict fast on Indira Ekadashi, abstaining from grains. Some may follow a complete fast without food and water, while others may consume fruits, milk, and water. The fast begins at sunrise on Ekadashi and ends after sunrise on the following day, Dwadashi.

observances.name: Vishwakarma Puja
observances.description_1: Honoring the divine artisan Lord Vishwakarma, a sacred celebration of creativity and craftsmanship.
observances.description_2:
Vishwakarma Puja is a revered Hindu festival dedicated to Lord Vishwakarma, the divine architect and craftsman. Celebrated mainly in the eastern states of India, especially in West Bengal, Assam, Tripura, Uttar Pradesh and Bihar.

Vishwakarma Puja is observed on the last day of the Bengali month Bhadra.

Lord Vishwakarma, the celestial architect and divine craftsman, is worshipped on Vishwakarma Puja. Artisans, craftsmen, engineers, and workers seek his blessings for skill, creativity, and success in their respective trades. The festival holds special significance for those involved in industrial and manufacturing activities.

Vishwakarma Puja begins with the installation of idols or images of Lord Vishwakarma in workshops, factories, and industrial areas. Special pujas are performed, invoking the blessings of the divine craftsman for skilful craftsmanship, safety, and prosperity.

observances.name: Indira Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Indira Ekadashi is a fasting day dedicated to Lord Vishnu that falls in the month of Ashwin (Krishna Paksha).
observances.description_2:
Indira Ekadashi is observed on the Ekadashi of the Krishna Paksha in the month of Ashwini. It is particularly significant for those who wish to offer liberation to the souls of their ancestors.

According to Hindu mythology, the legend of Indira Ekadashi is associated with King Indrasena, who ruled the kingdom of Mahishmati. One day, the sage Narada visited the king and informed him that his deceased father was suffering in the afterlife due to his past sins.To offer relief to his father's soul, the sage advised King Indrasena to observe a fast on Indira Ekadashi and perform the necessary rituals. The king followed the sage's advice with utmost devotion. As a result, Lord Vishnu was pleased with the king's devotion and granted liberation to the soul of his father, relieving him from the suffering in the afterlife.

Devotees observe a strict fast on Indira Ekadashi, abstaining from grains. Some may follow a complete fast without food and water, while others may consume fruits, milk, and water. The fast begins at sunrise on Ekadashi and ends after sunrise on the following day, Dwadashi.

observances.name: Masik Sankranti
observances.description_1: Masik Sankranti marks the transition of the Sun into a new zodiac sign each month, observed with spiritual significance.
observances.description_2:
Sankranti refers to the transmigration of the sun from one rashi (zodiac) to another in Indian astronomy
The observance revolves around sun’s transition into new rashi (zodiac sign), symoblizing the end of one solar month and the beginning of another.

Malik Sankranti’s including the Makara Sankranthi is associated with Surya pravesh (Sun’s entry) into each rashi. There are twelve rashis (12 signs) namely Mekh (Mekha), Virkh, Mithun, Kark, Singh-Simha, Kanya, Tula,Vrischik, Dhan, Makara, Kumbh and Meena.

While significance and rituals may vary for each Masik Sankranti, they are generally considered as times to offer prayers, seek blessings and make positive changes in one’s life.

Sankranti days are considered good for charity activities and all auspicious ceremonies are avoided on the day of Sankranti(s).

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Mahalaya Amavasya
observances.description_1: Mahalaya Amavasya is a revered day for honoring ancestors, widely observed, especially in Bengali culture.
observances.description_2:
Mahalaya Amavasya, also known as Sarvapitri Amavasya, Pitra Moksha Amavasya, or Pitru Amavasya, is a Hindu tradition honoring ancestors. It falls on the Amavasya of the Bhadrapada masa in the Amanta calendar followed in South India, and during the Ashwini masa in the Purnimanta calendar, used in North India.

It marks the culmination of the 15-day long Shraddha rituals, offering a significant opportunity for performing shraddha rites for deceased individuals regardless of the tithi. On this day, families perform Mahalaya Amavasya tarpana and rituals to honor their ancestors and seek blessings for a peaceful and prosperous life.

Mahalaya Amavasya is the final day of the Pitr Paksha. In Bengal, it signifies the commencement of the Durga Puja festivities, symbolizing the descent of Goddess Durga to Earth. Additionally, it initiates the Bathukamma festival in Telangana. Families worship their ancestors with offerings of dhoop, deepa, flowers, water, barley, and donations.

observances.name: Bhadrapada Mahalaya Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: Surya Grahana
observances.description_1: Solar Eclipse occurs when the Moon passes between the Earth and the Sun, temporarily blocking sunlight.
observances.description_2:
If a Solar Eclipse spans across two different dates, the Eclipse Day should be when the maximum eclipse occurs.

In Hinduism, Solar Eclipses hold significance only if visible to the naked eye. Penumbral Solar Eclipses, invisible to the naked eye, have no associated rituals. Rituals are only observed if the Solar Eclipse is visible during the Umbral Phase.

If a Solar Eclipse is not visible in your city but is visible nearby, it should not be observed. Precautions advised during Sutak should only be taken if the Solar Eclipse is visible in your city, regardless of visibility due to weather conditions.

Sutak, an inauspicious time before Solar and Lunar Eclipses, is believed to contaminate the Earth's atmosphere. It lasts for 4 Prahars (12 hours) before a Solar Eclipse and 3 Prahars (9 hours) before a Lunar Eclipse, during which food consumption is prohibited.

During Sutak, all food, solid or liquid, is prohibited, except for children, the sick, and the elderly, for whom restrictions are limited to a single Prahar (3 hours). Pregnant women are advised to avoid venturing out during the Eclipse to prevent potential harm to the unborn child.

Various activities such as oil massage, drinking water, and engaging in sexual activities are prohibited during an Eclipse. After the Eclipse, cooked food should be discarded, and only freshly prepared food should be consumed. Items like grains and pickles that cannot be discarded should be protected with Kusha grass or Tulasi leaves. It is also recommended to bathe and make offerings to Brahmins after the Eclipse for spiritual benefit.

eclipse_info.description: It is advised to not consume any food or liquids during this time.

observances.name: Ghatasthapana
observances.description_1: Ghatasthapana is a significant ritual that marks the beginning of Navratri, a nine-day festival dedicated to the worship of Goddess Durga and her nine forms.
observances.description_2:
Ghatasthapana is a traditional ceremony that involves the invocation of the Goddess Shakti into a kalash (sacred pot), symbolizing the start of the Navratri festivities.

Ghatasthapana is performed during an auspicious time known as the 'Ghatasthapana Muhurta,' on the first day of Navratri while Pratipada is prevailing. It can be performed during the Abhijit Muhurta as well. The kalash is filled with water and adorned with mango leaves. A coconut is placed on top of the kalash and is covered with a red cloth. Seeds of seven different grains are sown around the kalash in a pot filled with soil. This pot is kept in a sacred place in the puja room or altar.

observances.name: ShailPutri Puja
observances.description_1: Shailputri Puja is the worship of Goddess Shailputri on the first day of Navratri.
observances.description_2:
Shailputri Puja is worship of Goddess Shailputri on the first day of Navratri, a nine-day festival dedicated to the worship of the goddess Durga and her various forms. Shailputri, also known as Sati, Bhavani, Parvati, or Hemavati, is the first form of the Navadurga, the nine forms of the goddess Durga worshipped during Navratri. Her name, Shailputri, means "daughter of the mountains," reflecting her birth as the daughter of the Himalayas.

According to Hindu mythology, Shailputri is the reincarnation of Sati, the first consort of Lord Shiva. After Sati's self-immolation, she was reborn as Parvati, the daughter of King Himavan, the king of the Himalayas, and was later known as Shailputri.

The mount of Goddess Shailputri is the bull and because of that she is also known as Vrisharudha. Goddess Shailputri is depicted with two hands. She carries Trishul in the right hand and the lotus flower in the left hand.

observances.name: Brahmacharini Puja
observances.description_1: Brahmacharini Puja is the worship of Goddess Brahmacharini on the second day of Navratri.
observances.description_2:
Brahmacharini Puja is performed on the second day of Navratri, the nine-day Hindu festival dedicated to the worship of the goddess Durga and her nine forms, known as Navadurga. Her name, "Brahmacharini," means "one who practices devout austerity."

According to Hindu mythology, Brahmacharini is the form of Parvati when she undertook severe penance to win Lord Shiva as her husband. She practiced intense austerities and lived an ascetic life to prove her devotion and dedication. Goddess Brahmacharini is depicted as walking on the bare feet. She has two hands and She carries Jap Mala in the right hand and Kamandal in the left hand.

observances.name: Sindoor Tritiya
observances.description_1: Sindoor Tritiya is dedicated to Goddess Parvati and is observed on the third day of Navratri.
observances.description_2:
Sindoor Tritiya is celebrated by married women, primarily in North India. This festival is dedicated to Goddess Parvati and is observed on the third day of Navratri.

Sindoor Tritiya is believed to bring happiness and prosperity to married women. It is a time for them to pray for the long life and well-being of their husbands. On this day, women apply sindoor (vermilion) to the parting of their hair, which is a significant symbol of marriage in Hindu culture. They also offer sindoor to Goddess Parvati during the puja. Many married women observe a fast on this day, praying for the longevity and prosperity of their husbands.

observances.name: Lalita Panchami
observances.description_1: Lalita Panchami is a fasting day dedicated to Goddess Lalita.
observances.description_2:
Lalita Panchami is celebrated on the fifth day of the Sharad Navaratri festival which falls on the fifth day of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Ashwin.

Goddess Lalita, also known as Lalita Tripura Sundari, is one of the ten Mahavidya Goddesses. A significant legend associated with Lalita Panchami involves the appearance of Goddess Lalita to defeat the demon Bhandaasura, who was causing havoc in the universe. With her divine powers she defeated the demon and restored peace and harmony.

Lalita Panchami vrata, which is observing a fast on this day is believed to bring wealth, happiness and wisdom. Chanting of Vedic mantras dedicated to Goddess Lalita is very beneficial. Fasting on Lalita Panchami is famous in Gujarat and some parts of Maharashtra.

observances.name: Bilva Nimantran
observances.description_1: Bilva Nimantran is a significant ritual in the worship of Goddess Durga during the festival of Durga Puja.
observances.description_2:
Bilva Nimantran signifies the commencement of the Durga Puja festivities, inviting the divine presence of Goddess Durga into the homes and pandals of devotees. Shashthi tithi in the evening is the most preferred time for Bilva Nimantran.

The ritual involves inviting Goddess Durga to reside in the Bilva tree or its leaves. This invitation is a formal request for the goddess to accept the offerings and prayers of the devotees during the Durga Puja. A Bilva branch with leaves is selected for the ritual. In some traditions, devotees go to a Bilva tree and perform the ritual at its base. Special mantras and hymns dedicated to Goddess Durga are recited. The Bilva tree is considered highly sacred in Hinduism, particularly in the worship of Lord Shiva and Goddess Durga.

deities.title: Durga
deities.description: Goddess Durga is a major deity in Hinduism, worshipped as a principal aspect of the mother goddess Mahadevi. She was created by the combined energies of the gods Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, who infused their divine powers into her to combat the demon, Mahishasura. She is celebrated for her strength and  her role as a fierce warrior against evil and injustice. Durga is often depicted as a beautiful woman with ten arms, each holding a weapon or symbol. She rides a lion or tiger.

observances.name: Sashti
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Katyayani Puja
observances.description_1: Katyayani Puja is the worship of Goddess Katyayani on the sixth day of Navratri.
observances.description_2:
Katyayani Puja is performed on the sixth day of Navratri, the nine-day Hindu festival dedicated to the worship of the goddess Durga and her nine forms, known as Navadurga. Katyayani, the sixth form of Navadurga, is worshipped as the goddess of power and courage. She is considered one of the most powerful forms of Goddess Durga and is associated with victory and righteousness.

According to Hindu mythology, Katyayani was born to the sage Katya to destroy the buffalo demon Mahishasura, who had been causing havoc in the heavens. Katyayani grew up to be a fierce warrior and eventually led the gods to victory by slaying Mahishasura, restoring peace and order in the cosmos.

Goddess Katyayani rides on the magnificent lion and depicted with four hands. She carries lotus flower and sword in her left hands and keeps her right hands in Abhaya and Varada Mudras.

observances.name: Maha Saptami
observances.description_1: Commencing the divine revelry of Durga puja, unveiling the spiritual aura and festive splendor in Bengal.
observances.description_2:
Maha Saptami, a pivotal day in the grand celebration of Durga Puja, marks the commencement of the elaborate rituals in honour of Goddess Durga. This auspicious day is rich in cultural significance, setting the stage for the vibrant festivities that engulf the state of West Bengal.

Maha Saptami falls on the seventh day of Shukla Paksha in Ashwin masa.

Goddess Durga is the primary deity worshipped during Maha Saptami. The day symbolizes the descent of the goddess to Earth, marking the start of her battle against the buffalo demon Mahishasura.

Maha Saptami is characterized by the Kalparambha ritual, where the formal beginning of the Puja is established through the symbolic planting of a banana tree, representing Goddess Durga. Elaborate pujas, traditional music, and dance performances contribute to the festive atmosphere.

observances.name: Saraswati Puja
observances.description_1: Devotion to Goddess Saraswati for wisdom, knowledge, and arts.
observances.description_2:
Saraswati Puja during Sharad Navratri is more popular in South Indian states. Saraswathi Puja is a day of reverence for education and the pursuit of knowledge, symbolizing the importance of intellect and wisdom in one's life.

The first day of Saraswati Puja during Navratri Puja is known as Saraswati Avahan. Avahan means invocation of Goddess Saraswati.

Students place their books, instruments, and tools in front of the goddess as a symbolic gesture of seeking her blessings for success in their studies and creative endeavours. It is customary to refrain from reading or writing on this day, as it is believed that the goddess is blessing the tools of learning. People, especially students, spend the day in contemplation, music, dance, and cultural activities.

observances.name: Maha Astami
observances.description_1: The pinnacle of spiritual reverie during Durga puja, unleashing divine energies and cultural splendor in bengal.
observances.description_2:
Maha Astami also known as Durgashtami is the eighth day of the Navratri or Durgotsav festival and is rich in cultural significance, setting the stage for the vibrant festivities that engulf the state of West Bengal.

This day is attributed to Goddess Shakti, an avatar of Durga who is symbolic of eternal power and the victory of 'good' over 'evil'.

Maha Saptami falls on the eighth day of Shukla Paksha in Ashwin masa.

Goddess Kali culminated from the forehead of Devi Durga on this day and killed Mahishasur — the king of Demons and his associates—Chanda and Munda.

On this day, Mother Durga annihilated Bhairo Nath, an evil 'tantric' in the form of Vaishno Devi. This incident led to the history of the establishment of the pilgrimage of Vaishno devi and it is said that the famous Bhairo Nath temple lies at the site where the head of Bhairo Nath fell after being chucked off by the Goddess.

Maha Ashtami is marked by the ritual of Kumari Puja, where young girls symbolizing the divine feminine are worshipped as incarnations of Goddess Durga. The Sandhi Puja, performed during the transition from Ashtami to Navami, is a crucial observance believed to harness immense spiritual power.

observances.name: Maha Navami
observances.description_1: Culminating the divine odyssey of Durga puja, embracing spiritual triumph and cultural elegance in Bengal.
observances.description_2:
Maha Navami is the ninth day of the Navratri festival and is the final day of worship before Vijaya Dashami, the end of Navratri. On this day, Goddess Durga is worshipped in different forms in different parts of the country.

Falling on the ninth day of Shukla paksha in Ashwin masa, Maha Navami symbolizes the powerful and conclusive phase of the extended Durga Puja festivities.

Devi Durga's battle against Mahishasur, the king of demons, lasted for nine days. The ninth day is the final day before the Goddess wins over the evil with her power and wisdom. So Maha Navami is also considered the eve of starting anything new on Vijaya Dashami.

Navami Homa is performed on Maha Navami and it is a significant ritual during Durga Puja. The best time to perform Homa is at the end of Navami Puja.

deities.title: Lakshmi
deities.description: Lakshmi is the goddess of wealth, fortune, and prosperity, both material and spiritual. She is the consort of Vishnu and is typically depicted with four arms, symbolizing the four goals of human life—dharma, artha, kama, and moksha. Lakshmi is celebrated during the festival of Diwali, when she is worshipped to invite wealth and happiness into homes.

deities.title: Parvathi
deities.description: Parvati is a principal deity in Hinduism and the consort of Shiva. Known as the goddess of fertility, love, and devotion, she is also regarded as the motherly force of the universe. Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife, and is the mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya. She embodies the ideal of marital fidelity and is often depicted alongside Shiva, representing the combined power of renewal and destruction. Her manifestations include fierce forms like Kali and gentle aspects like Gauri.

deities.title: Durga
deities.description: Goddess Durga is a major deity in Hinduism, worshipped as a principal aspect of the mother goddess Mahadevi. She was created by the combined energies of the gods Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, who infused their divine powers into her to combat the demon, Mahishasura. She is celebrated for her strength and  her role as a fierce warrior against evil and injustice. Durga is often depicted as a beautiful woman with ten arms, each holding a weapon or symbol. She rides a lion or tiger.

deities.title: Saraswathi
deities.description: Saraswati is the goddess of knowledge, music, art, wisdom, and learning. Saraswati is often depicted as a beautiful deity dressed in pure white, often seated on a white lotus, which symbolizes light, knowledge, and truth. She not only embodies knowledge but also the experience of the highest reality. Her iconography usually includes a veena, representing the arts and sciences, and books, representing knowledge.

observances.name: Ayudha Puja
observances.description_1: A sacred ritual honouring tools, Instruments, and implements.
observances.description_2:
Ayudha Puja, also known as Shastra Puja, is a Hindu festival that reveres tools, instruments, and equipment. This significant ritual is observed on the ninth day of the Navratri festival, usually known as Mahanavami.

Ayudha Puja is celebrated across India, but it is particularly prominent in states like Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, and Kerala. The festival holds cultural significance and is observed with great enthusiasm in workplaces, factories, and homes.

On Ayudha Puja, various tools, vehicles, and instruments are worshipped as embodiments of the divine. The puja is dedicated to Goddess Saraswati, the deity of knowledge, and Lord Ayudha Poojai, a form of Lord Vishnu who is worshipped in the form of weapons.

In its modern form, Ayudha Puja has become Vahana Puja when people worship their vehicles including cars, scooters, and motorbikes. During Vahana Puja all sorts of vehicles, which are in use, are decorated with vermilion, garlands, mango leaves and banana sapling and worshipped. Most significantly during Vahana Puja a white pumpkin is decorated with vermilion and turmeric and smashed in front of the vehicle as a custom to get rid of all sorts of evils.

observances.name: Mysore Dasara
observances.description_1: Mysore Dussehra, celebrates victory of good over evil, grand festival in Mysore, Karnataka, featuring cultural events.
observances.description_2:
Mysore Dasara, renowned for its opulence and cultural extravaganza, is a vibrant celebration that unfolds in the city of Mysore, Karnataka. This ten-day festival, culminating in Vijayadashami, stands as a testimony to the rich heritage and traditions of the region.

Vijayadashami falls on the tenth day of Shukla Paksha in Ashwin masa.

Mysore Dasara primarily honours the goddess Chamundeshwari, a form of Goddess Durga. The festival has deep mythological roots, symbolizing the victory of Goddess Chamundeshwari over the demon Mahishasura. The significance lies in the triumph of good over evil.

Mysore Dasara is marked by the symbolic tree chopping at the onset and the grand inauguration by the royal family. The illumination of Mysore Palace and the iconic Jambu Savari procession featuring Goddess Chamundeshwari's adorned idol are central rituals, symbolizing the triumph of light and divine blessings. The festival also embraces cultural events and the Dasara Exhibition, creating a vibrant and sacred atmosphere that celebrates the rich heritage of Karnataka.

observances.name: Bengali Vijayadashami
observances.description_1: A cultural splendour culminating Durga puja, blending tradition, art, and devotion in the heart of Bengal.
observances.description_2:
Bengali Vijayadashami, the final day of Durga Puja, holds immense cultural significance in the heart of Bengal. The festival marks the culmination of the elaborate worship of Goddess Durga, symbolizing her triumph over the buffalo demon Mahishasura.

Vijayadashami falls on the tenth day of the bright fortnight (Shukla Paksha) in the Hindu month of Ashwin.

Goddess Durga, along with her divine children, is worshipped during Durga Puja. Bengali Vijayadashami holds deep significance as it marks the day when Goddess Durga vanquished the demon Mahishasura, signifying the victory of good over evil.

The day begins with the traditional Sindoor Khela, where married women apply vermilion to the goddess and to each other, symbolizing the power of femininity. The immersion procession, known as Bisorjon, takes place, bidding an emotional farewell to the goddess and her family. The day also marks the start of Devi Baran, a series of rituals for the goddess's departure.

observances.name: Vijayadashami
observances.description_1: Celebrating triumph and enlightenment, the culminating day of Navratri signifies victory over evil.
observances.description_2:
Vijayadashami, also known as Dussehra, marks the tenth and final day of the Navratri festival, symbolizing the triumph of good over evil. This significant Hindu festival holds diverse cultural and religious significance across India.

Vijayadashami falls on the tenth day of Shukla Paksha in Ashwin masa.

On Vijayadashami, devotees pay homage to Goddess Durga and Lord Rama. The day holds significance for different reasons in different parts of India. In the northern and western regions, it commemorates Lord Rama's victory over the demon king Ravana, as narrated in the epic Ramayana. In the southern states, it marks the victory of Goddess Durga over the buffalo demon Mahishasura.

The day begins with special prayers and pujas dedicated to Goddess Durga and Lord Rama. In the northern and western regions, effigies of Ravana, Meghnad, and Kumbhakarna are burnt on open grounds, symbolizing the victory of righteousness over evil. In the southern states, the day is marked by the immersion of Goddess Durga idols.

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Papankusha Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Kojagara Puja
observances.description_1: Observed for prosperity and worshipped for Goddess Lakshmi's blessings.
observances.description_2:
Kojagara Puja, also known as Sharad Purnima, is celebrated on Purnima of the Ashwin masa. It is primarily observed in the eastern and northeastern states of India, such as West Bengal, Assam, Odisha, Bihar, and Tripura.

Kojagari is derived from the Bengali word 'Ke Jago Re' meaning 'who is awake' and it is believed that on the day of Kojagari Lakshmi Puja, Goddess Lakshmi takes around on the Earth's orbit and relieves her devotees from their woes. Those who remain to awaken on the night of Sharad Purnima are blessed with health and wealth.

Due to keeping Jagarana during the night, this fast is known as Kojagara Vrat. This fast is observed on the day of Ashwin Purnima. This fast is also known by the names Kojagari Puja, Bengali Lakshmi Puja etc. The full moon of Ashwin month is also called Kaumudi. Hence, one name of this fast is also Kaumudi Vrat. According to Skandapuran, Kojagara Vrat is the best fast, by observing which even an ordinary being attains the highest position and gets opulence, health and children in this birth and in other births also.

deities.title: Lakshmi
deities.description: Lakshmi is the goddess of wealth, fortune, and prosperity, both material and spiritual. She is the consort of Vishnu and is typically depicted with four arms, symbolizing the four goals of human life—dharma, artha, kama, and moksha. Lakshmi is celebrated during the festival of Diwali, when she is worshipped to invite wealth and happiness into homes.

observances.name: Purnima
observances.description_1: Purnima, signifies the full moon day, often marked by religious ceremonies and spiritual observances.
observances.description_2:
Purnima, or the Full Moon day, is a significant occasion in Indian culture, occurring monthly as the moon reaches its maximum brightness.

Purnima fasting is observed either on the Purnima day itself or the day before, known as Chaturdashi, depending on the timing of the Purnima Tithi (lunar day) from the previous day.

Purnima fasting on Chaturdashi occurs only when the Purnima begins during the Madhyahna period on the previous day. If Chaturdashi extends beyond Madhyahna, it's considered impure for Purnima fasting, even if Purnima begins later in the evening.

In North India, the full moon day is called Purnima, while in South India, it's referred to as Pournami or Pournima, and fasting on this day is known as Pournami Vratam, observed from sunrise until the moon is sighted.

observances.name: Valmiki Jayanti
observances.description_1: Valmiki Jayanti celebrates the birth anniversary of Maharishi Valmiki, the author of the epic Ramayana.
observances.description_2:
Valmiki, revered as the first Sanskrit poet, authored the epic Ramayana, comprising 24,000 verses and 7 cantos (Kandas), including the Uttara Kanda. He is considered the Adi Kavi, or the original poet of Sanskrit.

Believed to have lived during the time of Lord Rama, Valmiki's exact birth era remains uncertain, as it aligns with the debated birth era of Lord Rama. However, his birth anniversary, or Jayanti, is celebrated on Ashwin Purnima.

According to the Ramayana, Lord Rama encountered Valmiki during his exile and sought refuge with him. Valmiki sheltered Devi Sita in his hermitage after Rama banished her, and it was there that Rama's twin sons, Kusha and Lava, were born and taught the Ramayana.

In his earlier life, Valmiki was known as Ratnakar, a highway dacoit who underwent a profound transformation under the guidance of sage Narada Muni. Through intense penance and chanting the sacred mantra of Rama Nama, Ratnakar eventually became Valmiki, meaning "the one born out of ant-hills," signifying his rebirth and spiritual evolution.

observances.name: Purnima
observances.description_1: Purnima, signifies the full moon day, often marked by religious ceremonies and spiritual observances.
observances.description_2:
Purnima, or the Full Moon day, is a significant occasion in Indian culture, occurring monthly as the moon reaches its maximum brightness.

Purnima fasting is observed either on the Purnima day itself or the day before, known as Chaturdashi, depending on the timing of the Purnima Tithi (lunar day) from the previous day.

Purnima fasting on Chaturdashi occurs only when the Purnima begins during the Madhyahna period on the previous day. If Chaturdashi extends beyond Madhyahna, it's considered impure for Purnima fasting, even if Purnima begins later in the evening.

In North India, the full moon day is called Purnima, while in South India, it's referred to as Pournami or Pournima, and fasting on this day is known as Pournami Vratam, observed from sunrise until the moon is sighted.

observances.name: Karwa Chauth
observances.description_1: Celebrated in North India, married women fast for husbands' longevity, breaking fast at moonrise.
observances.description_2:
Karwa Chauth observed primarily in North India, is a significant festival celebrated by married Hindu women. Predominantly in Punjab, Haryana, Rajasthan, and Uttar Pradesh, elaborate rituals and festivities mark this occasion.

While Karwa Chauth is observed during Kartik's Krishna Paksha Chaturthi, in Gujarat, Maharashtra, and Southern India, it aligns with the Ashwin month. Despite the varying calendar months, the festival is celebrated nationwide on the same day.

Karwa Chauth coincides with Sankashti Chaturthi, a fasting day dedicated to Lord Ganesha. Women worship Lord Shiva and His family, including Lord Ganesha, breaking their fasts only after sighting and offering prayers to the moon.

Karwa Chauth is also known as Karak Chaturthi, with "Karwa" referring to the earthen pot used for the water offering to the moon. This pot holds significant importance during the Puja and is often donated to others.

Although Karwa Chauth is more popular in North Indian states compared to South India, its essence of devotion and marital commitment resonates throughout the country.

observances.name: Sankasta Chaturthi
observances.description_1: Sankashti Chaturthi is a significant day for Lord Ganesha devotees, observed to seek his blessings and overcome obstacles.
observances.description_2:
In the Hindu calendar, each lunar month includes two Chaturthi Tithi. The one following the full moon, known as Purnimasi, during Krishna Paksha is called Sankashti Chaturthi, while the one following the new moon, known as Amavasya, during Shukla Paksha is called Vinayaka Chaturthi.

If Sankashti Chaturthi falls on a Tuesday, it is revered as Angarki Chaturthi, considered highly auspicious, particularly in Western and Southern India, notably Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu.

During Sankashti Chaturthi, devotees of Lord Ganesha observe a fast from sunrise to moonrise. Sankashti, meaning deliverance during troubled times, signifies the belief that observing this fast can remove obstacles, as Lord Ganesha is revered as the remover of obstacles.

The fast is observed strictly, with consumption limited to fruits, roots, and vegetable products. Typical foods include Sabudana Khichadi, potatoes, and peanuts, with devotees breaking their fast after sighting the moon.

In North India, Sankashti Chaturthi in the month of Magha is known as Sakat Chauth, while Vinayaka Chaturthi in the month of Bhadrapada is celebrated as Ganesha Chaturthi worldwide as Lord Ganesha's birthday.

Among Tamil Hindus, Sankashti Chaturthi is referred to as Ganesh Sankatahara or Sankatahara Chaturthi.

observances.name: Karthika Somavara - Prathama
observances.description_1: Prathama Somvara, the first monday of the Karthika masa, is highly auspicious. Devotees visit Shiva temples, perform abhisheka (ritual bath), and recite prayers.
observances.description_2:
Karthika Somavara is a special time dedicated to Lord Shiva, observed on Mondays during Karthika masa. People believe that fasting and praying on these days can help cleanse sins, fulfill wishes, and bring blessings from Lord Shiva.

On Karthika Somavara, devotees start their day early with a purifying bath, often in sacred rivers or water bodies. They visit Shiva temples or perform prayers and rituals at home, offering bilva leaves, milk, fruits, and bael (wood apple) to show their devotion.

Many people fast throughout the day, not eating or drinking until evening when they perform the evening puja to Lord Shiva. This fast is seen as a way to cleanse both body and mind, leading to spiritual purification.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Radha Kunda Snan
observances.description_1: Radha Kunda Snan is the ritual bath in Radhakunda on the auspicious day of Ahoi Ashtami.
observances.description_2:
The ritual bath in Radha Kunda is considered highly auspicious, especially on the day of Ahoi Ashtami. Couples who have problems in conceiving come here to seek blessings of Goddess Radha Rani, the consort of Lord Krishna. The bathing day falls on Ashtami thiti of Krishna Paksha in the month of Kartik.

On the day of Ahoi Ashtami, thousands of devotees gather at Radha Kunda to take a ritual bath. The bathing ceremony usually takes place at midnight, as it is believed to be the most auspicious time. Couples perform Puja after standing in the water tank and offer Kushmanda or white raw pumpkin after decorating it with a red cloth.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

observances.name: Ahoi Ashtami
observances.description_1: Celebration of maternal devotion, marked by fasting until evening star sightings for children's well-being.
observances.description_2:
Ahoi Ashtami, widely celebrated in North India, particularly Uttar Pradesh and Bihar, honours maternal love and devotion. It occurs on the Krishna Paksha Ashtami in the Kartik masa.

Mothers venerate Ahoi Mata, a form of Goddess Parvati, praying for their children's well-being and longevity. They observe a day-long fast, abstaining from food and water until evening star sightings.

Traditionally for sons' well-being, modern observance includes daughters too. The fast ends at twilight or upon spotting stars. Ahoi Ashtami is about eight days before Diwali and four days post Karwa Chauth.

This rigorous fast, akin to Karwa Chauth, culminates with star sightings in the evening sky.

observances.name: Tula Sankramana
observances.description_1: Tula Sankramana marks the transition of the Sun to the Tula Rashi.
observances.description_2:
Tula Sankramana falls around mid-October marking the Sun's transition from Kanya Rashi (Virgo) into Tula Rashi (Libra) according to the Hindu solar calendar.

Tula Sankramana is considered a highly auspicious day. During Tula Sankramana, it is believed that the Sun attains a state of perfect balance, symbolizing harmony and equilibrium. Prayers are offered to Surya Deva, seeking his blessings. Sesame seeds (nuvvulu) and jaggery (bellam) are offered as prasadam (sacred offering). Some families also perform puja to Goddess Lakshmi, the embodiment of prosperity, for good fortune.

While known as Tula Sankramana in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh, this festival has different names in other parts of India. In Karnataka, it's called Kaveri Sankramana, with special poojas offered to the holy Kaveri river. In Tamil Nadu, it's known as Aippasi Masam, a month dedicated to Lord Vishnu.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

observances.name: Govatsa Dwadashi
observances.description_1: Govatsa Dwadashi is dedicated to the worship of cows and calves.
observances.description_2:
Govatsa Dwadashi is celebrated on Dwadashi thiti of the Krishna Paksha month of Kartika. It is celebrated one day before Dhanteras and marks the beginning of Diwali celebrations in some parts of India, especially in the state of Maharashtra.

Cows are considered sacred in Hinduism and symbolize purity, motherhood, and the sustenance. On Govatsa Dwadashi, cows and calves are worshipped and wheat products are given to them after worship. People also abstain from eating any wheat and milk products during the day.

In some North Indian states, Govatsa Dwadashi is referred to as Vagh, which implies the repayment of one's financial debts. It is therefore a day when businessmen clear their accounting books and do not make further transactions in their new ledgers.

observances.name: Sakat Chauth
observances.description_1: Sakat Chauth is dedicated to the compassionate and protective Goddess Sakat.
observances.description_2:
Sakat Chauth dedicated to Godess Sakat is observed on the Chaturthi of the Krishna Paksha during month of Magha mainly in North Indian states.

Women, especially mothers, observe a fast on Sakat Chauth, praying for the longevity and prosperity of their children. Lord Ganesha is also worshipped since Krishna Paksha Chaturthi is dedicated to Lord Ganesha.

observances.name: Rama Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
