Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Masik Sankranti
observances.description_1: Masik Sankranti marks the transition of the Sun into a new zodiac sign each month, observed with spiritual significance.
observances.description_2:
Sankranti refers to the transmigration of the sun from one rashi (zodiac) to another in Indian astronomy
The observance revolves around sun’s transition into new rashi (zodiac sign), symoblizing the end of one solar month and the beginning of another.

Malik Sankranti’s including the Makara Sankranthi is associated with Surya pravesh (Sun’s entry) into each rashi. There are twelve rashis (12 signs) namely Mekh (Mekha), Virkh, Mithun, Kark, Singh-Simha, Kanya, Tula,Vrischik, Dhan, Makara, Kumbh and Meena.

While significance and rituals may vary for each Masik Sankranti, they are generally considered as times to offer prayers, seek blessings and make positive changes in one’s life.

Sankranti days are considered good for charity activities and all auspicious ceremonies are avoided on the day of Sankranti(s).

observances.name: Dhanteras
observances.description_1: Dhanteras, also known as Dhanatrayodashi, marks the beginning of the Diwali festival.
observances.description_2:
Observed on the thirteenth day of the Krishna Paksha in the Kartik month. this day is dedicated to wealth and prosperity, and people engage in various rituals and customs to invite blessings for financial abundance.

Dhantrayodashi which is also known as Dhanteras is the first day of five days long Diwali festivities. On the day of Dhantrayodashi, Goddess Lakshmi came out of the ocean during the churning of the Milky Sea. Hence, Goddess Lakshmi, along with Lord Kubera who is the God of wealth, is worshipped on the auspicious day of Trayodashi. However, Lakshmi Puja on Amavasya after two days of Dhantrayodashi is considered more significant.

Lakshmi Puja on Dhanteras or Dhantrayodashi should be done during Pradosh Kaal which starts after sunset and approximately lasts 2 hours and 24 minutes.

Devotees clean and decorate their homes on Dhanteras, welcoming prosperity and positivity. Lighting lamps and candles are symbolic of dispelling darkness and inviting light. Purchasing gold, silver, or new utensils on this day is considered auspicious. Many also perform puja ceremonies, recite mantras, and offer prayers to invoke the blessings of Goddess Lakshmi.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Naraka Chaturdashi
observances.description_1: Marks Lord Krishna's triumph over the demon Narakasura, observed before Diwali celebrations.
observances.description_2:
Naraka Chaturdashi holds significant importance in the Deepavali celebrations, typically occurring a day before Lakshmi Puja. It stands as the second most crucial day during Deepavali, often referred to as Choti Deepavali, especially in North Indian regions.

This day commemorates Lord Krishna's victory over the demon Narakasura. Legend has it that Lord Krishna, along with Satyabhama, defeated Narakasura and observed an oil bath during Brahma Muhurat after the battle, making it customary to take a ritualistic oil bath before sunrise on Naraka Chaturdashi.

Naraka Chaturdashi's timing is determined by the lunar calendar, specifically during Brahma Muhurat, which is the period just before sunrise. It falls on the Krishna Paksha Chaturdashi of Kartika masa in the Purnimanta calendar and Ashwin masa in the Amanta calendar.

Observances on Naraka Chaturdashi typically include early morning oil baths, known as Abhyang Snan in Maharashtra, wearing new clothes, lighting earthen lamps, and playing with fireworks.

In North India, Naraka Chaturdashi is celebrated as Choti Deepavali or Roop Chaudas. In South Indian states like Tamil Nadu and Karnataka, it is observed as Deepavali. Maharashtra popularly refers to this day as Abhyang Snan.

observances.name: Karthika Somavara - Dwitiya
observances.description_1: Dwitiya Somvara, the second monday of the Karthika masa, devotees continue their fervent worship of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Karthika Somavara is a special time dedicated to Lord Shiva, observed on Mondays during Karthika masa. People believe that fasting and praying on these days can help cleanse sins, fulfill wishes, and bring blessings from Lord Shiva.

On Karthika Somavara, devotees start their day early with a purifying bath, often in sacred rivers or water bodies. They visit Shiva temples or perform prayers and rituals at home, offering bilva leaves, milk, fruits, and bael (wood apple) to show their devotion.

Many people fast throughout the day, not eating or drinking until evening when they perform the evening puja to Lord Shiva. This fast is seen as a way to cleanse both body and mind, leading to spiritual purification.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Kamala Jayanti
observances.description_1: Kamala Jayanti is dedicated to the worship of Goddess Kamala, one of the ten Mahavidya Goddesses.
observances.description_2:
Kamala Jayanti celebrates Goddess Kamala, the tantric form of Goddess Lakshmi and is revered for her attributes of wealth, prosperity, and fertility. She is worshipped for her ability to grant material abundance, spiritual prosperity, and overall well-being.

Goddess Kamala is often depicted as seated on a lotus flower, similar to Goddess Lakshmi, symbolizing purity, beauty, and spiritual enlightenment. She is surrounded by elephants, which shower her with water, symbolizing abundance and fertility. She is depicted with four arms. In two arms, she holds lotus flowers and the other two arms are in the Varada mudra (granting boons) and Abhaya Mudra (dispelling fear).

observances.name: Diwali
observances.description_1: A celebration of the triumph of light over darkness and good over evil with vibrant decorations, joyful gatherings, and the exchange of sweets and gifts.
observances.description_2:
Diwali, the festival of lights, embodies the victory of light over darkness and good over evil. Diwali is a shortened form of the original word Deepavali meaning rows of lamps, which perfectly encapsulates its significance.

On the Hindu lunar calendar, Diwali coincides with Kartik amavasya. In India, especially in the northern states, Diwali spans five days, commencing with Dhanteras on the 13th lunar day of the Krishna paksha and concluding with Bhai Dooj on the 17th lunar day of the Shukla paksha, following the Purnimanta calendar.

The festival begins with Dhanteras and reaches its climax with Bhai Dooj. The main celebration takes place on Kartik Amavasya, marked by the illumination of oil lamps, fireworks, gift exchanges, and prayers to Goddess Lakshmi for prosperity, also known as Lakshmi Puja.

Diwali encompasses diverse traditions across India, serving as a national holiday. It starts with Dhanteras, symbolising the start of the new financial year, followed by Naraka Chaturdasi, Govardhan Puja, and Bhai Dooj, where sisters seek blessings for their brothers' well-being.

During Diwali, festivities include feasting and gift exchanges, alongside wearing new clothes and worshipping Goddess Lakshmi and Lord Ganesha. In Southern India, it honours the return of King Mahabali, while in Bengal and Eastern India, Goddess Kali is revered, and in Maharashtra, cows and their calves are respected.
Diwali fairs are held nationwide, serving as bustling centres of commerce and entertainment, often featuring performances by artists and acrobats, contributing to the festive ambience.

deities.title: Lakshmi
deities.description: Lakshmi is the goddess of wealth, fortune, and prosperity, both material and spiritual. She is the consort of Vishnu and is typically depicted with four arms, symbolizing the four goals of human life—dharma, artha, kama, and moksha. Lakshmi is celebrated during the festival of Diwali, when she is worshipped to invite wealth and happiness into homes.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

deities.title: Rama
deities.description: Lord Rama is the seventh avatar of Vishnu, incarnated to defeat the demon king Ravana and restore dharma. He is one of the most revered deities in Hinduism. He embodies the ideals of virtue, duty, and kingly conduct, often referred to as Maryada Purushottama. His life and actions serve as a guide for ideal behavior in various roles - as a son, husband, brother, and king.

observances.name: Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: Ashvayuja Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: Bali Padyami
observances.description_1: A ritual celebrated in honor of King Bali, symbolizing prosperity and righteousness, with prayers and offerings.
observances.description_2:
Bali Padyami, also known as Bali Puja, takes place on Kartik Pratipada, the day following Diwali Puja. It aligns with Govardhan Puja, which venerates Govardhan hills and Lord Krishna. However, Bali Puja specifically seeks blessings from Demon King Bali.

Demon King Bali is honoured during Diwali due to a boon from Lord Vishnu. In the legend of Vamana Avatar, Lord Vishnu sends Bali to Patala but grants him three days on Earth due to his generosity. During these days, it's believed that Bali resides on Earth to bless his devotees.

Traditionally, during Bali Puja, the image of King Bali, along with his wife Vindhyavali, is drawn at the centre of homes and adorned with five different colours, symbolizing his worship.

In South India, King Bali is worshipped during Onam, mirroring the tradition of Bali Puja in North India.

observances.name: Bestu Varas
observances.description_1: Gujarati new year celebrations marked by traditions, prayers, and festive joy.
observances.description_2:
Gujarati New Year which is also known as Bestu Varas is celebrated a day after Diwali. The Gujarati New Year falls on Shukla Paksha Pratipada of the Kartik masa.

Bestu Varas is of special significance for Gujarati businessmen and traders who start new books of account and close the old ones. These account books are called chopda or bahi-khata. Prayers are offered to Lakshmi, the Hindu goddess of wealth, with the hope that the New Year will be prosperous and profitable.

Many Gujarati communities organize cultural events, folk dances, and performances to celebrate Bestu Varas.

deities.title: Lakshmi
deities.description: Lakshmi is the goddess of wealth, fortune, and prosperity, both material and spiritual. She is the consort of Vishnu and is typically depicted with four arms, symbolizing the four goals of human life—dharma, artha, kama, and moksha. Lakshmi is celebrated during the festival of Diwali, when she is worshipped to invite wealth and happiness into homes.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

observances.name: Bhai Dooj
observances.description_1: Bhai Dooj is a festival celebrating the bond between brothers and sisters with rituals, gifts, and prayers for their well-being.
observances.description_2:
The word "Bhai Dooj" translates to "Brother's Second" in English. The word "Bhai" means brother, and "Dooj" means the second day after the new moon, is a joyous festival that celebrates the sacred bond between brothers and sisters.

Bhai Dooj falls on the second day of the Shukla Paksha in Kartik masa.

On Bhai Dooj, sisters perform aarti for their brothers, apply a ceremonial mark on their foreheads, and pray for their well-being. Brothers, in turn, offer gifts and express their love and protection for their sisters. Families often come together, sharing a festive meal and strengthening the bonds of kinship.

observances.name: Nagula Chavithi
observances.description_1: Nagula Chavithi is dedicated to the worship of Naga Devatas.
observances.description_2:
Nagula Chavithi is observed on the fourth day after Deepavali Amavasya during Karthika month. Nagula Chavithi is celebrated mostly in Andhra Pradesh, Tamil Nadu and some parts of Karnataka. It is mainly observed by married women for the wellbeing of their children.

Nagula Chavithi is dedicated to the worship of snakes, which are considered sacred and powerful in Hinduism. Snakes are associated with several deities, including Lord Shiva (who wears a snake around his neck) and Lord Vishnu (who rests on the serpent Ananta Shesha).

The festival is believed to provide protection from snake bites and bring prosperity and fertility to the land and family.

observances.name: Labh Pancham
observances.description_1: Labh Pancham marks the end of the Diwali festivities and is considered an auspicious day for starting new business ventures and making financial investments.
observances.description_2:
Labh Pancham falls on the Panchami thiti of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Kartika. It is mainly celebrated in the state of Gujrat. Labh Pancham is considered an auspicious day for starting new business ventures, opening new accounts, and making financial investments. The word "Labh" means "profit" or "benefit," indicating a focus on prosperity and success.

Businessmen and traders reopen their shops and offices on this day, having kept them closed during the Diwali holidays. On this day businessmen inaugurate new account ledgers, known as Khatu in Gujarati, by writing Shubh on left, Labh on right and drawing a Sathiya in the centre of the first page.

deities.title: Lakshmi
deities.description: Lakshmi is the goddess of wealth, fortune, and prosperity, both material and spiritual. She is the consort of Vishnu and is typically depicted with four arms, symbolizing the four goals of human life—dharma, artha, kama, and moksha. Lakshmi is celebrated during the festival of Diwali, when she is worshipped to invite wealth and happiness into homes.

deities.title: Ganesha
deities.description: Ganesha is the elephant-headed deity known as the remover of obstacles and the lord of beginnings. Son of Shiva and Parvati, he is commonly depicted with a broken tusk and riding a mouse. Ganesha is revered for his wisdom and is often invoked first in Hindu rituals to ensure success and clear obstacles. He also symbolizes the patronage of arts and sciences.

observances.name: Soora Samharam Skanda Sashti
observances.description_1: Skanda Shashti is dedicated to Skanda, son of God Shiva and Goddess Parvati. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan and Subramanya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda Sashti is celebrated on the sixth day of the bright half of Shukla Paksha in the Kartika month. Devotees fast for six days which end with Soorasamharam.

Shashti Tithi is dedicated to Lord Skanda. For Skanda Sashti Vratam, Sashti Tithi combined with Panchami Tithi is preferred. Hence, Skanda Sashti Vratam might be observed on Panchami Tithi.

Hindu scriptures narrate the tale of the demon king Tarakasura, who wreaked havoc across the heavens. The gods, unable to defeat him, sought Lord Shiva's intervention. Skanda emerged as a powerful warrior, vanquishing Tarakasura and restoring peace to the celestial realms. Skanda Shashti commemorates this victory of good over evil and celebrates the power of Lord Skanda.

In Tamil Nadu, it is widely celebrated as Kanda Shashti, while in North India, it is sometimes referred to as Kumar Shashti.

observances.name: Chhath Puja
observances.description_1: Popular in Bihar, it is a traditional festival venerating the Sun God through rituals, prayers, and offerings.
observances.description_2:
Chhath Puja is primarily celebrated in northern India including Bihar, Jharkhand, Uttar Pradesh and parts of Nepal.

This festival, observed on the 6th day of the Kartikeya masa in the Hindu Luni-Solar Bikram Sambat calendar, spans four days, marked by various rituals and customs.

Dedicated to Lord Surya, Chhath Puja holds significance for women, who observe fasting for the well-being of their sons and family happiness. The rituals include Nahay Khay, the first day's holy dip, and Kharna, fasting without water from sunrise to sunset on the second day.

The third and significant day includes fasting throughout the day, culminating in Arghya, an offering to the setting Sun, continuing overnight, with Parana performed the following morning. The festival concludes on the fourth day with Usha Arghya, offering to the rising Sun, breaking the 36-hour fast.

Also known as Pratihar, Dala Chhath, Chhathi, and Surya Shashthi, Chhath Puja symbolizes devotion and gratitude to the Sun God.

deities.title: Surya
deities.description: Surya is the god of the sun, symbolizing light, life, and the dispeller of darkness. As the source of all life, Surya is considered a creator and a vital deity. He is often depicted riding a chariot drawn by seven horses, representing the seven colors of the rainbow or the seven chakras in the body, driven by his charioteer, Aruna. Surya is worshipped daily in many Hindu households, especially during the Surya Namaskar (sun salutation) yoga practice, which enhances vitality and improves health.

observances.name: Karthika Somavara - Trithiya
observances.description_1: Tithiya Somvara, the third monday, the devotees engage in various spiritual activities such as fasting, temple visits, and hymn recitations for Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Karthika Somavara is a special time dedicated to Lord Shiva, observed on Mondays during Karthika masa. People believe that fasting and praying on these days can help cleanse sins, fulfill wishes, and bring blessings from Lord Shiva.

On Karthika Somavara, devotees start their day early with a purifying bath, often in sacred rivers or water bodies. They visit Shiva temples or perform prayers and rituals at home, offering bilva leaves, milk, fruits, and bael (wood apple) to show their devotion.

Many people fast throughout the day, not eating or drinking until evening when they perform the evening puja to Lord Shiva. This fast is seen as a way to cleanse both body and mind, leading to spiritual purification.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Sashti
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Skanda Sasthi
observances.description_1: Skanda Shashti is dedicated to Skanda, son of God Shiva and Goddess Parvati. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan and Subramanya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda Sashti is celebrated on the sixth day of the bright half of Shukla Paksha in the Kartika month. Devotees fast for six days which end with Soorasamharam.

Shashti Tithi is dedicated to Lord Skanda. For Skanda Sashti Vratam, Sashti Tithi combined with Panchami Tithi is preferred. Hence, Skanda Sashti Vratam might be observed on Panchami Tithi.

Hindu scriptures narrate the tale of the demon king Tarakasura, who wreaked havoc across the heavens. The gods, unable to defeat him, sought Lord Shiva's intervention. Skanda emerged as a powerful warrior, vanquishing Tarakasura and restoring peace to the celestial realms. Skanda Shashti commemorates this victory of good over evil and celebrates the power of Lord Skanda.

In Tamil Nadu, it is widely celebrated as Kanda Shashti, while in North India, it is sometimes referred to as Kumar Shashti.

observances.name: Akal Bodhon
observances.description_1: Akal Bodhan is the worship of Durga in the Bengali month of Ashvin, an uncustomary time for her worship.
observances.description_2:
The word Akala means untimely, and bodhana means awakening. Akalabodhana refers to the untimely awakening of the goddess Durga for her worship.

According to the Bengali version of Bhagavata Purana, when Ravana awakened Kumbhakarna and sent him to fight in the Lanka war, Rama was terrified. Brahma assured Rama and told him to worship Durga for success on the battlefield. Rama told Brahma that this was not the proper time (akala) to worship the goddess as it was the Krishna Paksha (waning moon), prescribed for her sleep. Brahma assured Rama that he would perform a puja for the awakening (bodhana) of the goddess. Rama agreed and appointed Brahma as the purohita (priest) of the ritual. Brahma performed the puja from the period of Krishna Navami till the death of the Ravana, during Shukla Navami.

deities.title: Durga
deities.description: Goddess Durga is a major deity in Hinduism, worshipped as a principal aspect of the mother goddess Mahadevi. She was created by the combined energies of the gods Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, who infused their divine powers into her to combat the demon, Mahishasura. She is celebrated for her strength and  her role as a fierce warrior against evil and injustice. Durga is often depicted as a beautiful woman with ten arms, each holding a weapon or symbol. She rides a lion or tiger.

observances.name: Jalaram Bapa Jayanti
observances.description_1: Jalaram Bapa Jayanti is the birth anniversary of Jalaram Bapa, a a revered Hindu saint.
observances.description_2:
Jalaram Bapa Jayanti falls on Saptami thiti of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Kartika. It is observed with great devotion, especially by his followers in Gujarat and other parts of India.

Jalaram Bapa was born on November 4, 1799, in Virpur, Gujarat. From a young age, he displayed a deep inclination towards spirituality and service. With blessings of his guru, Guru Bhojalram, he started "Sadavrat", a feeding centre, where all saints as well as the needy were fed.

One day, a sadhu who came to his house gave him a deity of Lord Rama, forecasting that Hanuman, would follow soon. Jalaram Bapa installed Rama as his family deity and after a few days, a deity of Hanuman appeared out of earth, on its own. The deity of Sita and Lakshman also appeared. Due to a miracle in the house of Jalaram, where grains were stored, became inexhaustible. Later other devotees and village folk joined him in his works of human welfare.

Jalaram bapa’s fame spread as a divine incarnation. Whoever came to Virpur, irrespective of caste, creed and religion were fed by Jalaram. This tradition of feeding people continues to this day in Virpur.

observances.name: Jagaddhatri Puja
observances.description_1: Jagaddhatri Puja is the worship of Goddess Jagaddhatri, another form of Goddess Durga.
observances.description_2:
Jagaddhatri Puja falls on the Shukla Navami tithi of the Bengali month of Karthik. In West Bengal, it is celebrated as a five day festival.

Jagaddhatri is depicted sitting on a lion with an elephant under them. The elephant, symbolizing ahamkara, and the lion symbolizes courage. According to the legend in the Katyayani Tantra, after the goddess Durga killed Mahishasura, the gods forgot her powers. So she appeared before the gods Agni, Vayu, Varuna, and Chandra who were filled with ahamkara or ego. She asked them to move a tiny blade of grass. All of them failed reminding them of her power. The goddess appeared before them as Uma, riding on a lion.

observances.name: Akshaya Navami
observances.description_1: Akshaya Navami is a highly auspicious day associated with eternal prosperity and good fortune.
observances.description_2:
Akshaya Navami is observed on Navami thiti of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Kartika month which is two days before Dev Uthani Ekadashi.

Akshaya Navami is considered an auspicious day that brings eternal prosperity and good fortune. It is believed that any good deed performed on this day, whether it be charity, worship, or starting a new venture, will bring everlasting benefits. It is believed that on this day, the Satya Yuga began.

The day of Akshaya Navami is also known as Amla Navami. Worshiping the Amla tree on this day is believed to bring health and prosperity.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

deities.title: Surya
deities.description: Surya is the god of the sun, symbolizing light, life, and the dispeller of darkness. As the source of all life, Surya is considered a creator and a vital deity. He is often depicted riding a chariot drawn by seven horses, representing the seven colors of the rainbow or the seven chakras in the body, driven by his charioteer, Aruna. Surya is worshipped daily in many Hindu households, especially during the Surya Namaskar (sun salutation) yoga practice, which enhances vitality and improves health.

observances.name: Kansa Vadh
observances.description_1: Kansa Vadh is a significant event in Hindu mythology and is celebrated to commemorate the victory of Lord Krishna over the tyrant king Kansa.
observances.description_2:
Kansa Vadh is observed on the Dashami thiti of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Kartika and usually falls ten days after the Deepavali Lakshmi Puja. Kansa Vadh is local festival of Braj region and is mainly celebrated in city of Mathura by the Chaturvedi community.

Kansa, the king of Mathura, was a ruthless and oppressive ruler. He imprisoned his sister Devaki and her husband Vasudeva after hearing a divine prophecy that their eighth son would kill him. To protect Krishna from Kansa, he was secretly transported to Gokul after his birth. Krishna spent his childhood in Gokul and Vrindavan, performing various miracles. As Krishna grew up, Kansa became increasingly fearful of the prophecy. To eliminate Krishna, he invited him and his brother Balarama to Mathura under the pretext of a wrestling competition. Upon arriving in Mathura, Krishna and Balarama defeated several of Kansa's strong allies. Finally, Krishna confronted Kansa in the wrestling arena. Despite Kansa's formidable power, Krishna overpowered and killed him, thereby ending his reign of terror. King Ugrasena was reinstated as King of Mathura.

Kansa Vadh is celebrated by worshipping Lord Krishna and Goddess Radha.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

observances.name: Utthana Ekadashi Grihastha
observances.description_1: Utpanna Ekadashi is a fasting day dedicated to Lord Vishnu that falls in the month of Margashirsha(Krishna Paksha).
observances.description_2:
Utpanna Ekadashi is celebrated on the eleventh day of the Krishna Paksha in the month of Margashirsha. Utpanna Ekadashi is considered particularly auspicious as it is believed to be the day when the Ekadashi fast was first established.

According to Hindu mythology, there was a powerful demon named Murasura who terrorized the gods and disrupted the cosmic order. The gods, unable to defeat him, sought the help of Lord Vishnu. Lord Vishnu engaged in a fierce battle with Murasura. During the battle, Lord Vishnu took refuge in a cave to rest. While Lord Vishnu was resting, Murasura attempted to attack him. To protect Lord Vishnu, a divine feminine energy emerged from his body, manifested as a radiant goddess. She fought Murasura and defeated him, thus protecting Lord Vishnu. Pleased with her valor and devotion, Lord Vishnu named her Ekadashi and hence Utpanna Ekadashi is considered the birth anniversary of Ekadashi. Devotees, who pledge to observe yearly fasting, begin Ekadashi fasting from Utpanna Ekadashi.

Devotees observe a strict fast on Utpanna Ekadashi, abstaining from grains. Some may follow a complete fast without food and water, while others may consume fruits, milk, and water. The fast begins at sunrise on Ekadashi and ends after sunrise on the following day, Dwadashi.

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Tulsi Vivah
observances.description_1: Tulsi Vivah is a ceremonial event celebrated, marking the ceremonial marriage of the sacred Tulsi plant with Lord Vishnu.
observances.description_2:
Tulsi Vivah is celebrated across India, with special emphasis in states like Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh, Gujarat, and Karnataka.

The festival is celebrated on the twelfth day of the Shukla Paksha in Kartika masa.

The central deities worshipped during Tulsi Vivah are Lord Vishnu and Tulsi Devi. The marriage is symbolic, representing the sacred bond between the divine couple. Tulsi is considered an incarnation of Goddess Lakshmi, and the festival is believed to bring prosperity, happiness, and spiritual well-being.

The rituals of Tulsi Vivah involve the ceremonial marriage of Tulsi and Vishnu, conducted in temples and households. Devotees perform puja, recite hymns, and offer sweets to the divine couple. The Tulsi plant is adorned with ornaments and vermillion, signifying its status as a sacred bride. The festival is also an occasion for charitable acts and cultural celebrations.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

deities.title: Tulasi
deities.description: Tulsi, also known as Holy Basil or Vrinda, is a sacred plant. She is considered the avatar of Lakshmi and the principal consort of the god Vishnu. The offering of its leaves is mandatory in ritualistic worship of Vishnu and his avatars, including Krishna and Vithoba. The leaves of the Tulsi plant are believed to be a symbol of purity and devotion, and they are offered during puja to Lord Vishnu and Goddess Lakshmi.

observances.name: Karthika Somavara - Chaturtha
observances.description_1: Chaturtha Somvara, the fourth and final monday of Karthika masa, marks the culmination of the month-long observance for Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Karthika Somavara is a special time dedicated to Lord Shiva, observed on Mondays during Karthika masa. People believe that fasting and praying on these days can help cleanse sins, fulfill wishes, and bring blessings from Lord Shiva.

On Karthika Somavara, devotees start their day early with a purifying bath, often in sacred rivers or water bodies. They visit Shiva temples or perform prayers and rituals at home, offering bilva leaves, milk, fruits, and bael (wood apple) to show their devotion.

Many people fast throughout the day, not eating or drinking until evening when they perform the evening puja to Lord Shiva. This fast is seen as a way to cleanse both body and mind, leading to spiritual purification.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Vaikuntha Chaturdashi
observances.description_1: Vaikuntha Chaturdashi celebrates the combined worship of Lord Vishnu and Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Vaikuntha Chaturdashi is observed on chaturdashi tithi of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Kartika. It is unique because it honors both deities, Lord Shiva and Lord Vishnu.

According to legend, Lord Vishnu once went to Varanasi to worship Lord Shiva on this day. Lord Vishnu wanted to worship Lord Shiva with 1,000 lotuses but couldn't find the 1000th lotus. So, he offered one of his eyes to Shiva. Pleased with Vishnu's devotion, Shiva not only restored his eye but also gave him the Sudharshana Chakra.

For pooja, the devotees of Lord Vishnu prefer Nishitha Kaala, which is midnight while the devotees of Lord Shiva prefer Arunodaya which is dawn. For the devotees of Shiva, early morning bath during Arunodaya at Manikarnika Ghat in Varanasi is very significant and ts known as Manikarnika Snan.

On this occasion, Vishnu is given a special place of honour in the sanctum of Kashi Vishwanath temple, a prominent Shiva temple in Varanasi. The temple is described as Vaikuntha on this day.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

deities.title: Sri Panduranga
deities.description: Sri Panduranga is a form of the Vishnu in his Krishna avatar. He worshipped primarily in the Indian states of Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Andhra Pradesh. The Varkari sect, a devotional movement centered around Panduranga, emphasizes the values of humility, devotion, and community service. He embodies a youthful, compassionate aspect of Lord Krishna.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

observances.name: Manikarnika Snan
observances.description_1: Manikarnika Snan is a sacred bathing ritual observed at the Manikarnika Ghat, one of the holiest ghats along the banks of the Ganges River in Varanasi, India.
observances.description_2:
Manikarnika Snan is the ritualistic bathing ceremony on the Chaturdashi thiti of Shukla Paksha in the month of Kartik on the Manikarnika Ghat in Varanasi.

Manikarnika ghat holds immense spiritual significance in Hinduism and is believed to be a place where devotees can attain moksha through ritualistic bathing. It is closely associated with Lord Shiva, who is believed to reside in Varanasi.

On the day of Manikarnika Snan, the bathing ceremony on the Manikarnika Ghat is performed during the last quarter of the night. Thousands of devotees from across the country gather at Varanasi on this day and perform the ritual to attain moksha.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

deities.title: Ganga
deities.description: Goddess Ganga, is the personification of the sacred River Ganga. She is believed to have descended from the heavens to Earth, through the efforts of King Bhagiratha, to cleanse the souls of his ancestors and relieve them from a curse. She is seen as a divine purifier, capable of washing away sins and providing salvation to those who bathe in her sacred waters or have their ashes immersed in the river.

observances.name: Dev Diwali
observances.description_1: Celebrated in Varanasi with grand illuminations on the ghats of the Ganges to honor the victory of Lord Shiva over the demon Tripurasura.
observances.description_2:
Dev Deepawali is a festival celebrated in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, India. It is also known as Choti Deepavali.

The word Dev Deepawali comes from "Dev", which means divine or godly, and "Diwali", which refers to the festival of lights that falls on the full moon night of the Hindu month of Kartik,

According to Hindu mythology, the gods and the goddesses come down to earth to take a dip in the holy waters of the river Ganges on the auspicious day of Dev Diwali. The ghats of Varanasi are lit with diyas to pay respect to all the gods and goddesses. The celebration of the triumph of Lord Shiva against the demon Tripurasura is also celebrated on this day.

People, on this day, decorate their homes in rangoli and oil lamps, and the ghats of Varanasi are decorated in diyas. The Ganga Aarti on Dev Diwali is one of the main attractions of the festival. 24 priests and 24 young girls perform the Ganga Aarti with utmost devotion on this day.

Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. She is seen as a divine purifier, capable of washing away sins and providing salvation to those who bathe in her sacred waters or have their ashes immersed in the river.

observances.name: Purnima
observances.description_1: Purnima, signifies the full moon day, often marked by religious ceremonies and spiritual observances.
observances.description_2:
Purnima, or the Full Moon day, is a significant occasion in Indian culture, occurring monthly as the moon reaches its maximum brightness.

Purnima fasting is observed either on the Purnima day itself or the day before, known as Chaturdashi, depending on the timing of the Purnima Tithi (lunar day) from the previous day.

Purnima fasting on Chaturdashi occurs only when the Purnima begins during the Madhyahna period on the previous day. If Chaturdashi extends beyond Madhyahna, it's considered impure for Purnima fasting, even if Purnima begins later in the evening.

In North India, the full moon day is called Purnima, while in South India, it's referred to as Pournami or Pournima, and fasting on this day is known as Pournami Vratam, observed from sunrise until the moon is sighted.

observances.name: Kanakadasa Jayanti
observances.description_1: Kanaka Dasa Jayanti commemorates the birth anniversary of Kanaka Dasa, a renowned poet, philosopher, and musician in Karnataka.
observances.description_2:
Kanaka Dasa, a renowned figure in Karnataka, was not just a poet but also a musician, philosopher, and social reformer. He significantly contributed to Carnatic music and was part of the Haridasa literary movement. Each year, his birth anniversary, known as Kanaka Dasa Jayanti, is celebrated on the 18th day of the Kartika masa.

His literary works, particularly his kirtans, played a crucial role in spreading social awareness and advocating for equality. Kanaka Dasa actively fought against class differences and the caste system, addressing these issues in his compositions. He wrote "Ramadhyanacharitre," a metaphorical piece highlighting the disparities between the rich and the poor. Through his kirtans, which were often satirical, he emphasized social themes and promoted equality among all social classes. He made his compositions accessible to the public by using the local language.

observances.name: Ganadhipa Sankashti
observances.description_1: Ganadhipa Sankashti is is a fasting day dedicated to to worshipping the Ganadhipa form of Lord Ganesha.
observances.description_2:
Ganadhipa Sankashti falls on the Chaturthi thiti of the Krishna Paksha in the month of Margashirsha.

Ganadhipa Sankashti is dedicated to the worship of Lord Ganesha, seeking his blessings for the removal of obstacles, success in endeavors, and overall prosperity. On this day, devotees of Lord Ganesha observe a strict fast from sunrise to moonrise and consume only fruits and roots or tubers.

deities.title: Ganesha
deities.description: Ganesha is the elephant-headed deity known as the remover of obstacles and the lord of beginnings. Son of Shiva and Parvati, he is commonly depicted with a broken tusk and riding a mouse. Ganesha is revered for his wisdom and is often invoked first in Hindu rituals to ensure success and clear obstacles. He also symbolizes the patronage of arts and sciences.

observances.name: Sankasta Chaturthi
observances.description_1: Sankashti Chaturthi is a significant day for Lord Ganesha devotees, observed to seek his blessings and overcome obstacles.
observances.description_2:
In the Hindu calendar, each lunar month includes two Chaturthi Tithi. The one following the full moon, known as Purnimasi, during Krishna Paksha is called Sankashti Chaturthi, while the one following the new moon, known as Amavasya, during Shukla Paksha is called Vinayaka Chaturthi.

If Sankashti Chaturthi falls on a Tuesday, it is revered as Angarki Chaturthi, considered highly auspicious, particularly in Western and Southern India, notably Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu.

During Sankashti Chaturthi, devotees of Lord Ganesha observe a fast from sunrise to moonrise. Sankashti, meaning deliverance during troubled times, signifies the belief that observing this fast can remove obstacles, as Lord Ganesha is revered as the remover of obstacles.

The fast is observed strictly, with consumption limited to fruits, roots, and vegetable products. Typical foods include Sabudana Khichadi, potatoes, and peanuts, with devotees breaking their fast after sighting the moon.

In North India, Sankashti Chaturthi in the month of Magha is known as Sakat Chauth, while Vinayaka Chaturthi in the month of Bhadrapada is celebrated as Ganesha Chaturthi worldwide as Lord Ganesha's birthday.

Among Tamil Hindus, Sankashti Chaturthi is referred to as Ganesh Sankatahara or Sankatahara Chaturthi.

observances.name: Kaal Bhairav Jayanti
observances.description_1: Jayanti of Kaal Bhairav, the fierce manifestation of Lord Shiva, particularly revered in Varanasi.
observances.description_2:
Kaal Bhairav Jayanti is a festival dedicated to Lord Kaal Bhairav, the formidable and fierce manifestation of Lord Shiva. Celebrated on the auspicious day of Kaal Bhairav's birth.

It is celebrated on the Ashtami Tithi in Krishna Paksha during Margashirsha masa.

Kaal Bhairav Jayanti is considered auspicious by devotees of MahaKaal. It is believed to be the day when Lord Shiva manifested as Lord Kaal Bhairav to protect the universe from negative forces. Kaal Bhairav is said to be the fierce form of Mahadev, and is also worshipped as the "Hindu God of Time".

Devotees observe fasts, visit Kaal Bhairav temples, and offer prayers on Kaal Bhairav Jayanti. Special pujas, including the Abhishekam of the deity, are performed to seek blessings. Lighting lamps, reciting hymns, and making offerings are common practices during this auspicious day.

observances.name: Utpanna Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Utpanna Ekadashi is a fasting day dedicated to Lord Vishnu that falls in the month of Margashirsha(Krishna Paksha).

observances.name: Vrischikam Sankramam
observances.description_1: Marking the entry of the Surya Deva into Vrischikam (Scorpio) and invoking spiritual renewal.
observances.description_2:
Vrischikam Sankramam, also known as Vrischika Sankranti, festival that celebrates the movement of the sun from one rashi to another. It marks the sun's transition from the Tula rashi to the Vrischika rashi.

Sun worshippers gather at a significant ground in front of the temple of Vrischikam day to offer Puja to the Sun. For offering Puja to the Sun, Puja performers take Tulsi seed in the Tulsi Patra and present it to the Sun during the Puja act.

Sun worshippers take a holy bath in rivers, and after taking a bath, they move to the Vishnu temple to offer prayers to the Sun. Vishnu idols are wrapped in yellow dresses, and yellow flower garlands are worn. At the end of all, Sun worshippers perform charity activities in which charity products like new clothes and food products are given to people experiencing poverty. The Festival ends with Sun prayers offered for ancestor’s salvation.

deities.title: Vishnu
deities.description: Vishnu is known as the preserver and protector of the universe, part of the Hindu Trimurti alongside Brahma and Shiva. He maintains the cosmic order and is often depicted with a dark complexion, lying on the serpent Ananta in the ocean of milk. Vishnu incarnates on Earth in various forms, known as avatars, including Rama and Krishna, to restore dharma in times of crisis. His symbols include the conch, discus, lotus, and mace, each representing different aspects of his divine authority.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

deities.title: Ayyappa
deities.description: Lord Ayyappa is the deity of truth and righteousness particularly worshipped in the southern Indian states. He is the presiding deity of the famous Sabarimala Temple. Ayyappa is considered the son of Lord Shiva and Mohini, the female avatar of Lord Vishnu, embodying both Shaiva and Vaishnava traditions. He is depicted as a celibate young man riding a tiger, carrying a bow and arrow.

observances.name: Masik Sankranti
observances.description_1: Masik Sankranti marks the transition of the Sun into a new zodiac sign each month, observed with spiritual significance.
observances.description_2:
Sankranti refers to the transmigration of the sun from one rashi (zodiac) to another in Indian astronomy
The observance revolves around sun’s transition into new rashi (zodiac sign), symoblizing the end of one solar month and the beginning of another.

Malik Sankranti’s including the Makara Sankranthi is associated with Surya pravesh (Sun’s entry) into each rashi. There are twelve rashis (12 signs) namely Mekh (Mekha), Virkh, Mithun, Kark, Singh-Simha, Kanya, Tula,Vrischik, Dhan, Makara, Kumbh and Meena.

While significance and rituals may vary for each Masik Sankranti, they are generally considered as times to offer prayers, seek blessings and make positive changes in one’s life.

Sankranti days are considered good for charity activities and all auspicious ceremonies are avoided on the day of Sankranti(s).

observances.name: Mandalakala Pooja
observances.description_1: The 41-day period of austerity and devotion undertaken by devotees at the Sabarimala Ayyappan Temple.
observances.description_2:
The Sabarimala Ayyapa temple in Kerala has an auspicious ritual that is performed on its premises known as Mandala puja. This is a 41-day-long austerity observed by the devotees known as Mandala Kalam. The puja rituals are carried out by the devotees of Lord Ayyapa. It begins with the Vrishchik Masam when the Vrishchik Sankranti occurs, and ends at Dhanu Masam.

The Mandala puja at Sabarimala temple falls on the eleventh or the twelfth day of Dhanu Masam. There are two famous festivals dedicated to the Ayyapa temple called Mandala Puja and Makar Vilakku.

Vratam or fasting, is an integral part of Mandala Puja and living in austerity is also mandatory for people who visit the Sabarimala temple.
During the period of Mandala Puja, devotees lead a very simple life, wear rudraksha or tulsi mala with lord Ayyappa's locket till the time they make a visit to the Sabarimala Ayyappa temple and then they take out the mala. During this time, the devotees are termed as 'Swami' or 'Ayyappan'.

deities.title: Ayyappa
deities.description: Lord Ayyappa is the deity of truth and righteousness particularly worshipped in the southern Indian states. He is the presiding deity of the famous Sabarimala Temple. Ayyappa is considered the son of Lord Shiva and Mohini, the female avatar of Lord Vishnu, embodying both Shaiva and Vaishnava traditions. He is depicted as a celibate young man riding a tiger, carrying a bow and arrow.

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

This fasting is observed on both Trayodashi Tithis, occurring in both Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha of the lunar month. Some differentiate between Shukla and Krishna Paksha Pradosham.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: Vivah Panchami
observances.description_1: Commemorating the wedding of Lord Rama and Goddess Sita.
observances.description_2:
Vivah Panchami is a sacred festival that marks the celestial wedding anniversary of Lord Rama and Goddess Sita. Celebrated on the fifth day of the Shukla Paksha in Margashirsha masa.

Lord Rama and Goddess Sita are the deities worshipped on Vivah Panchami. The festival commemorates their divine union, symbolizing the ideals of love, loyalty, and righteousness. Devotees seek the blessings of the divine couple for a harmonious and blissful married life.

Devotees observe fasts, visit temples dedicated to Lord Rama and Goddess Sita, and participate in processions and cultural events. The recitation of verses from the Ramayana, the epic narrating the life of Lord Rama, is a common practice. Many also reenact scenes from the wedding of Lord Rama and Goddess Sita.

deities.title: Rama
deities.description: Lord Rama is the seventh avatar of Vishnu, incarnated to defeat the demon king Ravana and restore dharma. He is one of the most revered deities in Hinduism. He embodies the ideals of virtue, duty, and kingly conduct, often referred to as Maryada Purushottama. His life and actions serve as a guide for ideal behavior in various roles - as a son, husband, brother, and king.

deities.title: Shri Sita
deities.description: Goddess Sita is an incarnation of Goddess Lakshmi, the consort of Lord Vishnu, and is worshipped as a deity embodying purity, devotion, and strength. Her life, as depicted in the epic Ramayana, exemplifies ideal womanhood, virtue, and unwavering faith, making her a symbol of fidelity and resilience. Worshipped alongside Lord Rama, Sita is often depicted seated beside him, showcasing her integral role in the divine couple's balance of dharma (righteousness) and karma (duty).

observances.name: Subrahmanya Sasthi
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Sashti
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Gita Jayanti
observances.description_1: Revering the divine discourse, commemorating the advent of the Bhagavad gita, a spiritual beacon for humanity.
observances.description_2:
Gita Jayanti is a observance that marks the day the Bhagavad Gita dialogue occurred between Arjuna and Krishna on the battlefield of Kurukshetra. It is celebrated on the Shukla Ekadashi of Margashirsha masa.

It is a day of great religious importance as the Bhagavad Gita is one of the most sacred scriptures of Hinduism.

Devotees engage in reading and reciting the verses of the Bhagavad Gita, organizing discourses, and participating in group discussions on its profound philosophy. Many undertake fasts and visit temples dedicated to Lord Krishna. The day is dedicated to gaining spiritual insight and understanding the essence of life's purpose.

deities.title: Krishna
deities.description: Krishna is revered as the eighth avatar of Vishnu. He is known for his roles in the Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita, where he serves as Arjuna's charioteer and imparts spiritual wisdom. Krishna's life story, filled with playful and miraculous events, is celebrated in the festival of Janmashtami. His teachings on various paths of yoga and devotion have deeply influenced Hindu thought and philosophy.

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Annapurna Jayanti
observances.description_1: Annapurna Jayanti is dedicated to Goddess Annapurna, the deity of food and nourishment.
observances.description_2:
Annapurna Jayanti is observed on the Purnima in the month of Margashirsha.This day commemorates the birth anniversary of Goddess Annapurna, the Goddess of nourishment. Goddess Annapurna is known to be an incarnation of Goddess Parvati.

A popular legend associated with Annapurna Jayanti involves Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati. According to the story, Lord Shiva once remarked that everything in the material world, including food, is an illusion (Maya). To demonstrate the importance of food, Goddess Parvati disappeared, causing the world to suffer from famine and hunger. When Shiva realized the importance of food and sustenance, he sought Parvati's forgiveness, and she returned as Annapurna to provide nourishment to the world.

observances.name: Dattatreya Jayanthi
observances.description_1: Commemorating the divine trinity, celebrating the birth anniversary of Lord Dattatreya, the embodiment of Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Dattatreya Jayanthi is a sacred festival that honours Lord Dattatreya, the divine incarnation representing the holy trinity of Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva. Celebrated on the auspicious day of Lord Dattatreya's birth.

Dattatreya Jayanthi is observed on Purnima in Margashirsha masa, typically falling in December.

Lord Dattatreya, often depicted with three heads and six arms, represents the unity of the divine trinity—Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva. Devotees worship Lord Dattatreya seeking spiritual guidance, knowledge, and the harmonious integration of the creative, preservative, and destructive aspects of the cosmos.

Devotees observe fasts, visit temples, and engage in prayers and hymns dedicated to Lord Dattatreya. The recitation of the "Dattatreya Ashtakam" and the "Guru Gita" is considered auspicious. Some may also engage in acts of charity and seva on this day.

deities.title: Dattatreya
deities.description: Dattatreya is the combined form of the trinity of Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva. He is often depicted with three heads, symbolizing the unification of these three gods, and six hands, holding various objects associated with each deity. Dattatreya was born to the sage Atri and his wife Anasuya, who received a boon from the Trimurti, resulting in the birth of a child embodying all three gods. Dattatreya is regarded as a teacher of wisdom, yoga, and spiritual knowledge, and he is considered an incarnation of divine energy.

observances.name: Karthigai Deepam
observances.description_1: Commemorating the appearance of Lord Shiva as an infinite light.
observances.description_2:
Karthigai Deepam is predominantly celebrated in Tamil Nadu. The festival is observed with great enthusiasm in cities like Chennai and Madurai, where the lighting of lamps becomes a grand and vibrant affair.

Karthigai Deepam is celebrated on the day of Karthigai Pournami, typically in November or December. The lighting of the lamp, known as the "Mahadeepam," is the highlight of the festival.

Lord Shiva and Lord Murugan (Subramanya) are the deities worshipped during Karthigai Deepam. The festival is celebrated to commemorate the divine appearance of Lord Shiva as a cosmic flame, and the lighting of lamps signifies the dispelling of ignorance and the realization of spiritual knowledge.

deities.title: Shiva
deities.description: Shiva is revered as the destroyer and transformer within the Trimurti, alongside Brahma the creator and Vishnu the preserver. Known for his ascetic lifestyle and meditation, Shiva is often depicted with a third eye, a crescent moon in his hair, and the river Ganges flowing from his matted locks. He holds a trident and is accompanied by Nandi, his bull. Shiva's dance, the Tandava, symbolizes the cosmic cycles of creation and destruction. He is also the lord of all beings, the Mahadev, deeply revered in numerous forms.

observances.name: Bhairavi Jayanti
observances.description_1: Bhairavi Jayanti is dedicated to the worship of Goddess Bhairavi , one of the ten Mahavidya Goddesses.
observances.description_2:
Bhairavi Jayanti celebrates Goddess Bhairavi, consort of the Bhairava which is the fierce manifestation of Lord Shiva. She represents the fierce and powerful aspect of the divine feminine.

Goddess Bhairavi is believed to be Chandi in the Durga Saptashati who slayed Chanda and Munda.In Tantric traditions, Bhairavi holds a significant place with the bhairavi tantric kriya associated with her.

Goddess Bhairavi wears red garments and has a garland of severed heads around her neck. She is often shown standing on a corpse, symbolizing her mastery over death and her role as a transformer of consciousness.

observances.name: Purnima
observances.description_1: Purnima, signifies the full moon day, often marked by religious ceremonies and spiritual observances.
observances.description_2:
Purnima, or the Full Moon day, is a significant occasion in Indian culture, occurring monthly as the moon reaches its maximum brightness.

Purnima fasting is observed either on the Purnima day itself or the day before, known as Chaturdashi, depending on the timing of the Purnima Tithi (lunar day) from the previous day.

Purnima fasting on Chaturdashi occurs only when the Purnima begins during the Madhyahna period on the previous day. If Chaturdashi extends beyond Madhyahna, it's considered impure for Purnima fasting, even if Purnima begins later in the evening.

In North India, the full moon day is called Purnima, while in South India, it's referred to as Pournami or Pournima, and fasting on this day is known as Pournami Vratam, observed from sunrise until the moon is sighted.

observances.name: Sankasta Chaturthi
observances.description_1: Sankashti Chaturthi is a significant day for Lord Ganesha devotees, observed to seek his blessings and overcome obstacles.
observances.description_2:
In the Hindu calendar, each lunar month includes two Chaturthi Tithi. The one following the full moon, known as Purnimasi, during Krishna Paksha is called Sankashti Chaturthi, while the one following the new moon, known as Amavasya, during Shukla Paksha is called Vinayaka Chaturthi.

If Sankashti Chaturthi falls on a Tuesday, it is revered as Angarki Chaturthi, considered highly auspicious, particularly in Western and Southern India, notably Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu.

During Sankashti Chaturthi, devotees of Lord Ganesha observe a fast from sunrise to moonrise. Sankashti, meaning deliverance during troubled times, signifies the belief that observing this fast can remove obstacles, as Lord Ganesha is revered as the remover of obstacles.

The fast is observed strictly, with consumption limited to fruits, roots, and vegetable products. Typical foods include Sabudana Khichadi, potatoes, and peanuts, with devotees breaking their fast after sighting the moon.

In North India, Sankashti Chaturthi in the month of Magha is known as Sakat Chauth, while Vinayaka Chaturthi in the month of Bhadrapada is celebrated as Ganesha Chaturthi worldwide as Lord Ganesha's birthday.

Among Tamil Hindus, Sankashti Chaturthi is referred to as Ganesh Sankatahara or Sankatahara Chaturthi.

observances.name: Sarada devi Jayanti
aliases: Holy Mother Sri Sarada Devi Jayanti
observances.description_1: Sarada Devi Jayanti commemorates the birth anniversary of Sarada Devi, the spiritual consort of Sri Ramakrishna Pramahamsa, and a key figure in the Ramakrishna Movement.
observances.description_2:
Sarada Devi Jayanti commemorates the birth of Sarada Devi, the spiritual consort of the revered Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa. Born on December 22, 1853, Sarada Devi played a pivotal role in the Ramakrishna Movement, which advocates spiritual enlightenment and the unity of religions.

Her life exemplified simplicity, service, and profound spiritual wisdom, inspiring millions worldwide. Devotees celebrate this occasion with special prayers, devotional songs, and discourses reflecting on her life and teachings. Many engage in acts of charity and community service to honor her legacy.

Temples and institutions associated with the Ramakrishna Order organize elaborate ceremonies and rituals to commemorate her contributions to spiritual growth and social welfare.

observances.name: Saphala Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Saphala Ekadashi is a fasting day dedicated to Lord Vishnu that falls in the month of Pausha (Krishna Paksha)
observances.description_2:
Saphala Ekadashi is observed on the Ekadashi of the Krishna Paksha in the month of Pausha.
The word 'Saphala' means success, and it is believed that observing this Ekadashi brings prosperity and success in all endeavors.

According to Hindu mythology, the story of Saphala Ekadashi is associated with a king named Mahishmata and his eldest son, Lumpaka. Lumpaka was a sinner who indulged in immoral activities and was eventually exiled from his kingdom. During his exile, Lumpaka lived under a banyan tree in the forest and unknowingly observed a fast on Saphala Ekadashi. He also offered fruits from the banyan tree to Lord Vishnu, seeking protection from the cold. Impressed by his devotion, Lord Vishnu forgave Lumpaka's sins and restored him to his former glory. Lumpaka returned to his kingdom, reformed his ways, and ruled righteously.

Devotees observe a strict fast on Saphala Ekadashi, abstaining from grains, beans, and certain vegetables. Some may follow a complete fast without food and water, while others may consume fruits, milk, and water. The fast begins at sunrise on Ekadashi and ends after sunrise on the following day, Dwadashi.

observances.description_2:

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Masik Sankranti
observances.description_1: Masik Sankranti marks the transition of the Sun into a new zodiac sign each month, observed with spiritual significance.
observances.description_2:
Sankranti refers to the transmigration of the sun from one rashi (zodiac) to another in Indian astronomy
The observance revolves around sun’s transition into new rashi (zodiac sign), symoblizing the end of one solar month and the beginning of another.

Malik Sankranti’s including the Makara Sankranthi is associated with Surya pravesh (Sun’s entry) into each rashi. There are twelve rashis (12 signs) namely Mekh (Mekha), Virkh, Mithun, Kark, Singh-Simha, Kanya, Tula,Vrischik, Dhan, Makara, Kumbh and Meena.

While significance and rituals may vary for each Masik Sankranti, they are generally considered as times to offer prayers, seek blessings and make positive changes in one’s life.

Sankranti days are considered good for charity activities and all auspicious ceremonies are avoided on the day of Sankranti(s).

observances.name: Pradosha
observances.description_1: Pradosh Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.
observances.description_2:
Pradosh Vrat, also known as Pradosham in South India, is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

When Pradosham falls on Monday, it's called Soma Pradosham, on Tuesday, Bhauma Pradosham, and on Saturday, Shani Pradosham.

observances.name: Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: Khichadi Amavasya
observances.description_1: Amavasya, marks the new moon day, often associated with spiritual practices and rituals.
observances.description_2:
Amavasya is commonly known as the New Moon Day. This monthly occurrence marks the absence of the moon in the night sky, symbolizing a period of stillness and introspection. Amavasya is a time when individuals across India engage in rituals to honour their ancestors. The belief is that on this moonless night, the barriers between the living and the departed are thinner, allowing a more direct connection with ancestral spirits.

Amavasya falling on weekday Monday is known as Somvati Amavasya and Amavasya falling on weekday Saturday is known as Shani Amavasya.

All Amavasya days are appropriate to perform Shraddha rituals to appease ancestors. Amavasya day is also an appropriate day to perform Kalasarpa Dosha puja. Amavasya is also spelt and pronounced as Amavasai or Amavas.

Devotees observe Amavasya by performing special prayers, visiting temples, and participating in ceremonies dedicated to their forefathers.

observances.name: Sashti
observances.description_1: Sasthi Vrat is observed to seek the blessings of Lord Kartikeya.
observances.description_2:
Skanda, a revered Hindu deity, holds special significance among Tamil Hindus. He is the son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, regarded as the younger brother of Lord Ganesha in South India and the elder brother in North India. Skanda is also known as Murugan, Kartikeyan, and Subramanya.

Sashti Tithi witnesses devotees fasting during Shukla Paksha Sashti day.

observances.name: Vaikuntha Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day. On Ekadashi day, they maintain a strict fast, breaking it only after sunrise the next day, abstaining from grains and cereals throughout the fasting period.

Devotees have the flexibility to choose their fasting method, which may include fasting without water, consuming only water or fruits, or having a single meal, depending on their preference and physical capability, a decision to be made before commencing the fast.

Sometimes Ekadashi fasting is recommended for two consecutive days. It is suggested that families observe fasting on the first day, while the second day is recommended for ascetics, widows, and those seeking spiritual liberation.

Devotees of Lord Vishnu may choose to fast on both days to deepen their connection with the deity.

observances.name: Ekadashi
observances.description_1: Ekadashi is a fasting day observed twice a month, dedicated to spiritual purification and devotion to deities.
observances.description_2:
Ekadashi fasting occurs every 11th Tithi in the Hindu calendar, with two fasting days each month, one during Shukla Paksha and one during Krishna Paksha, observed by devotees seeking blessings from Lord Vishnu.

The fasting period extends over three days. Devotees eat a single meal in the afternoon before the fasting day to ensure an empty stomach the following day.
